XKD v XKE

XKD v XKE
[2025] SGFC 32

Case Number:Divorce No 2605 of 2023 (Ancillary Matters)
Decision Date:19 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): C Selvaraj (M/s Apex Law LLC) for the Husband; Grace Chacko (M/s Grace Chacko Law Practice) for the Wife.
Parties: XKD — XKE

Family Law – Care and control – Plaintiff and Defendant each seeking sole care and control of their child – Defendant is a foreigner on long-term visit pass in Singapore which will be expiring soon – Applicable considerations

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Plaintiff’s CPF contributions – Plaintiff working for about 33 years before marriage which lasted for about 12 years

Family Law – Matrimonial assets – Division – Defendant working for about four years during the marriage – Single-income marriage for the remaining eight years of the 12-year marriage – Defendant awarded 30% of the matrimonial assets

Family Law – Maintenance – Wife – Plaintiff earning higher income than Defendant – Plaintiff already past his retirement age and has only about three years of working life left – Defendant gainfully employed and can continue to work for about 20 years before reaching retirement age

Family Law – Maintenance – Child

19 March 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       The parents in this case have each sought sole care and control of their child. The mother is a foreigner on a long-term visit pass (“LTVP”) in Singapore. The pass will expire soon, and it is unclear whether it will be renewed by the authorities. Are such factors conclusive in showing that the Singaporean father ought to have sole care and control of the child? This issue – which has thus far eluded judicial comment – arose in the present case.

2       The Plaintiff is a Singaporean (“Husband”). The Defendant is a Filipino on LTVP in Singapore (“Wife”). They were married in June 2011 and have a 10-year-old son (D.O.B. XX September 2014) (“Son”).

3       After 12 years of marriage, the Husband commenced divorce proceedings in June 2023. Interim judgement was granted in August of the same year.

4       This matter came before me to determine the ancillary matters.

Child custody, care and control, and access

5       I begin with the issues relating to the Son.

Parties’ position

6       The parties have agreed to have joint custody of the child.[note: 1]

7       Each of them however wishes to have sole care and control of the Son.

Applicable principles

8       Given the parties’ position, I will have to determine which of them is a more suitable parent to care for the Son. This requires me to consider which parent can better (a) attend to the child’s emotional, developmental, and material needs, (b) provide for his daily care, and (c) make day-to-day decisions for him: see e.g., XDZ v XEA [2024] SGFC 90 (“XDZ”) at [13].

9       In making such a determination, courts have generally considered the following:

(a)      The parents’ past and present interactions with the child. For instance, which parent has shown greater concern, interest and responsibility for the child? Which parent has been the child’s primary caregiver? Which parent has a stronger bond with the child? See XDZ at [14(a)] to [14(d)].

(b)      The parents’ future caregiving arrangements. For instance, which parent can provide better care for the child? Which parent can provide a more secure and stable home environment for the child? Which parent is more willing to promote a healthy relationship between the child and the other parent? What are the child’s wishes? See XDZ at [14(e)] to [14(g)].

(c)      Adverse considerations. For instance, does any of the parent have an unhealthy lifestyle or outlook which may affect his/her ability to make rational decisions for the child? Has any of the parent acted in a way to intentionally or knowingly harm the child’s interest? See XDZ at [15].

(d)      Other considerations. When making orders of care and control, courts are mindful, for instance, that the continuity of the child’s living arrangements is an important factor for his/her emotional well-being. Courts are also slow to separate siblings from one another. See XDZ at [16].

My decision

Care and control – Considerations

10     Applying the above considerations to the present case, I make the following findings.

Considerations

Findings

Past and present interactions

(a)

Which parent has shown greater concern, interest and responsibility for the Son?

Finding – The Wife

(i) The Wife has shown concern, interest and responsibility for the Son. For instance, to spend more time with the Son, the Wife would walk with him to school and had switched jobs so that she could fetch him home from childcare.[note: 2] The Wife would also go through the Son’s lessons with him.

(ii) There is insufficient evidence to show the extent to which the Husband has shown concern, interest and responsibility for the Son.

(iii) For completeness, I wish to address two points raised by the Wife. First, she claimed that the Husband did not care for the Son as he had stopped his Tamil tuition.[note: 3] The Husband explained that he had done so as he had planned to help the child with the language himself.[note: 4] Given the Husband’s work timings (see [10(b)(ii)] below) and that the Son is likely to be free only in the evening and weekends for tuition, I am not so sure whether the Husband’s plan is feasible.

(iv) Second, the Wife submitted that the Husband had threatened to send the Son to a children’s home. To support this submission, she referred to WhatsApp messages from the Husband where he had stated that “[The Son] will be send to children home …”, “You can ask any lawyer he’s life gone”, and “This mrg I talk to Adrian he too say the same thing. [The Son] will be send to children home. Think carefully 3 of our life gone”. I am not exactly sure what is the context in which these messages were sent – e.g., whether they were threats (as alleged by the Wife) or warnings about the consequences of the Wife seeking a divorce and persuading her not to take that path. As such, I do not give much weight to these messages.

(v) For clarity, the observations in (ii) to (iv) above is not a finding that the Husband does not care for the Son.

(b)

Which parent has been the Son’s primary caregiver?

Finding – The Wife

(i) The Wife is the Son’s primary caregiver. She had stopped working after the child was born to look after him. She was the one who had brought him for his vaccinations and hospital visits.[note: 5] The Wife continued to be the Son’s primary caregiver after she returned to work in 2021: see [10(a)(i)] above.

(ii) The Husband holds a full-time job, working mostly night shifts (8.00 pm to 8.00 am).[note: 6] When working on such shifts, the Husband would leave the home at about 7.00 pm (when the Son is at home) and return home by about 9.00 am the next day (when the child is in school). This means that the Husband will hardly see the Son during weekdays. There is no evidence that the Husband intends to work the day shifts for the sake of his child.

(c)

Which parent has a stronger bond with the Son?

Finding – The Wife

The Wife is likely to have a stronger bond (than the Husband) with the Son. Apart from the Wife being the child’s primary caregiver since his birth, there is also the fact of a 56-year age gap between the Husband (66 years old) and the Son (10 years). This huge age gap may affect how the father and child relate to each other. (The Wife is about 45 years old.)

Parents’ future caregiving arrangements

(d)

Which parent can provide better care for the Son?

Finding – The Wife

(i) Both parties are currently working. The Son is in school during the morning and in after-school student care in the afternoon.

(ii) Given that the Husband will not be at home when the Son returns from after-school student care (see [10(b)(ii)] above), he intends to seek help from his six siblings and their children (who are older than the Son) to look after the child.[note: 7]

(iii) The Wife does not have any relative in Singapore. She plans to hire a domestic helper to care for the Son. I am not sure whether this idea is realistic. First, the Wife earns $1,972/month (net income) as a kitchen staff.[note: 8] Employing a helper will deplete a significant portion of the Wife’s income. Second, the Husband is unlikely to be able to help pay for the helper: see [46(d)] below.

(iv) On balance, the Wife appears to be in a better position to care for the Son. First, the Husband will hardly be able to look after the Son during weekdays: see [10(b)(ii)] above. Second, if the Husband is given sole care and control of the Son, his relatives will effectively by the child’s surrogate caregivers. Finally, there is no evidence to show that the Son is close to any of these relatives.

(e)

Which parent can provide a more secure and stable home environment for the Son?

Finding – The Husband

(i) The Husband can provide a more secure and stable home environment for the Son. The latter can live in the matrimonial flat (“Flat”) with the Husband, assuming that it is not sold.

(ii) The Wife is a foreigner and is currently staying in a women’s shelter.[note: 9] She plans to secure a HDB rental flat so that the Son can stay with her. There is a lot of uncertainty regarding (1) whether her LTVP will be renewed (see [12] below) and (2) whether HDB will approve her rental flat application.[note: 10]

(f)

Which parent is more willing to promote a healthy relationship between the Son and the other parent?

Finding – Inconclusive

Both parties appear to be equally willing to promote a healthy relationship between the Son and the other parent.[note: 11]

(g)

The Son’s wishes.

Not determined

I did not conduct a judicial interview with the Son or seek a child evaluation report. These are my reasons.

(i) First, the Son is young – only about 10 years old. The Husband submitted that the Wife had been alienating the child from him. In the circumstances, it is unclear whether the Son can express an independent and informed opinion on which parent he prefers to follow.

(ii) Second, and in any event, I do not think that it is right to place on the Son the onerous burden of having to choose between his parents.

Adverse considerations

(h)

Whether any of the parent had intentionally or knowingly harmed the Son’s interest?

Finding – Both parents

(i) The Wife and Husband has a personal protection order, made by consent, restraining each of them from using family violence against the Son.[note: 12]

(ii) The Husband claimed that he had come to know (after the PPO was granted) from a family service centre counsellor that the Wife had physically and emotionally abused the Son for many years.[note: 13] I decline to give weight to this claim because it is based on hearsay evidence (from the counsellor) and its reliability has not been tested in court.

Other considerations

(i)

Continuity of living arrangements.

Finding – The Wife

At the time of the hearing, the Son is being cared for by the Wife. Awarding care and control to her will ensure continuity of his current care arrangements.



11     Based on the above, the preponderance of considerations points to the Wife as being the more suitable parent to care for the Son.

Uncertainty over the renewal of the Wife’s LTVP

12     That said, there is one major issue if the Wife is awarded sole care and control of the child. Her LTVP expires on 2 April 2025 (i.e., about two weeks after this judgement). It is unclear whether she can renew her LTVP thereafter. This is because she needs a Singapore citizen or permanent resident to sponsor her LTVP renewal application. The evidence suggests that the Husband is unwilling to continue to be her sponsor.[note: 14]

13     If her LTVP is not renewed, the Wife will have to leave Singapore. This can lead to (a) application by the Wife to relocate the Son overseas (so as to be with her) and (b) application by the Husband for the child to remain in Singapore and be placed under his care instead.

14     Does uncertainty regarding the renewal of the Wife’s LTVP, as well as the possibility that she may denied continued stay in Singapore, mean that sole care and control of the Son must be awarded to the Husband? In my view, the answer is no. Let me explain.

(a)     In deciding in whose care and control the Son should be placed, the paramount consideration is his welfare: s 125 Women’s Charter 1961 (“Charter”).

(b)     Whether the Wife will be allowed to remain in Singapore is a relevant factor in deciding whether she should have care and control of the Son. This is because it goes towards the issue of whether she can provide a continuity of his living arrangements in the long term.

(c)     That said, it is settled law that the continuity of a child’s living arrangements is just one of the many factors that must be considered on the issue of care and control. A court must consider and balance all the relevant factors: XDZ at [14] to [16]. If the mere possibility that the Immigration and Checkpoint Authority (“ICA”) may not renew the Wife’s LTVP means that care and control of the Son must be awarded to the Husband, this is tantamount to (i) placing undue weight to the continuity factor and (ii) rendering the other factors in [9] and [10] above redundant when deciding on care and control issues.

(d)      Finally, I agree with the Wife that it will be wrong in principle for me to let ICA’s decision (on whether to renew the Wife’s LTVP) dictate my decision on which parent should have care and control of the Son. This is because the ICA decision is based on immigration policy considerations, whereas my decision is to be based solely on the Son’s welfare and interest.

15     To be clear – the foregoing should not be understood to mean that the non-renewal of a parent’s LTVP is an irrelevant consideration altogether: see [14(b)] above. Rather, the issue is what weight ought to be placed on this factor. In this regard, much depends on the circumstances of each case. For instance –

(a)     If the factors in [9] are finely balanced, then the possibility that the LTVP may not be renewed can tip the balance in favor of awarding care and control to the Singaporean parent.

(b)     Additionally, a child’s age – e.g., whether it is (i) a baby, (ii) schooling, (iii) approaching the age for national service enlistment (in the case of males), or (iv) on the cusp of adulthood – can also affect the weight to be placed on the possibility that a parent’s LTVP may not be renewed.

16     I am mindful that the scenarios in [13] above can be severely disruptive for the Son. In my view, this does not displace the clear evidence that the Wife is better able (than the Husband) to care for the child.

(a)     The Son is still young – only about 10 years’ age – and in his formative years. The Wife (i) has been his primary caregiver since birth, (ii) shares a stronger bond with him, and (iii) is a more caring parent: see [10(a)] to [10(d)] above.

(b)     If the Son is placed in the Husband’s care and control, the child is likely to have a difficult time bonding with his father (given the latter’s work routine and their wide age gap). The Son may also end up feeling like an “abandoned child” if he were passed around from relative to relative to be looked after when the Husband is not free to take care of him. (I note that the Husband did not designate any particular relative who will be responsible for helping to look after the Son if the need arises.)

17     For completeness, I wish to address one other point. The Husband has submitted that the Wife is seeking care and control of the Son for an ulterior motive – to remain in Singapore. I am unable to accept this submission. The Wife’s life will not be easy if she remains in Singapore and have to look after the Son. This is because she will effectively be a single mother who must juggle between (a) caring for her growing child and (b) holding a full-time job. She will probably be doing this without a helper’s assistance: see [10(d)(iii)] above. This hardship will persist for a long time – as it will be a decade before the Son reaches adulthood.

Order

18     After considering all the factors wholistically, I decide to award the Wife sole care and control of the Son. Consequential orders arising from this decision can be found in Annex A.

Division of matrimonial assets

19     I now come to the division of the matrimonial assets. I begin by identifying which of the parties’ assets are “matrimonial assets” and thus liable for division.

Parties’ assets

21     The Wife claims that she does not have any asset or liability.

Assets liable for division

Flat

22     The Husband submitted that the Flat should be excluded from division. This is because it is “solely owned and paid for” by him.[note: 19] On the other hand, the Wife claimed that she had contributed $500/month towards the Flat’s mortgage from December 2021 to December 2023 (total contributions: $12,000). According to the Wife, she had recorded these contributions in a notebook. However, the notebook had since mysteriously disappeared.[note: 20]

23     In my view, the Flat is a “matrimonial asset” as defined under s 112(10)(b) of the Charter and is thus liable for division.

(a)      First, the definition of a “matrimonial asset” includes assets of any nature “acquired during the marriage by one party or both parties to the marriage”. (emphasis added) It is clear from this definition that so long as a property is acquired by a spouse during marriage, it is “matrimonial asset”. This so even if the property is “solely owned and paid for” by one spouse: BJS v BJT [2013] 4 SLR 41 at [34]; BPC v BPB [2019] 1 SLR 608 at [49] and [52]. In the present case, the Husband bought the Flat in February 2013 – i.e., during the marriage.

(b)      Second, the Husband clearly had intended the Flat to be a “matrimonial home”. It is his evidence that after the marriage, he had looked “for a flat for us”[note: 21] – i.e., the Wife and himself. Further, the Husband explained that he had listed the Wife as an occupier in the Flat because she was his spouse.[note: 22]

(c)      Finally, it is not disputed that the Flat had been used as a “matrimonial home”.

25     The parties’ position regarding the above CPF funds are as follows:

(a)     According to the Husband, the funds should be excluded from division. This is because (i) a substantial portion of them came from 33 years of CPF contributions which he had made before marriage (since 1978 when he started working at age 20), and (ii) the contributions that he had made during the marriage form only a small portion of these funds.[note: 23]

(b)     The Wife submitted that the CPF funds should be included in the matrimonial pool. According to her, the Husband had failed to prove how much of these funds were contributed before and after marriage. In the circumstances, it would be pure speculation for him to claim that all the funds were acquired before marriage. Furthermore, in accordance with CPF’s usual policy, the Husband would have used up all the funds in his Ordinary Account when he paid for the Flat. This means that the funds currently in this account must have been acquired after such payment.

26     My findings are as follows.

(a)     I accept the Wife’s submission (i) that the Husband has the burden of proof, and (ii) that he is likely to have used up most of the funds in his Ordinary Account to pay for the Flat’s downpayment ($59,200). I would add that the Husband is also likely to have thereafter used the monthly contributions into his Ordinary Account to settle the Flat’s monthly mortgage payments. This means that the funds currently in his Ordinary Account – $145.75 – is likely to have been acquired after the marriage.

(b)     As for the funds in the other accounts, i.e., the Medisave Account, Special Account, and Retirement Account, I find that most of them are likely to have come from contributions that the Husband had made before the marriage. This is because the circumstances in which funds may be withdrawn from these accounts are very limited. In other words, the CPF contributions which the Husband had made since the start of his working life (in 1978) are likely to have remained largely intact in these accounts.

(c)     I note that the Husband has been working for about 45 years as of 2023 (when the marriage ended). Of this period, he was married for about 12 years (i.e., about ¼ of his working life).

(d)     Taking a broadbrush approach, I find that ¼ of the CPF funds in [24(e)] should be added to the matrimonial pool. This amount comes to $30,704.17.[note: 24]

Funds in the Husband’s POSB account

27     Next, I turn to the funds in the Husband’s POSB account ($10,602.37). According to the Husband, these funds should be excluded because they represent his savings from the time he started working in 1978.

28     I am unable to accept the Husband’s case. Over the past 45 years, there would have been funds flowing into and out of the account – including payments for big ticket items such as renovations and furnishings of the Flat ($114,645): see [34(a)(iii)]. In my view, the $10,602.37 in the POSB account should be added to the matrimonial pool.

Just and equitable division

30     Having identified the matrimonial assets, the next issue is how they can be divided between the parties in a “just and equitable” way.

Nature of marriage

31     In addressing this issue, I note several things. First, the parties had a marriage that lasted for about 12 years. Second, the Wife was working briefly at the start of the marriage (from June 2011 to November 2014 – when the Son was born). Finally, she resumed working again towards the end of the marriage (for about 20 months before interim judgement was granted).

Appropriate approach

32     I agree with the Husband that it is inappropriate to use the “structured approach” enunciated in ANJ v ANK [2015] 4 SLR 1043 to distribute the matrimonial assets.[note: 25] This is because the structured approach is intended for dual-income marriages: TNL v TNK [2017] 1 SLR 609 at [42], [44], [46] and [47].

33     In the present case, the parties had for most part (about eight out of 12 years) a single-income marriage.[note: 26] In WOS v WOT [2024] SGHC(A) 11, the High Court held that –

36    … In single-income marriages, the court considers the division trends in case precedents with a similar factual matrix including, importantly, the length of the marriage and the contributions of the parties. …

[emphasis added]

Wife’s Share

34     In the present case, I find that it is “just and equitable” to award the Wife 30% of the matrimonial assets ($313,951.43). On this basis, the Wife will receive $94,185.43 (“Wife’s Share”). In coming to this finding, I have considered the following:

(a)     In terms of financial contributions, the Husband was the sole breadwinner during eight years of the 12-year marriage. He had also contributed much more financially to acquiring the Flat and making it habitable: see table below. (Note. The Wife contributed only $12,000: see [22] above.)

(b)     As for non-financial contributions, I note that the Husband had coordinated and supervised the renovation and furnishing of the Flat.[note: 28] On the other hand, the Wife had stopped working after the Son’s birth and devoted herself to being a full-time homemaker and to raising the child.

(c)     The case precedents reveal the following:

(i)       Where (1) the wife made little or no direct contributions, (2) the marriage was a childless one, and (3) the marriage’s length was about 10 years, it would be just and equitable to award her between 10% to 20% of the total pool of assets: Zhou Lijie v Wang Chengxiang [2015] SGHC 316 at [60].

(ii)       For marriages around 10 to 15 years’ duration, “the trend appears to be towards awarding the non-income earning party about 25% to 35% of the matrimonial pool”: BOR v BOS [2018] SGCA 78 at [113].

35     I come to the next issue – How is the Wife’s Share to be paid?

Option 1 – Lump sum payment

36     If the Husband wants to keep the Flat, then one option is for him to pay the Wife’s Share in one lump sum within a reasonable period of this judgement, e.g., in about two months.

37     If the Husband chooses this option, then he is entitled to look to the Wife to pay her share of funds needed to discharge the outstanding mortgage ($107,355.11). This is because the value of the Wife’s Share is calculated based on the outstanding mortgage having been fully discharged: see [20(a)] above. It would not be fair to the Husband if he has to bear the full responsibility of discharging this mortgage while the Wife can reap the full benefits of the net value of the Flat without having to pay a single cent towards the outstanding mortgage.

38     In my view, it will be fair for the parties’ contributions towards discharging the outstanding mortgage liability to be based on their respective share in the Flat – i.e. 70% (Husband): 30% (Wife).

39     In other words, if the Husband elects the lump sum payment mode, then he will need to pay the Wife $61,978.90 – i.e., Wife’s Share ($94,185.43) minus Wife’s contributions towards the outstanding mortgage ($32,206.53).[note: 29] After receiving the Wife’s contributions towards the mortgage, the Husband will be responsible for discharging the Flat’s outstanding mortgage.

Option 2 – Sale of the Flat

40     If the Husband is unable to pay the Wife’s Share within a reasonable period, then –

(a)     The Flat will have to be sold in the open market,

(b)     The balance sale proceeds – after making the relevant deductions – will be divided in accordance with the parties’ respective share in the Flat – i.e., the Husband (70%) and the Wife (30%), and

(c)     The Husband will have to pay the Wife $12,391.97 – this amount being 30% of the funds in the Husband’s (i) CPF accounts ($30,704.17) and (ii) POSB account ($10,602.37): see [29(b)] and [29(c)].

Spousal maintenance

Parties’ position

41     Next, I turn to the Wife’s application for spousal maintenance.

(a)     According to the Wife, she needs maintenance ($350/month) to cover the increased utilities and groceries, as well as the costs of renting a place to stay.[note: 30] When I pointed out to the Wife’s counsel that the Husband had already passed his retirement age, she submitted that being in the security field, he could work for as long as he is fit and able. Furthermore, the Husband could seek a variation of the spousal maintenance if he were to subsequently lose his job.

(b)     The Husband objected to paying spousal maintenance on the following grounds: (i) the Wife has an income, (ii) he has not provided her with maintenance during their marriage, and (iii) he does not have any surplus funds.[note: 31]

My decision

42     I decline to award spousal maintenance. My reasons are as follows.

(a)      First, the Wife has a higher earning capacity than the Husband.

(i)       The Husband is already past his retirement age. He has only about three years of working life left before he is not entitled to be re-employed.

(ii)       On the other hand, the Wife has been gainfully employed since 2021. She is now only about 45 years old and can continue to work for the next two decades before she reaches the retirement age.

(iii)       I find the Wife’s submission that the Husband could continue working for as long as he wants to be unrealistic. The Husband is not in the best of health – having suffered a heart attack in 2016.[note: 32] This will affect his ability to continue working.

(b)      Second, the Wife will receive funds from the division of matrimonial assets ($61,978.90) that can provide her with some level of financial security.

Conclusion

47     Before concluding, I wish to make a few observations.

(a)     At the time of this judgement, there is a great deal of uncertainty regarding whether the Wife can remain in Singapore after her LTVP expires.

(b)     The future looks grim for all parties concerned if the Wife cannot remain in Singapore.

If care and control is awarded to the Husband –

(i)       The Wife will find it very challenging to maintain the maternal bond with the Son from overseas. This can be highly distressful for any mother.

(ii)       The Son will lose the deep connection and care of his mother, who has been his primary care giver since his birth.

(iii)       The Husband may have to bear the burden of maintaining the Son alone if the Wife is not able to provide her share of child maintenance, e.g., because of she receives a lower income in her home country.

If the Son is allowed to relocate overseas to be with the Wife –

(iv)       The Husband may grow apart from the Son due to the geographical distance between them.

(v)       The Son has been living in Singapore for his entire life. He may find it difficult to adjust to living in a different country and culture.

(c)     Given these harsh realities, it is in the parties’ interests to work together – to explore how the Husband can assist the Wife to remain in Singapore.

XJZ v XJY and another matter

XJZ v XJY and another matter
[2025] SGFC 30

Case Number:SS No. 806 of 2024; SS No. 879 of 2024
Decision Date:17 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Sharifah Nor Azizah Binte Sheikh Azad Ally & Azalea Syazwany Binte Mohamad Khair for the Wife; Mohamed Niroze Idroos for the Husband
Parties: XJZ — XJY

Family Law – Family violence – Orders for protection – Cross-applications by husband and wife – Whether husband and wife have discharged their respective burden of proof

17 March 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       This case involves cross-applications for personal protection order (“PPO”) by applicants who are a divorcing couple. They were married in 2020 and have a daughter together (D.O.B: XX March 2022) (“Daughter”).

2       On 21 April 2024, the Wife left the matrimonial home (“Flat”) with the Daughter to reside at her parents’ home (“Parents’ Home”).

3       Shortly thereafter, the parties applied for PPO against each other. The brief details of their applications are as follows.

Date of application

Applicant

Sought PPO to protect –

(a)

April 2024

Wife

Wife & Daughter

SS No. 806/2024

(b)

May 2024

Husband

SS No. 879/2024



4       At the time of this decision, the parties are undergoing divorce proceedings. Issues relating to the Daughter’s custody, care and control, and access are contested in those proceedings. Regarding the access issue, the Wife has apparently denied the Husband physical access to the child since 21 April 2024 – and had allowed them to communicate via video calls only.

5       At the end of the hearing, I granted a PPO for the Wife. I dismissed the parties’ respective application for a PPO for the Daughter.

6       I will now explain the reasons for my decision – beginning with the Wife’s application.

Wife’s application

Grounds for application

7       The Wife relied on the following seven incidents for her PPO application.

 

Date

Location

To support application for –

(a)

18.02.24 9.00 pm

Bedroom in the Flat

Wife and Daughter

(b)

21.04.24 7.00 am

(c)

21.04.24 10.00 pm

Outside the Parents’ Home

Wife

(d)

26.04.24 11.00 am

Daughter’s playschool

Wife and Daughter

(e)

26.04.24 8.00 pm

Home of the Wife’s aunt

Wife

(f)

24.05.24 2.45 pm

Daughter’s playschool

(g)

17.06.24

WhatsApp messages



18 February 2024 – Force-feeding, threats and shove

Wife’s case

8       I will first deal with the 18 February incident. The Wife made the following allegations.[note: 1]

(a)      The force-feeding. At the material time, the Daughter was crying in the master-bedroom (occupied by the Husband). On opening the door, the Wife saw the Husband force-feeding the child with a milk bottle to pacify her and to stop her crying. The Daughter choked and the parties took the child to the toilet to clean up.

(b)      The threat. While attending to the child, the Husband repeatedly shouted at the Wife, “Go away, don’t come near me. … If you continue, I won’t let you see her again”. The Wife felt threatened by these words.

(c)      The shove and injury. At one point, the Husband placed the Daughter down on the bed. When the Wife tried to console the child, he shoved the Wife aside to remove her from the child. As a result, the Wife lost her balance, tipped over, and hit her right knee against a desk in the bedroom. This caused her to suffer a bruise on the knee.

Husband’s case

9       The Husband denied the above allegations.[note: 2]

My decision

10     I find that the Wife had failed to prove her allegations. My reasons for this finding are as follows.

11      First, the Husband had tendered a video which shows the events in the master-bedroom on 18 February 2024 from 9.05 pm to 9.14 pm. This video materially contradicts the Wife’s allegations.[note: 3]

(a)      The force-feeding. The video does not show the Husband force-feeding the Daughter. Instead, it shows him being very gentle with the child, calling her “Sayang” repeatedly, and trying to pacify her for about 10 mins.

(b)      The threat. Additionally, the video does not show the Husband repeatedly telling the Wife that he would not let her see the Daughter.

(i)       Instead, the video shows him simply telling the Wife to go away and to leave the child alone.

(ii)       Admittedly, the Husband had raised his voice towards the Wife. In my view, this does not constitute family violence in the nature of “continual harassment”.[note: 4] It bears highlighting that at the material time, the parties (being concerned parents) must have been distressed by the child’s vomiting and incessant crying. From the video, the Husband appears to be unhappy with the Wife for interfering in his attempts to pacify the Daughter. The Husband’s remarks and tone of voice to the Wife should be seen against this situational backdrop.

(iii)       The video also shows that despite having been asked to “go away”, the Wife had remained with the child throughout, and the Husband did not remove her from the bedroom. This shows that the Husband’s remarks were uttered in the heat of the moment and that the Wife was not in fear of him at the material time.

(c)      The shove and injury. Finally, the video does not show the Husband shoving the Wife aside to remove her from the child. Neither does it show the Wife losing her balance and hitting her right knee against a desk.[note: 5] Instead, the video shows that after the Daughter had been cleaned up and resting on the bed, the Wife left the bedroom voluntarily without any incident.

12      Second, the Wife had failed to give a reasonable explanation for the material contradictions between her allegations and the video evidence.

(a)     When confronted with the material discrepancies, the Wife claimed that the “missing” events had occurred before 9.05 pm – i.e., before the video recording started.

(b)     I am unable to accept this claim. The events in the video and the sequence in which they had occurred – e.g., (i) the Daughter crying, (ii) the Wife entering the bedroom, (iii) the parties bringing the child to the toilet to clean up, (iv) the Husband asking the Wife to go away, and (v) the child being placed on the bed to rest – mirror the Wife’s account of what had happened during the incident. For the Wife’s claim to make sense, the same events would need to have occurred twice – i.e., the first time at before 9.05 pm – and then again for the second time after 9.05 pm. However, the Wife did not testify that the events had occurred twice. Even if she did, I would have found such evidence to be incredible.

13      Finally, the Wife’s claim – that the Husband had shoved her and had thus caused her to lose her balance, hit a desk, and injure her right knee – has critical gaps and is internally inconsistent.

(a)     The Wife did not make the same claim in a police report which she had filed on 19 February 2024 – less than 24 hours after the incident.[note: 6] During cross-examination, the Wife conceded that if she had been injured as claimed, this is a material fact which she would have stated in her police report.[note: 7]

(b)     In her PPO application, the Wife had also failed to mention that she had been shoved and had thus injured her knee during the 18 February incident.[note: 8]

(c)     During re-examination, the Wife further contradicted herself by alleging that she had in fact suffered the knee injury on 21 April 2024 – not 18 February 2024.[note: 9]

21 April 2024 – Snatching of the Daughter and using force on the Wife

14     Next, I turn to the 21 April incident.

Wife’s case

15     According to the Wife, she was in her bedroom interacting with the Daughter at the material time. On seeing this, the Husband snatched the child away by forcefully pushing the Wife and slapping her hand. This caused the Wife’s shoulder and forearm to be bruised. The Husband’s actions had also caused the Daughter to cry. He eventually left the crying child on the floor.

Husband’s case

16     The Husband denied the Wife’s allegations.

My decision

17     According to the Wife, after the alleged incident, she left the Flat with the child on the same day to reside at the Parents’ Home. She submitted that there is no “plausible reason” for her to leave the Flat on that day but for the Husband’s aggressive conduct.[note: 10]

18     I am not persuaded by the Wife’s submission. I find that she had failed to prove her allegation that the Husband had used force on her. I have come to this finding because there are material omissions and discrepancies between (a) her pre-trial statements, (b) her affidavit, and (c) her testimony regarding the said allegation. These omissions and discrepancies are summarised below.

 

Pre-hearing statements

Affidavit [note: 11]

Testimony

(i)

Material omissions

 

WhatsApp messages [note: 12]

On 21 April 2024 at about 8.23 pm, the Wife informed the Husband via WhatsApp that she had decided to stay at the Parents’ Home.

Despite being asked by the Husband to explain her decision, the Wife did not state that it was due to the Husband’s alleged aggressive conduct earlier in the day.

This was so even though she had taken the trouble to text him regarding mundane information – e.g., the details about the Daughter’s activities and food consumption for that day.

The Wife did not adduce any contemporaneous message to show that she had referred to the alleged use of force by the Husband.

 

 

(ii)

Material omissions

 

Police report [note: 13]

The Wife did not mention that the Husband had caused her to suffer bruises.

Neither did she include any photo of these bruises to her police report.

 

The Wife referred to three photos (at pages 30 to 32 of her affidavit) as evidence of the bruises that she had suffered during the 21 April incident.

It is not clear from these photos (1) when they were taken and (2) what they were supposed to show.

 

The Wife agreed that if she had been injured during the 21 April incident, she would have mentioned this in the police report.

 

(iii)

Material discrepancies – Nature of the injury

 

PPO application [note: 14]

The Wife stated that the bruises were on her left shoulder and right forearm.

The Wife stated that the bruises were on her right shoulder and right forearm.

In re-examination, the Wife claimed that she had suffered a knee injury on 21 April 2024.[note: 15]

She did not mention that she had suffered the knee injury during the 21 April incident in her police report (lodged on 22 April 2024) and PPO application.



21 April 2024 – Harassment outside the Parents’ Home

19     I now come to the next incident. It is not disputed that on the same day that the Wife left the Flat (i.e., 21 April 2024), the Husband and some of his relatives went to the Parents’ Home at about 9.30 pm to look for the Daughter.

Wife’s case

20     According to the Wife, the Husband had caused harassment to her during the visit. First, by “shouting very loudly and threateningly demanding to be let inside the home for him to see the child”, and second, when his demands were denied, by lingering with his relatives at a street across the Parents’ Home for about two hours before finally leaving the area.[note: 16]

Husband’s case

21     The Husband denied having committed family violence. According to him, he had merely attempted to see the Daughter.

My decision

22     I find that the Wife has failed to prove her allegations regarding the 21 April incident. Let me explain.

(a)     This is a case involving the Wife’s bare claims against the Husband’s bare denials. Apart from the parties’ police reports[note: 17] (such reports can be self-serving), there is no other evidence to show whose evidence is more credible and reliable. In the circumstances, I am unable to find that the Wife’s account of the 21 April incident is more probable than the Husband’s.

(b)     Further, based on the Wife’s account, I find that the Husband’s actions do not constitute family violence.

(i)        First, the Wife failed to prove that the Husband had committed the relevant acts with intent to cause or knowing that they are likely to cause anguish to her: see limb (d) of the definition of “family violence” under s 64 of the Charter.

(ii)        Second, I accept the Husband’s evidence that he had gone to the Parents’ Home simply to see the Daughter – and not for the purpose of harassing the Wife. It is not disputed that the Wife’s decision for the Daughter to stay at the Parents’ Home came as a surprise to the Husband. (This is evident from the exchange of messages between the parties at the material time.[note: 18])

(iii)        Finally, it is also not disputed that the Husband had sought police assistance and filed an online police complaint before arriving at the Parents’ Home.[note: 19] Such actions are more consistent with those of a father who had resorted to legal means to see his child than one who was seeking to cause trouble or harassment.

26 April 2024 – Commotion at the Daughter’s playschool

23     I now come to the 26 April incident. It is not disputed that the Husband and his father had gone to the Daughter’s playschool on that day to see the child. It is also not disputed that the Husband was denied entry into the premises because the Wife had informed the school authorities that he was not “authorised” to see the Daughter.

Wife’s case

24     According to the Wife, the Husband had created a commotion and shouted at the school authorities after being disallowed to see the Daughter. As a result, the Wife – who was a staff at the playschool – was asked by the school management to resolve the situation. Eventually, a compromise was reached – the Wife allowed the Husband to see the Daughter briefly from outside the school premises through a glass door. Soon thereafter, the Husband and his father left.

Husband’s case

25     The Husband denied having created a commotion at the playschool. He highlighted the fact – which is undisputed – that he had waited outside the school premises to catch a glimpse of the Daughter.[note: 20]

My decision

26     In this case, the dispute centres on two issues. First, did the Husband create a commotion at the playschool. Second, if he did, then do his actions constitute family violence. On both issues, the Wife has the burden to prove that the answers are in the affirmative.

27     To discharge her burden of proof, the Wife drew my attention to the fact that when asked whether he was aware that there was a school protocol for visitors, the Husband had responded, “I believe I don’t have to follow any protocols because I am the legal parent of [the Daughter]”.[note: 21] The Wife submitted that the Husband’s response “[indicated] his intention to create a commotion at [her workplace]” at the material time.

28     I disagree. I find the link that the Wife sought to draw – i.e., between the Husband’s response above and his purported intent to harass her – to be tenuous. The evidence does not prove that the Husband had gone to the playschool to harass the Wife.

(a)     Based on the Wife’s own evidence, the Husband had allegedly created a commotion at the playschool only after learning that he was not allowed to see the Daughter. This shows that the alleged commotion was more likely to be the Husband’s spontaneous reaction to being denied access to his child than a deliberate act to harass the Wife.

(b)     Such a spontaneous reaction by the Husband is understandable.

(i)       It is not disputed that the Husband had gone to the playschool to see the Daughter. It bears highlighting that at the material time, he did not have physical access to her for about five days already – i.e., since the day that the Wife left the Flat with the child.

(ii)       As a father, it is reasonable for the Husband to believe that he had a right to see his Daughter at the playschool. At the material time, there was no court order denying him access to his child. (The Husband’s response in [27] above ought to be understood in this context.)

(iii)       Finally, the Husband came to know that he was not “authorised” to see the Daughter only after he had arrived at the playschool. This revelation must have come as a shock to him.

(c)     After being informed of the conditions for seeing the Daughter, the Husband had dutifully complied with them. He did not enter the school premises. As required by the Wife, he waited outside the school to catch a brief glimpse of his child through the glass door.

(d)     After seeing the Daughter, the Husband’s objective for the visit had been met – he left the playschool. He did not, for instance, linger at the school to cause trouble for the Wife.

26 April 2024 incident – Showing explicit photo to the Wife’s aunt

29     It is not disputed that after leaving the playschool, the Husband and his father went to the home of the Wife’s aunt. After the visit, the aunt sent WhatsApp messages[note: 22] to the Wife requesting to speak to her on the phone urgently.

Wife’s case

30     The Wife alleged that during the phone call, the aunt told her that the Husband had showed her explicit photos of the Wife. This caused the Wife to feel anxious and humiliated.[note: 23]

Husband’s case

31     The Husband denied the Wife’s allegations. According to him, he had visited the aunt just to let her know that the Wife had denied him physical access to the Daughter.

My decision

32     I find that the Wife had failed to prove her allegation.

(a)     The Wife’s case is based entirely on what the aunt had allegedly told her. The aunt did not testify at the hearing. In the circumstances, the Wife’s case is based on hearsay evidence.

(b)     The Husband – who was a party to the meeting with the aunt – had denied showing any explicit photo of the Wife during the meeting. The Wife is unable to rebut this denial given that she did not call the aunt to testify at the hearing.

(c)     The Wife submitted that I should accept her case on the basis that the Husband (i) had failed to call his father (who was also present at the meeting) to testify and (ii) had failed to produce a CCTV recording from the aunt’s premises of the meeting. In my view, the Husband’s failure to adduce such evidence does not in any way assist the Wife to discharge her own burden of proof. Her case is inherently weak as it is based on hearsay evidence.[note: 24]

24 May 2024 incident – Commotion at the Daughter’s playschool

33     I now come to the next incident. On 24 May 2024, the Husband again visited the Daughter’s playschool. It is not disputed that on this occasion, five of his relatives had also gone to the school at about the same time as him.

Wife’s case

34     According to the Wife, from around 2.45 pm to 4.00 pm,[note: 25] the Husband and his relatives began arriving at the school separately. They demanded to see the Daughter. Because of the commotion created, members of the school management, including its director (“Director”), had to intervene to manage the situation. Staff had also to be mobilised to prevent the Husband and his relatives from entering the children’s rooms. According to the Wife, she experienced “extreme fear and panic” at the material time. The Husband and his relatives eventually vacated the premises only after the school management threatened to call the police if they insisted on remaining in the premises and behaving aggressively.[note: 26]

Husband’s case

35     The Husband denied that his group had created a commotion at the playschool. According to him, he had remained outside the school premises, his sister and aunt were allowed to sit in the reception area, and the Wife was the one who had been shouting (at his sister and aunt) at the material time.

My decision

36      Wife’s account more credible. I find the Wife’s account of the 24 May incident to be more credible than the Husband’s. Given the following, the situation at the material time must have been chaotic and the Wife must have felt harassed.

(a)      First, it is not disputed that a significant number of persons (the Husband and his five relatives) had all wanted to see and speak to Daughter at the material time.

(b)      Second, it is also not disputed that the Husband and his relatives did not give prior notice to the playschool before their arrival. The school (i) would have been surprised by their visit and (ii) would not have had sufficient time to make the necessary arrangements for them.

(c)      Third, it bears highlighting that by 24 May 2024, the Husband had not physically interacted with the Daughter for more than one month. The Husband and his relatives must have felt frustrated with the Wife and the school for continuing to deny them access to the child.

(d)      Finally, the fact that tensions were high during the visit is evident in a conversation between the Husband and the Director on 27 May 2024, i.e., three days after the visit. (A transcript of this conversation was adduced at the hearing.[note: 27]) For instance –

(i)       At two points during the conversation, the Director told the Husband that he could not “have an entire gin gang of people coming here saying ... I want to see this girl”.[note: 28] He told the Husband that such actions would affect the school’s operations.[note: 29] It is clear from the Director’s remarks that the visit on 24 May 2024 by the Husband and his relatives had been chaotic and disruptive.

(ii)       The Husband’s frustration with the Director continued to persist – and this is evident from the conversation. When the Director tried to explain to the Husband why the latter could not take unilateral actions, the Husband threatened him, “I feel like you and my wife are having an affair now. So I can also bring that up to court. Do you want me to do that?” In addition to making threats, the Husband had repeatedly accused the Director of being biased in favour of the Wife because she was his employee. This is despite the fact that on several occasions, the Director had repeatedly emphasised that he was not stopping the Husband from visiting the Daughter – but that such visits must be done in accordance with school protocol. Despite this, the Husband refused to accept what the Director had to say. The Husband kept dominating the conversation and interrupting the Director when the latter tried to explain.

37      Husband complicit in the group visit. I have no doubt that the Husband was complicit in what had happened on 24 May 2024. It could not have been a sheer coincidence that five different relatives – including his grandmother, mother, aunt, and sister – had all somehow (a) known where the Daughter’s new playschool was (she was enrolled in another playschool until 21 April 2024),[note: 30] (b) wanted to see the child on the same day, and (c) descended at the school at about the same time as the Husband. The visit to the playschool by the Husband and his relatives must have been coordinated.

38      Husband’s motive. In my view, the Husband had committed family violence on 24 May 2024. Having failed to see his Daughter on 26 April 2024 at the playschool, I accept the Wife’s evidence that he had intended to intimidate her with the size of his group and to pressure her into surrendering to his demands to see his child.[note: 31] For more than an hour, the Husband – acting alone and with the complicity of his relatives – had continually harassed the Wife directly and indirectly through the school management. In behaving in a thuggish manner, the Husband must have intended to cause or known that his actions were likely to cause the Wife anguish.

17 June 2024 – Circulation of the Wife’s explicit photo

39     I now come to the final incident relied by the Wife for her PPO application. Regarding the 17 June incident, the following is not disputed.

(a)     17 June 2024 was Hari Raya Haji. On that day, the Husband’s mother had shared in a group chat an explicit photo of the Wife with another man. The members of the group chat are the Wife’s parents, the Husband and his mother.

(b)     The photo was recorded by a CCTV camera installed in the Flat’s master-bedroom.

(c)     Apart from the Wife, the Husband was the only person who had access to the CCTV recording.[note: 32]

Wife’s case

40     The Wife believed that the Husband (a) had forwarded the photo to his mother and (b) had caused the photo to be circulated on the group chat.

Husband’s case

41     The Husband denied having shared the photo to his mother.[note: 33] He also denied being involved in the photo’s circulation.

My decision

42     I agree with the Wife that the Husband was probably behind the circulation of the photo.

(a)      First, there were only two persons who had access to the CCTV recording that contained the photo – the Husband and the Wife. It is inconceivable that the Wife had provided the embarrassing photo of herself to the Husband’s mother. The only other person who could have done so is the Husband.

(b)      Second, the Husband had reasons to circulate the photo to the Wife and her parents.

(i)       At the material time, he was angry with the Wife for having committed adultery, and had no qualms about exposing the adultery to humiliate her. For instance, on 27 May 2024 (i.e., less than a month before the photo was circulated), the Husband had repeatedly offered to show “graphic evidence” to the Director to discredit the Wife.[note: 34] On 11 June 2024 (i.e., less than a week before the photo was circulated), the Husband’s lawyers had also written to the Wife’s lawyers to threaten to show “the CCTV footage of [her] sordid conduct, as evidence, at the appropriate juncture”.[note: 35]

(ii)       Importantly, at the time of the photo’s circulation, the Husband had not physically interacted with the Daughter for about two months. This is alluded to in the following message which accompanied the circulation of the photo: “... It’s been almost 2 months since we have seen our g...”

(c)      Finally, the Husband did not disapprove his mother’s act of circulating the photo.[note: 36]

43     In my view, the Husband had probably caused his mother to circulate the photo. He had done so to embarrass the Wife and to compel her to grant him physical access to the Daughter. By circulating the photo during the festive occasion of Hari Raya, the intention is clearly to cause maximum distress to the Wife and her parents. Such conduct is malicious and highly reprehensible.

Summing up

Family violence has been committed

44     To sum up, I find that the Husband had committed family violence against the Wife on two occasions – (a) 24 May 2024 and (b) 17 June 2024.

45     While a father’s anxiety and desire to see his daughter is understandable, what the Husband had done during these two incidents have crossed the line. These incidents show that he has no qualms in employing reprehensible means – such as mob tactics and circulating explicit photo – to harass and pressure the Wife into giving in to his demand to see his child.

46     I wish to emphasize one thing. Legal rights must be enforced through legal means – not through the commission of family violence. I find it particularly deplorable that the Husband and his relatives had seen it fit to cause a commotion at a playschool – which is supposed to be a safe place for young children. They have done so with blatant disregard for the alarm that their actions might cause to these children. This is simply not acceptable.

PPO necessary

47     In my view, a PPO is necessary to protect the Wife.

(a)     The two incidents of family violence were triggered by the Wife’s denial of the Husband’s physical access to the Daughter.

(b)     The parties have not been able to resolve the child issues between themselves amicably. This is evident from the fact that there are contested applications between them for custody, care and control, as well as access to the Daughter.

(c)     Given that the Daughter is still very young (only about three years old), it is likely that the parties will continue to have disagreements over her custody, care, control, and access in the coming years.

(d)     A PPO will serve to warn the Husband against committing family violence against the Wife to resolve such disagreements.

Husband’s application

Grounds for application

48     I will now turn to the Husband’s application. He relied on the following incidents for his PPO application.

 

Date

Location

To support application for –

(a)

10.09.23 2.25 pm

Flat

Daughter

(b)

11.09.23 12.50 pm

(c)

12.09.23 8.50 pm

(d)

11.04.24 7.35 pm

Parents’ Home



10 September 2023 – Vaping in the Daughter’s presence

49     I begin with the 10 September incident. It is not disputed that on that day, the Wife was recorded on CCTV to have been vaping in the bedroom with the Daughter lying next to her. The child was about 1½ years old at the material time.

Husband’s case

50     According to the Husband, the Wife had shown a “callous disregard” for the Daughter’s well-being by vaping in her presence. The Wife had continued her vaping habit even after leaving the Flat on 21 April 2024. To support this claim, the Husband relied on the undisputed fact that Health Sciences Authority (“HSA”) had found the Wife to be in possession of vaping devices on 18 May 2024 at the Parents’ Home.[note: 37] He is concerned that the Wife will continue to vape in the child’s presence.

Wife’s case

51     According to the Wife –

(a)     She was not aware that vaping besides the Daughter would be harmful to the child’s health.

(b)     In any event, she had since stopped the vaping habit and had surrendered all the paraphernalia to HSA.

(c)     The Husband had reported her vaping habit to the Ministry of Social and Family Development. Following the complaint, officers from the Child Protection Services (“CPS”) had visited her at her Parents’ Home on 23 May 2024. On 27 May 2024, CPS informed her that they had closed the matter without the need for a safety plan to be implemented.[note: 38]

My decision

52     During the hearing, the issue of whether the Wife’s act of vaping in the Daughter’s presence was harmful to the child was hotly contested. Both parties however did not produce clear and unequivocal expert evidence on this issue.

53     Assuming that the issue is answered in the affirmative, I find that there is no necessity for a PPO to be issued against the Wife over her vaping habit.

(a)      First, the Husband had produced evidence of only one instance where the Wife had vaped in the child’s presence. That incident occurred about 18 months ago. There is no other evidence that the Wife had vaped in the Daughter’s presence on other occasions.

(b)      Second, the parties have been living apart since April 2024. As such, the Husband has no evidential basis to contend that the Wife “is still in possession of vaping devices or could easily purchase them online and use them in [the Daughter’s] presence”.[note: 39] Such a contention is based on pure conjecture.

(c)      Finally, I note that following the Husband’s complaint about the Wife’s vaping habit, CPS had visited the Parents’ Home, interviewed the Wife, and examined the Daughter’s living environment. CPS had assessed that it is not necessary to take any further action to protect the child. There is no basis for me to reject this assessment.

11 September 2023 – Throwing the Daughter on the bed

54     Next, I turn to the 11 September incident.

Husband’s case

55     The Husband’s claim that the Wife had committed family violence is based on a recording from his CCTV camera in a bedroom in the Flat. (The Husband was not at home at the material time.) According to him, the recording shows that at about 12.50 pm, the Wife had handled the Daughter in a rough manner – by “throwing” her on the bed and thus causing her to “bounce” backward on the bed and to land on her head.[note: 40]

Wife’s case

56     The Wife denied having intentionally or knowingly caused hurt to the Daughter. According to the Wife, she was merely engaging in horseplay with the child at the material time.[note: 41]

My decision

57     I find that the Wife did not commit family violence as alleged by the Husband. The following is clear from the recording –

(a)     The Wife did not throw the Daughter on the bed. She had simply placed the child in the middle of the bed.

(b)     There were two pillows on the bed. They had been positioned to form a layer of protection around the child. This suggests that the Wife had taken steps to ensure the Daughter’s safety while the latter was on the bed.

(c)     After being placed on the bed, the Daughter bent her body backwards on her own. She did not “bounce” backwards from the impact of being forcefully placed on the bed.

(d)     After bending backwards, the Daughter’s head and part of her upper body landed on a pillow. There is no evidence that she was hurt or had cried at the material time.

12 September 2023 – Pulling the Daughter’s legs

58     I now turn to the next incident which is also based on a CCTV recording. The incident occurred in the bedroom on 12 September 2023. Similarly, the Husband was not at home at the material time. The recording shows the Wife and the Daughter on the bed, and the latter crying.

Husband’s case

59     According to the Husband, the Daughter was crying because the Wife had exerted excessive force on the child by pulling her legs back and forth.[note: 42]

Wife’s case

60     The Wife denied the Husband’s allegations. According to her, the Daughter was crying due to discomfort from constipation. The Wife explained that she was “rotating” the child’s legs – a home remedy – at the material time to relieve the child of her discomfort.

My decision

61     The Husband has the burden to prove that the Wife had intentionally or knowingly caused hurt to the Daughter by pulling or rotating the child’s legs. In my view, the Husband had failed to discharge his burden of proof.

(a)      First, the Wife’s evidence that the Daughter was crying due to discomfort from constipation – and not from her moving the child’ legs – is plausible. This is because the Husband had confirmed that the Daughter had constipation.[note: 43] He was not at home during the incident. As such, he has no basis to dispute the Wife’s evidence that the child was suffering from constipation at the material time.

(b)      Second, the Wife’s explanation that she was trying to relieve the child of her discomfort from constipation is consistent with the evidence.

(i)       In the video recording (exhibit R3), the Wife can be seen calmly massaging the child’s stomach and patiently moving her legs at the material time.

(ii)       The Husband had confirmed that to relieve the Daughter of constipation, he would practice home remedies such as “rotating the legs”[note: 44] and “massaging the stomach”.[note: 45]

(iii)       Even when the Daughter was struggling and pushing against the Wife, the latter was not rough with the child.

(iv)       The recording does not show the Wife to be angry or frustrated with the Daughter at the material time.

(c)      Finally, if the Wife had wanted to cause hurt to the Daughter, she would have done so in a more direct way, e.g., by pinching or hitting the child. There is no evidence of this in the recording.

11 April 2024 – Mark on the Daughter’s leg

62     I now come to the final incident relied by the Husband for his PPO application. This concerns a mark found on the Daughter’s leg at around 7.30 pm on 11 April 2024.[note: 46]

Husband’s case

63     According to the Husband, the mark was not on the Daughter’s leg earlier that day. He had noticed it only after the child spent the day with the Wife. When questioned, the Wife explained that it was an insect bite. The Husband decided to apply some cream over the mark. The next day, the condition of the mark had worsened. According to the Husband, it became filled with pus and blood was oozing out. When he brought the Daughter to a doctor on 13 April 2024, the Daughter kept mentioning the words “pain” and “fire”. The Husband suspected that the mark was a burn mark and caused by the Wife’s smoking and vaping habit.[note: 47]

Wife’s case

64     The Wife denied having caused the mark on the Daughter’s leg. She had discovered the mark, which looked like an insect bite, when changing the child’s diapers in the morning of 11 April 2024.[note: 48] According to the Wife, the words “fire” and “pain” were beyond the vocabulary of the Daughter, who was about two years old at the material time.[note: 49]

My decision

65     To succeed in his PPO application, the Husband must prove the following:

(a)     That the mark on the Daughter’s leg – as shown in the Wife’s affidavit dated 3 July 2024 (in relation to SS 879/2024) at page 52 (“11 April photo”) – was not caused by an insect bite.

(b)     That the mark must have been a burn mark caused by the Wife from her smoking or vaping.

(c)     That the Wife must have caused the mark intentionally or knowingly.

(d)     That a PPO is necessary to prevent the Wife from causing further physical harm to the Daughter.

66     In my view, the Husband has failed to prove the above on a balance of probabilities.

(a)      First, there is no medical opinion on whether the mark found on the Daughter’s leg on 11 April 2024 was caused by an insect bite or a burn mark. All that is stated in the doctor’s memo is that the child had a 1 cm x 1 cm erosion with surrounding 2 cm skin induration that was erythematous. The memo also stated that there was no pus or discharge at the time of examination.

(b)      Second, I have no basis to find that the mark was not caused by an insect bite.

(i)       Looking at the 11 April photo, the mark is consistent with an insect bite.

(ii)       According to the Wife, it was “pretty normal” for the Daughter to be bitten by insects.[note: 50] The Husband did not dispute this piece of evidence during the hearing.

(c)      Third, the Wife had proactively alerted the Husband to the mark on 11 April 2024. It is unlikely that she would have done so if she had burnt the Daughter.

(d)      Further, the Husband has failed to show why the Wife would want to intentionally or knowingly burn the child.

(e)      Finally, assuming that the Daughter did utter the words “fire” and “pain” (this is hotly contested by the Wife), this does not prove that the Wife had burnt the child’s leg.

(i)       It is conceivable that the child might have been describing how the pain felt – i.e., like being burned – instead of stating that “fire” was the cause of the pain.

(ii)       It also bears highlighting that the Daughter had allegedly mentioned the words “fire” and “pain” at the doctor’s office on 13 April 2024.[note: 51] This is two days after the discovery of the mark. In the time between the discovery of the mark and the visit to the doctor’s office, both the Husband and the Wife had applied medicinal cream to the mark. According to the Husband, one day after he had applied the cream, pus and blood started oozing from it. In the circumstances, I cannot exclude the possibility that the medicinal cream and the subsequent worsening of the condition of the mark had caused the Daughter to feel the sensation of fire on her leg.

Summing up

67     To sum up – I find that the Husband has failed to prove that the Wife had committed family violence against the Daughter.

Conclusion

68     For the above reasons, I granted the Wife’s application for a PPO for herself and dismissed the rest of the PPO applications by the parties.

69     I order that the Husband is not to use family violence in any form against the Wife.

(a)     The PPO shall take immediate effect and shall last until the Daughter turns 21. In other words, the order will expire one day before XX March 2043.

(b)     In determining the duration of the PPO, I have considered (i) the applicable principles (see XEF v XEG [2024] SGFC 92 at [43]) and (ii) the fact that child-related issues were the trigger for the Husband’s commission of family violence. Such issues are likely to persist so long as the parties can exercise parental rights over the Daughter: see [47(c)] above.

(c)     I wish to emphasise to the Husband a few things. First, it is an offence to contravene the order that I have made. Second, if the Husband were to intentionally contravene the order, he can be arrested and be punished with a fine and/or imprisonment. Finally, for the sake of his Daughter, I urge the Husband to resolve any future disagreement that he may have with the Wife calmly and through legal means.

70     Finally, I come to the issue of costs. The Wife has succeeded in one of her PPO applications while the Husband has failed in his. In my view, a costs order of $3,000 in favour of the Wife is proportionate to the amount of work and effort expended on litigating the family violence committed on 26 April 2024 and 17 June 2024. I make this cost order accordingly.
