Decision Date:17 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Phang Hsiao Chung
Counsel Name(s): Applicant in person; Ms Ong Ying Ting Eunice (Netto & Magin LLC) for the respondent.
Parties: XJZ — XKA

Family Law – Divorce – Setting aside of consent orders – Division of matrimonial assets – Maintenance of spouse – Maintenance of children

17 March 2025

District Judge Phang Hsiao Chung:

Introduction

1       This is an application by a former husband (the “Husband”) against his former wife (the “Wife”) for:

(a)     the Certificate of Final Judgment (Divorce) in FC/D 1265/2024 (the “Certificate of Final Judgment”) to be set aside in its entirety;

(b)     clauses 3(c) to 3(g) of the Interim Judgment in FC/D 1265/2024 (the “Interim Judgment”) to be set aside in their entirety;

(c)     a Case Conference to be fixed in FC/D 1265/2024 for directions to be given to the parties to file and exchange their affidavits of assets and means; and

(d)     the Wife to pay the Husband the costs of these proceedings.

Facts

The parties

2       The Husband and the Wife are both professionals in the same industry. The Husband holds a senior appointment in a multinational corporation, where he manages around 70 personnel, and with them collectively generate an annual revenue of about US$39 million.

3       The parties have 2 sons (collectively, the “children”), who were born in 2007 and 2010.

Background to the dispute

4       In FC/D 1265/2024, the Wife was granted an Interim Judgment on 4 April 2024 on the ground that the marriage has irretrievably broken down by reason that the Husband has behaved in such a way that the Wife cannot reasonably be expected to live with the Husband. The Interim Judgment was made final when the Certificate of Final Judgment was issued on 8 July 2024.

5       Clauses 3(c) to 3(g) of the Interim Judgment were orders on divorce ancillary matters that were made by consent. Clause 3(c) relates to the division of the matrimonial home. Clause 3(d) relates to the division of other matrimonial assets, including a property in Singapore, 2 properties in London, monies standing to the credit of the parties in their Central Provident Fund (“CPF”) accounts, monies in various bank accounts, stocks and shares held by the parties in their sole names, and monies from Treasury Bills and fixed deposits. Clause 3(e) relates to spousal maintenance for the Wife, and the giving to the Wife of 50% of the bonus and shares allocated to the Husband for his performance in 2023. Clause 3(f) relates to maintenance for the children, annual contributions by the Husband to the Wife’s joint account with the children, and the nomination of the children as beneficiaries of the parties’ life insurance policies and CPF monies. Clause 3(g) relates to the following matters: (a) payment by the Husband to the Wife of a monthly sum for household expenses; (b) the parties’ agreed mechanism for varying the amounts of spousal maintenance, child maintenance, and household expenses, if there is a “permanent change” of the Husband’s employment; (c) the provision of a 3.5% “inflationary adjustment” every year for the amount of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses; (d) the repayment by the Husband to the Wife of an amount withdrawn from the parties’ joint account; and (e) the Husband’s sole liability for all personal loans taken in his own name.

6       Under the consent orders, the Husband agreed to pay the Wife spousal maintenance of $7,500 every month from January 2024 to January 2034 (or until the Husband’s official retirement, whichever is later), $3,400 every month for the maintenance of the children from January 2024 until the children completed their university education, and $3,800 every month for household expenses from January 2024 to January 2032, with these amounts to increase by 3.5% every year (unless otherwise agreed between the parties). In addition, the Husband agreed to make an annual contribution of $100,000 to the Wife’s joint account with the children for 5 years, from 2024 to 2028 (both years inclusive).

The parties’ cases

7       The Husband’s case is set out in detail in his affidavit filed in support of the application, and summarised in his oral submissions. The Husband seeks to set aside the Certificate of Final Judgment, and clauses 3(c) to 3(g) of the Interim Judgment, on the ground that “the clauses impose unfair and unjust terms that have a negative impact on [him], which [he] did not fully understand at the point of consenting, due to the pressure put on [him] by the [Wife] to sign the divorce papers”. The Husband added that he “did not have the benefit of legal advice at the material time” as he was “self-representing / acting in person”.

8       According to the Husband, throughout the marriage, he had been the “primary financial contributor to the family” and “paid for most of the family’s expenses”. His current job was fast paced, with long hours and significant responsibilities that often left him feeling overwhelmed by work commitments. The Wife took on “familial duties”, including “managing [the Husband’s] salary / income”, which the Husband paid into the parties’ joint bank account, and “using [the Husband’s] monies to pay for the family’s expenses and to make investments”. The Husband was given about $2,000 every month to pay for his personal expenses.

9       The Husband claimed that he signed the draft consent order on divorce ancillary matters “without seeking legal help or advice” due to pressure from the Wife and “overwhelming stress ... at work”. According to the Husband, the Wife “pushed [him] to sign the documents in a rushed manner”, despite the Husband informing her many times that he needed more time to review them and come to a decision, especially with his heavy workload and stress. Due to pressure and threats by the Wife, the Husband “only focused on the key aspects, such as the Joint Custody of [the] children and the access [he] had with them”. As for the other orders, the Husband “did not have sufficient time and / or the capacity to fully understand what [he] was signing”.

10     The Husband provided the following elaboration.

(a)     When the Husband consented to the terms of the draft consent order, he was “extremely affected by the fact that the marriage was ending on a bad note”, and was “extremely worried and concerned about the impact this would have on the Children”. He wanted to resolve the matter amicably without involving lawyers, and trusted the Wife to be cooperative, fair and reasonable.

(b)     The Wife had “made threats during the negotiations that, if [the Husband] did not agree to her terms, she would go on to expose the Third Party and name / involve the Third Party in the Divorce proceedings”. This “Third Party”, with whom the Husband had an extramarital affair, was a woman “of a certain seniority” in his industry. The Husband was concerned that the Wife’s exposure of the Third Party would “cause major reputational loss” to the Third Party and to him. To ensure that the Third Party “does not get pulled into [the parties’] divorce proceedings”, and that the jobs of the Husband and the Third Party “don’t end up being at stake”, the Husband signed the draft consent order “despite not completely agreeing to its terms and without fully understanding the implications it will have on [him]”.

(c)     The Wife also threatened to deny the Husband access to the children, when he made counterproposals during the negotiations.

(d)     The Husband was “under tremendous pressure at work and felt overwhelmed”.

(e)     Collectively, these issues “weighed heavily on [the Husband’s] mind and clouded [his] judgment”.

11     The Husband also claimed that “due to [his] lack of expertise in the management of the funds used for the family expenses, [he] was unaware of the various costs associated with living on [his] own”, and underestimated his living expenses. The Husband claimed that after paying off his monthly expenses and the amounts payable to the Wife pursuant to the Interim Judgment, the Husband was “in a deficit” and “financially drained”. The Husband also stated that he had “little to no savings” to allocate towards commitments such as purchasing a home, saving for retirement and managing his health, despite working long hours.

12     The Husband claimed that the consent orders were unfair to him, having regard to his larger direct financial contributions to the matrimonial assets. He also claimed that the Respondent was a capable and well-paid individual who earned close to $300,000 a year, and therefore did not require the the amount of spousal maintenance that she demanded. He wanted the Wife to bear part of the children’s maintenance and household expenses. He also stated that the yearly inflationary adjustment was not sustainable, as he was reaching the ceiling of his career and was unlikely to have any significant salary increments.

13     In the Wife’s affidavit in reply, the Wife gave details of the breakdown of the marriage and the negotiations that followed. The Wife claimed that the negotiations were fair, and that she had acted reasonably in the negotiations.

14     However, the Wife also admitted to intentionally making things difficult for the Husband by suggesting that she would name the Third Party as a co-defendant in the divorce. It was clear from the Wife’s evidence on the negotiations that the Wife knew of the Husband’s desire to keep the Third Party out of the divorce proceedings, and the Wife used this to her advantage in the negotiations.

15     The Wife denied withholding access to the children, or using the children as a bargaining tool. She explained that the discussion relied on by the Husband took place when she “was still trying to recover and heal, and [she] genuinely could not bring [herself] to communicate with him about the children”. I think there is some truth to this statement, as the Husband did not raise any issue in relation to the consent orders in the Interim Judgment on custody, care and control of, and access to, the children.

16     In relation to the Husband’s suggestion that he could not afford the monthly payments for maintenance and household expenses, the Wife claimed that the Husband’s monthly income was between $30,000 and $40,000, and his annual income (presumably including bonuses) was between $600,000 and $700,000.

Application to set aside the Certificate of Final Judgment

17     The Husband’s application to set aside the Certificate of Final Judgment was bound to fail. As observed by Choo Han Teck J in VQB v VQC [2021] SGHCF 5 at [14] and [16]:

(a)     In a divorce case, the Final Judgment dissolves the marriage, and the status of the parties as a married couple is brought to a permanent and unsalvageable end. Once the Final Judgment is made, the marriage is at a permanent end and cannot be reinstated.

(b)     The Women’s Charter 1961 makes no provision for setting aside a Final Judgment. The only conceivable exception is when the Final Judgment was obtained by fraud; but even then, it may have to be a fraud that taints the Final Judgment itself, such as a forgery of the order of court.

(c)     Setting up the Interim Judgment for attack is futile once the Final Judgment is made. To hold that a Final Judgment may be rescinded if the Interim Judgment was flawed is to create a legal fiction. The reliefs and remedies for obtaining a flawed Interim Judgment lie elsewhere than to pretend that the Final Judgment has no effect.

18     In any case, the Husband’s complaint lies not with the granting of the divorce, but with the terms of the consent order on divorce ancillary matters. The Husband affirmed the Interim Judgment for divorce by asking for a Case Conference to be fixed for directions to be given to the parties to file and exchange their affidavits of assets and means.

Application to set aside clauses 3(c) and 3(d) of the Interim Judgment

19     Clauses 3(c) and 3(d) of the Interim Judgment were consent orders dealing with the division of matrimonial assets.

20     Section 112 of the Women’s Charter 1961 deals with the power of the court to order the division of matrimonial assets. Under section 112(4), the court may, at any time it thinks fit, extend, vary, revoke or discharge any order made under section 112, and may vary any term or condition upon or subject to which any such order has been made.

21     In AYM v AYL [2012] SGCA 68; [2013] 1 SLR 924, the Court of Appeal made the following observations at [11], [12], [15], [22], [23], [25] and [27] to [30]:

(a)     Section 112(4) does not furnish the court with a carte blanche to vary an order on division of matrimonial assets. There must be exceptional reasons before such variation can be effected. There must be some finality once the matrimonial assets have been divided between the parties. Section 112(4) must have a limited operation only, especially when the order of court made under section 112 is premised upon a consent order entered into between the parties themselves.

(b)     Once the order of court with respect to the division of matrimonial assets has been completely implemented or spent (inasmuch as everything that is required to be done has been effected and the assets concerned have in fact been distributed to the parties concerned), the court does not have the power to revisit or reopen the order. Section 112(4) was included to give administrative flexibility to the court so long as the order it has made has not been completely effected or implemented. The court would make the necessary variations to an order for the division of matrimonial assets only where the order was unworkable or has become unworkable (before it has been fully effected or implemented).

(c)     Where an order becomes unworkable (in that it is a matter of practical impossibility to implement it), it is fair and reasonable that the court is empowered under section 112(4) to make the necessary variations. There will also be (albeit extremely limited) circumstances in which unworkability, understood in a substantive as well as purposive sense, will justify a variation of the order by the court. Where new circumstances have emerged since the order was made, which so radically change the situation so that to implement the order as originally made would be to implement something that is radically different from what was originally intended, this would amount to unworkability, and the court would make the necessary variations to deal with such unworkability. Another instance of a radical change in circumstances amounting to unworkability may arise after the court makes an order under section 112 that is of a continuing nature. Where there has been a change in circumstances invalidating the very basis on which the court made a continuing order, this amounts to a radical change in circumstances amounting to unworkability, and the court will be empowered to make the necessary variation (or indeed, extension, revocation or discharge) under section 112(4) to deal with such a change. The view that a material change in the circumstances would suffice to trigger a variation under section 112(4) sets too low a threshold.

(d)     Section 112(4) may also be invoked to vary an order for the division of matrimonial assets where such order was unworkable to begin with. Any ab initio substantive unworkability must be a result of a fundamental misunderstanding apparent on the face of the order.

(e)     One other situation that might justify varying an order for the division of matrimonial assets, even after the order concerned has been implemented, is fraud. The standard of proof for fraud is a very high one.

22     The Court of Appeal provided the following elaboration on the fraud exception in BMI v BMJ and another matter [2017] SGCA 63; [2018] 1 SLR 43 at [3] and [5]:

(a)     As the court has no power to vary an order for the division of matrimonial assets that has been fully implemented, except in the limited case of fraud, any non-disclosure that was not fraudulent would not furnish a basis to set aside a consent order for the division of matrimonial assets.

(b)     The fact that the consent order has been fully implemented and the subsequent lapse of time are not factors which would, by themselves, prevent the court from intervening on the basis of section 112(4) if there was cogent evidence of fraudulent and material non-disclosure.

(c)     The threshold for establishing fraud is a high one which will not be met unless there is cogent and compelling evidence.

23     None of the reasons given by the Husband for seeking to set aside clauses 3(c) and 3(d) of the Interim Judgment fell within the ambit of section 112(4) of the Women’s Charter 1961, as explained by the Court of Appeal in AYM v AYL and in BMI v BMJ and another matter. The consent orders for division of matrimonial assets were clearly workable. In fact, at the time of the hearing, some of those orders had already been implemented, while others were in the process of being implemented. There was no evidence of fraud or fraudulent non-disclosure by the Wife in relation to the obtaining of the consent orders. While the Husband’s desire to keep the Third Party out of the divorce proceedings, and the pressures experienced by the Husband at work, may have given the Wife an upper hand in the negotiation of the terms of the consent orders, those matters did not in any way affect the validity of those consent orders. It follows that the Husband’s application to set aside clauses 3(c) and 3(d) of the Interim Judgment must be dismissed.

Application to set aside clauses 3(e) to 3(g) of the Interim Judgment

24     Clauses 3(e) and 3(f) of the Interim Judgment were consent orders dealing with maintenance for the Wife and maintenance for the children, respectively. Clause 3(g)(i), (ii) and (iii) was a consent order that provided for, among other things, the following matters: (a) payment by the Husband to the Wife of a monthly sum for household expenses; (b) the parties’ agreed mechanism for varying the amounts of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses, if there is a “permanent change” of the Husband’s employment; and (c) the provision of a 3.5% “inflationary adjustment” every year for the amount of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses.

25     Section 118 of the Women’s Charter 1961 provides for the power of the court to vary (or rescind) an order for spousal maintenance granted during matrimonial proceedings. Under section 118, the court may at any time vary or rescind any such order for spousal maintenance “where it is satisfied that the order was based on any misrepresentation or mistake of fact or where there has been any material change in the circumstances”.

26     Sections 72 and 127(2) of the Women’s Charter 1961, read together, provide for the power of the court to rescind or vary an order for child maintenance granted during matrimonial proceedings. Under those provisions, the court may rescind or vary the order for child maintenance “on proof of a change in the circumstances” of the parent ordered to pay the maintenance, or of the child receiving the maintenance, or “for other good cause being shown to the satisfaction of the court”. In considering any such application, the court may take into consideration any change in the general cost of living which may have occurred between the date of the making of the order sought to be varied and the date of the hearing of the application.

27     I begin with the following preliminary observations:

(a)     The order for payment by the Husband to the Wife of a monthly sum for household expenses may be construed as a supplementary order for a combination of spousal maintenance and child maintenance. It is open to the parties to agree to supplement the primary orders for spousal maintenance and child maintenance with an order for the payment of the whole or a part of the household expenses that would have been incurred for the maintenance of the Wife and the children.

(b)     Although the parties may have agreed on a mechanism for varying the amounts of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses, that agreement did not oust the application of the relevant statutory provisions on spousal maintenance and child maintenance. Clause 3(g)(ii) of the Interim Judgment only applies in a case where there is a “permanent change” of the Husband’s employment. It did not prevent the Husband from applying to vary the amounts of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses, in reliance on section 118, and section 72 read with section 127(2), of the Women’s Charter 1961, in any other case.

28     The Husband did not point to any specific misrepresentation by the Wife, or any mistake of fact (whether by himself, by the Wife or by both of them), that would justify a recission or variation of the consent order on spousal maintenance. There was also no evidence of any material change in the circumstances (whether of the Husband, the Wife or the children), between the date of the Interim Judgment (4 April 2024) and the date of the hearing of the Husband’s application (28 February 2025), that would justify a variation in the agreed amounts of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses. As mentioned in the context of the Husband’s unsuccessful attempt to set aside the consent orders on the division of matrimonial assets, while the Husband’s desire to keep the Third Party out of the divorce proceedings, and the pressures experienced by the Husband at work, may have given the Wife an upper hand in the negotiation of the terms of the consent orders, those matters did not in any way affect the validity of those consent orders. It follows that the Husband’s application to set aside clauses 3(e), 3(f) and 3(g)(i), (ii) and (iii) of the Interim Judgment must likewise be dismissed.

29     Clause 3(g)(iv) and (v) of the Interim Judgment were consent orders for: (a) the repayment by the Husband to the Wife of an amount withdrawn from the parties’ joint account; and (b) the Husband to be solely liable for all personal loans taken in his own name. None of the parties’ submissions were directed at clause 3(g)(iv) and (v). As there did not appear to be any basis to set aside clause 3(g)(iv) and (v), the Husband’s application to set aside clause 3(g)(iv) and (v) of the Interim Judgment is dismissed.

30     While I have declined to set aside the consent orders in relation to the payment of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses, I do not discount the possibility that the amounts payable for those matters, when increased by 3.5% each year, may at some time in the future be unsustainable on the Husband’s income. To illustrate how this may happen, in 2024, the total amount payable by the Husband each month under clause 3(e), 3(f) and 3(g)(i) of the Interim Judgment was $14,700 (comprising $7,500 for spousal maintenance, $3,400 for child maintenance and $3,800 for household expenses). This will increase to $15,214.50 per month in 2025, $15,747.01 per month in 2026, $16,298.15 per month in 2027, and 16,868.59 per month in 2028. I therefore clarify that if the monthly payments become so large as to be unsustainable on the Husband’s income, or there is any other material change in the circumstances of the Husband, the Wife or the children or any other good cause, my dismissal of the Husband’s application to set aside clauses 3(e), 3(f) and 3(g)(i) of the Interim Judgment does not preclude the Husband from applying, under the relevant statutory provisions, to vary the consent orders for payment of spousal maintenance, child maintenance and household expenses.

Conclusion

31     In the circumstances, the Husband’s application is dismissed. As a consequence of the dismissal of the Husband’s applications to set aside the Certificate of Final Judgment and clauses 3(c) to 3(g) of the Interim Judgment, the Husband’s remaining prayers for the fixing of a Case Conference and for costs are also dismissed.

32     The Wife’s solicitor sought costs of $5,000 all in, inclusive of filing fees totalling $303.90. The Husband’s 59 page affidavit had 20 pages of text, while the Wife’s 127 page affidavit had 22 pages of text. The hearing of the Originating Application lasted about an hour. All things considered, I order the Husband to pay the Wife costs of the application fixed at $1,800 (all in).

XJS v XJT

XJS v XJT
[2025] SGFC 27

Case Number:Divorce No 1582 of 2023
Decision Date:12 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kenneth Yap
Counsel Name(s): Ms Lee Mong Jen and Mr Yeo Yang (LMJ Law Corporation) for the plaintiff; Mr Gopalakrishnan Dinagaran (Prestige Legal LLP) for the defendant.
Parties: XJS — XJT

Family law – Matrimonial Assets – Division

Family Law – Maintenance – Wife

Family Law – Maintenance – Child

12 March 2025

District Judge Kenneth Yap:

1       These are my brief grounds of decision for the ancillary matters (“AM”) in D 1582/2023. The Plaintiff Wife is referred to as “PW” and the Defendant Husband as “DH”.

Background

2       The issues in dispute are:

(a)     Division of Matrimonial Assets

(b)     Spousal maintenance, and maintenance for the younger child (“PTK”). Maintenance for the older child (“KS”), had been agreed on 15 Dec 2023, with each party to pay AUD$1,400 and S$150 monthly w.e.f. 15 Dec 2023, with the last payment on 1 Jun 2024.

3       Parties are agreed that there would be joint custody of PTK, with care and control to the Wife, and the Husband having reasonable access.

4       The affidavits provided for the ancillary matters hearing are as follows:

Affidavits:

2.     DAM-1 (22 Feb 2024)

7.     Helper’s Affidavit (7 Oct 2024)

B. Division of Matrimonial Property

Parties keep their respective gratuities and bonuses.

C. Maintenance for the Spouse/Children

Parties’ positions

PW: Child maintenance from DH of A$4,904 per month, representing 70% of total expenses for PTK.

(Monthly Income: $9,630.66 (gross), $7,946 (nett)

DH: Maintenance for PTK to be equally divided, so long as expenses are accompanied with proof.

(Monthly Income: $11,488.06 (gross), $9,779.44 (nett) (based on NOA 2022 to 2023 and File Form B1 for YA 2024).

(Total nett monthly income = $17,725.44)

(Children’s Monthly Expenses: A4,904 monthly for PTK)

D. Costs

Parties’ positions

PW: (not mentioned)

DH: Each party to bear own costs.



Division of Matrimonial Pool

5       For a dual-income marriage, the structured approach for the division of matrimonial assets as established in ANJ v ANK [2015] 4 SLR 1043 would be applicable. This approach involves the following steps:

(a)     Determine the total matrimonial pool in accordance with s 112 of the Women’s Charter (1961) by aggregating the jointly held matrimonial assets, as well as assets held in each party’s name.

(b)     Determine the parties’ direct financial contributions towards the acquisition or improvement of the matrimonial assets.

(c)     Express as a second ratio the parties’ indirect contributions to the well-being of the family, considering both financial and non-financial contributions.

(d)     Derive the parties’ overall contributions by averaging the two ratios, with possible adjustments based on the circumstances of the case.

Determination of Matrimonial Pool

6       There was no dispute that the matrimonial pool should be identified at the time of interim judgment (per Court of Appeal’s decision in BPC v BPB and another appeal [2019] 1 SLR 608, referencing ARY v ARX [2016] 2 SLR 686), and valued at the nearest date to the ancillary hearing, save for bank account and CPF monies, the value of which are determined at the time of the interim judgment.

7       Parties however disputed the inclusion of several items into the matrimonial pool.

8       First, parties disagree on the inclusion of the Husband’s HUS Invest Funds, which are an employment gratuity paid upon retirement from the police force at the age of 56. The Husband’s argument that the HUS Invest Funds should be excluded because the Wife had received and spent her entitlements under the Connect Plan (a reward scheme for teachers under the Ministry of Education) is not legally valid. The HUS Invest Funds are a chose in action and therefore have an asset worth which can be valued at the ancillary hearing. The latest valuation provided by the Husband is as at 1 April 2024, in the sum of $202,047.82. The Wife sought to extrapolate the estimated increase in value as at January 2025. I instead directed the Husband to provide the latest statement to adopt the most accurate value, which was provided during the hearing as $219,799.83, based on a statement dated September 2024.

9       Second, the Husband makes a further argument that the Wife’s Connect Plan received payments over the years have been dissipated by her, and that the correct treatment should be the return of such funds to the matrimonial pool. However, I agree with counsel for the Wife that there is no legal basis for alleging dissipation when the divorce was not imminent. The divorce application was filed on 6 April 2023, and the Wife had explained that the monies had been spent over the years on family expenses and the purchase of the matrimonial home. I would not therefore require the Wife to refund any component of the spent monies to the matrimonial pool.

10     Third, regarding bank balances, as these should be valued at the time of the interim judgment, the Husband’s transfers of $8,000 to his sister’s bank account on 16 October and 15 November 2023 respectively should not be taken into account, as it is stated by his sister that the sums are for expenses incurred from October 2023 to February 2025, which are expenses post-interim judgment. Accordingly, the valuation of the Husband’s bank accounts should be taken at the time of interim judgment.

11     Fourth, with regard to insurance policies, the Wife claims that there were three insurance policies taken out by the Husband for the benefit of the children which had matured during the marriage but were not accounted, and which should be added back into the asset pool. The details of these three policies are as follows:

Parties also agreed that the insurance policies paid to PTK would be utilised towards her outstanding student loan incurred in the sum of $34,500 as at September 2024. Indirect Contributions

21     The Husband submitted for a 50-50 ratio for indirect contributions at the hearing, noting that the Mother had a helper who contributed towards the management of the household and raising of the children. The Wife’s position was that indirect contributions should be 75-25 in her favour.

22     The Wife contended that her indirect financial contributions had been consistent, substantial, and regular. Given the Husband's frequent travel during much of the marriage, she bore the primary financial responsibility for maintaining the household of six, paying for all essential and incidental expenses. These included consistent and significant contribution to the matrimonial properties throughout the marriage, which including taking out two staff renovation loans (which she repaid monthly), along with town council charges and utility bills. She also purchased household equipment which benefited the household, took on personal credit loans to meet the family’s needs, and stepped in as guarantor to her daughter’s university study loan. Finally, she also covered much of the daily household expenses, including service charges, utilities, groceries, dining out, cultural and festive expenses, children’s expenses such as pocket money, food, groceries, medical consultation and treatments, and the salary as well as agent fees for the family’s domestic helper. With regard to KS’s overseas education in Gold Coast, Australia, the Wife stated that she had financed the travel to Australia to facilitate her son’s settlement into the university, paying for part of the air tickets, car rental charges, Airbnb accommodation, and food expenses incurred by KS and herself during the trip, which amounted to a sum of $3,227.96. She also paid for other holiday trips and travel expenses during the course of the marriage.

Maintenance

35     The Wife submitted that at present, she provides $4,691.09 towards PTK’s monthly expenses, while the Husband provides $1,460.79. She submits that going forward, the Husband should pay 70% of monthly expenses for PTK, which is estimated at A$4,904 once PTK attends university in Brisbane, Australia. It was explained that the Husband should bear a higher proportion of maintenance going forward as he had under-provided during the earlier years, and the Wife also has medical issues for which she has to incur expenditure in the coming years.

36     The Wife also asks for backdated maintenance of $19,449.82 from April 2023 to October 2024, and a monthly sum of $653.20 thereafter each month from November 2024 to the date of hearing. This is because she had to shift out to her sister’s residence, on account of the Husband’s alleged family violence, and PTK wanted to move out as well (see paragraph 139 of PAM-2). This sum was adjusted at hearing to $20,749.82, as counsel for the Wife had omitted to include the cost of clothes and shoes from the month of October 2023.

37     As for the mode of payment towards PTK’s expenses, the Wife proposed that this be by way of direct transfer from the Husband to PTK, so she would not have to chase for payments. For big-ticket items for which she had paid in advance, the Wife would seek reimbursement after submitting the relevant receipt.

38     Finally, the Wife also sought spousal maintenance for a period of 12 months to allow her to transition and get her finances in order, should the Court not be prepared to grant her backdated maintenance, as she had spent nearly all of her money paying for the family’s expenses.

39     With regard to backdated maintenance, the Husband disputed the sum of $4,691.09 as representative of PTK’s monthly expenses. Specifically, he disputed her half-share of household expenses in the sum of $1,172.62, and objected to the following categories of items, which he said should only be reimbursed upon provision of proof of payment:

(a)     Special Moisturizer $177.12

(b)     Medical and Dental $175

(c)     Computer, mobile phone and digital $150

(d)     Scalp Treatment $156

(e)     Entertainment $100

(f)     School-related expenses $200

(g)     Clothes and shoes $200

(h)     Holidays $208

(i)     Massage recovery $340

40     I did not find that the Wife’s stated household expenses of $2,345.24, for which a half share of $1,172.62 was payable on PTK’s account, to be excessive. These included groceries ($500), wet market purchases ($200), domestic helper costs ($700), water utilities ($270), electricity utilities ($270) and MCST fee ($396.76). These appear to be normal household costs which I did not find to be unreasonable. As for the specific line items that are objected to subject to proof being provided, my views are as follows:

(a)     Special Moisturizer $177.12 – Evidence is provided in paragraph 84 of the Wife’s 2nd AOM affidavit (PAM-2).

(b)     Medical and Dental $175 – This is a reasonable figure and will not be adjusted.

(c)     Computer, mobile phone and digital $150 – this extrapolates to $1,800 a year for all digital devices, and is not adjusted as it appears to be reasonable for a polytechnic student.

(d)     Scalp Treatment $156 – Evidence is provided in paragraph 84 of Wife’s 2nd AOM affidavit (PAM-2).

(e)     Entertainment $100 – Not adjusted as this sum is reasonable.

(f)     School-related expenses $200 – Not adjusted as this sum is reasonable.

(g)     Clothes and shoes $200 – Adjusted downwards by $100.

(h)     Holidays $208 – this sum amounts to $2,496 a year, and is not unreasonable for expenditure on one or two holidays.

(i)     Massage recovery $340 – The Wife explains that these treatments are needed as PTK plays netball. The rate per session is $70, per page 411 of PAM-2. Husband’s position on this is that it should be $200 per month. I reduced this figure by $130 to $210 per month, on the basis that it would be fair to allow three sessions per month.

41     Applying these adjustments to the figures, the reduction of $50 for the Husband’s share of clothes and shoes applies across all 19 months from April 2023 to October 2024 (i.e. a reduction of $950). The reduction of $65 per month for the Husband’s share of massage recovery services applies for six months (from April 2023 to September 2023, as thereafter the Husband paid for his share of medical and massage costs on proof of receipt), and would amount to a reduction of $390. Accordingly, the total backdated maintenance should be reduced by $1,340, to a total of $19,409.82 for April 2023 to October 2024. For the months of November and December 2024, the Wife’s initial position was that the outstanding sum per month would be $653.20, which the Husband did not dispute. A further sum of $50 representing the Husband’s share of monthly expenses on clothing and shoes was added to this monthly figure, as the Wife’s counsel explained that this line item had been accidentally omitted from the Wife’s computation (the sum of $50 being half of the adjusted figure of $100 for clothing and shoes as explained above). Hence, I added $703.20 per month for November and December 2024, rendering the total backdated maintenance to be $20,816.22.

42     Turning to future maintenance, the Husband’s position was that he is willing to share PTK’s maintenance equally, subject to proof of expenditure, especially for accommodation, mobile phone and internet line, school related expenses and clothing for different seasons (see page 35 of the Husband’s Written Submissions). This was premised on his position that he retains the entirety of his HUS Invest Funds when he retires upon reaching 56 years of age (which he does so retain in view of the division of assets decided above). By contrast, as mentioned above, the Wife estimated the monthly maintenance to be A$4,904, based on a guide provided by the university as to living expenses for students in Brisbane, and asked that the Husband pay 70% of this sum.

43     Having considered the parties’ positions, I apportioned the share of maintenance payable by the husband as 55%, in direct proportion to the relative nett monthly income of the Husband and the Wife ($9,779.44 vs $7,946.00). However, as the Husband would reach the retirement age applicable to the police force at 57 years (i.e. 27 December 2026), I reduced his share to 50% effective from January 2027, in recognition of the fact that he would likely earn less in a post-retirement job.

44     As to the quantum of monthly maintenance for PTK, I did not find the Husband’s proposal that all expenses should be accompanied by proof to be reasonable or sustainable. It would be invidious and oppressive to require the daughter to come up with receipts for every single item of expenditure. Instead, I adjourned the hearing for parties to consider what a baseline cost would be, and for larger ticket items to be resolved in the proportion decided by the court upon proof of expenditure.

45     At the resumed hearing, parties updated that they agreed to the following baseline costs for PTK:

(a)     Allowance – A$400,

(b)     Laundry – A$64,

(c)     Mobile phone and internet line – A$35,

(d)     Toiletries – A$100, and

(e)     School related expenses – A$100.

46     Parties disagreed on the cost of food, transport and clothing. My decision on these items is as follows:

(a)     With regard to food, the Wife’s position was that the monthly cost should be A$1,568, as recommended by the student guide provided by the university. The Husband’s position was that this should be A$400, on the basis that breakfast is provided as part of the accommodation cost and that meals can be cooked. As breakfast is provided, I discounted the recommended monthly cost of food from A$1,578 to A$1,100.

(b)     With regard to transport, the Wife’s position was that this should be A$200, while the Husband claimed it should be A$100 as the accommodation is a ten minute walk from the school. I considered that public transportation to locations other than the school would be a necessity for a student, and apportioned this sum midway between the parties’ positions at A$150.

(c)     With regard to clothing, the Husband’s position was that this should be zero as he had already purchased sufficient clothing for the daughter (he noted that her course would end in June 2026), and any specific purchase should be claimed on a reimbursement basis. The Wife took the view that A$200 is a fair sum, and pointed out that it was she who had bought much of the daughter’s clothing. I allocated A$100 a month for smaller ticket purchases, with larger ticket clothing purchases to be claimed ad-hoc on a reimbursement basis.

47     Based on what I had determined and what parties had agreed to, the baseline monthly maintenance for PTK would be A$2,049. Other larger-ticket expenditure should be specifically claimed on a reimbursement basis, such as accommodation (fixed at A$1,556 for every 4 weeks, subject to adjustment if revised), as well as clothing, school related expenses in excess of what is specified in the baseline, airfare, furniture, furnishings, purchases of digital devices, costs of opening bank account, medical and dental expenses. These large-ticket expenses should be payable directly by the parents in the proportion I had specified above.

48     For the avoidance of doubt, the baseline maintenance is to continue even if the daughter is in Singapore for the holidays, given that that such periods are short and variable, and it would be difficult to compute the exact quantum of costs that would accrue to the daughter over such short periods. All payments are also to be made directly to PTK’s bank account.

49     Finally, no spousal maintenance is to be provided as the Wife had been working and was financially independent for the entire marriage.

Costs

50     I heard parties on costs subsequent to the delivery of my brief grounds. The Wife asked for costs on an indemnity basis at $20,000, on the basis that a without prejudice offer had been made to the Husband on 4 December 2023, after mediation and exchange of financial documents, which was less favourable in terms of the division percentage than what had been granted by this court. Counsel for the Wife argued that the matter had been protracted unnecessarily by the Husband, with the hearing of these ancillary proceedings spanning three sessions, and a total of 19 affidavits filed by both parties in the course of these proceedings.

51     Counsel for the Husband strenuously objected to any costs being ordered, and contended that parties could not agree because key items were outstanding and disputed, including the valuation of the matrimonial home. He also noted that additional affidavits from the domestic helper were filed at the last minute.

52     I considered parties’ submissions and noted that while the usual costs order in ancillary proceedings is for parties to bear their own costs, costs may nevertheless be ordered against a party who had been unreasonable and had caused delays and further costs to be incurred (WRX v WRY [2024] SGHC(A) 22, at [75]). In the present case, I took the view that the order of costs should be set at a level that would sufficiently instil discipline in proceedings and avoid unnecessary litigation. This case could have been resolved as far back as December 2023, when a more favourable without prejudice offer had been made to the Husband. Instead, the Husband chose to dispute individual line items and payments to a minutiae of detail, which added unnecessarily to the complexity and duration of these ancillary proceedings. It also bears noting that the Wife prevailed on a significantly greater number of contested issues in these proceedings than the Husband. For these reasons, I ordered the Husband to pay costs to the Wife, fixed at $10,000 (all-in).

5.    The Motor Vehicle bearing motor registration No. SLE XXXX (the "Motor Vehicle") shall be sold on the open market within 2 months of the date of this Order. The sale proceeds shall be applied as follows:

a.    To make full payment of the outstanding loan to the financial institution.

b.    To pay all costs and expenses incidental and relating to the sale of the Motor Vehicle.

c.    The net sale proceeds shall be divided in the following manner: 57.25% to the Wife and 42.75% to the Husband

d.    The Wife shall have sole conduct of the sale of the Motor Vehicle and the Husband shall hand over the Motor Vehicle and car keys in working condition, in his possession to the Wife within 2 weeks of this Order. Should the Husband elect to transfer ownership of the Motor Vehicle to his sole name, he shall notify the Wife within 1 week of this Order, pay her S$14,704.09 and solely discharge the outstanding hire purchase loan within 2 weeks of this Order. Failing which, the Husband shall hand over the Motor Vehicle and car keys to the Wife as stated herein.

e.    Pending sale of the Motor Vehicle or transfer of the Motor Vehicle to Husband’s name, Husband to continue to pay for hire purchase instalment and all costs related to Motor Vehicle.

6.    The OCBC Savings Account XXX-XXX397-001 (“the Joint Bank Account”) shall be closed within 7 days from the day of this Order with the balance to be split 57.25% to the Wife and 42.74 to the Husband.

7.    The Wife shall be entitled to S$150,000 of the Husband’s CPF monies pursuant to section 112 of the Women’s Charter (the “Ordered Amount”).

8.    The CPF Board shall transfer, from the monies standing to the credit of the Husband in the following CPF account(s) of Husband, the amount(s) specified as follows to the Wife’s CPF Account:

Husband’s CPF account(s) to transfer from

Amount to Transfer

Ordinary Account

$150,000



9.    This Order is made subject to the Central Provident Fund Act (“CPF Act”) and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder made in respect of Husband’s CPF monies, property and investments. The CPF Board shall give effect to the terms of this Order, in accordance with the provisions of the CPF Act and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder.

10.    Unless expressly provided for in the CPF Act, nothing in the Orders herein shall be taken to affect the Board’s charge on the matrimonial home or any other immovable property owned by one or both of the parties and which is the subject of this Order of Court. The Board shall determine the requisite refunds to be made to the respective parties’ CPF accounts upon the sale, transfer, assignment or otherwise disposal of such immovable property in accordance with the CPF Act and the subsidiary legislation made thereunder.

11.    The shortfall, if any, between the Ordered Amount and the payment received by the Wife from the Board or transferred to the Wife’s CPF account is a debt due from the Husband to the Wife and is recoverable as such.

The Wife shall retain the Rainbow Vacuum Cleaner, Thermostar Avantgarder Steam Cleaner and the Elken Water Purifier, purchased by her.

12.    Each party shall retain all other assets in their sole names.

13.    The Registrar / Assistant Registrar of the Family Justice Courts under s 31 of the Family Justice Act 2014 is empowered to execute, sign, or endorse all necessary documents relating to matters contained in this Order should either party fail to do so within seven days of written request being made to the party.

14.    The Parties, including the Board, shall be at liberty to apply for further directions or Orders generally.

Maintenance

Wife

15.    There be no maintenance for the Wife.

Children (PTK)

16.    The Husband shall pay the Wife outstanding maintenance payment for PTK for the period April 2023 to December 2024 amounting to S$20,816.22. Payment to the Wife’s designated bank account forthwith.

17.    PTK’s living expenses for her overseas education in Australia are fixed at A$2,049 and accommodation costs currently at A$1,556 for every four (4) weeks, subject to adjustment if revised (collectively “the said overseas expenses”). The Husband shall pay his share of the said overseas expenses directly to PTK’s designated bank account as follows on the 12th day of each month:

a.     From January 2025 to December 2026: 55% of the said overseas expenses monthly, or when the course concludes, whichever is earlier.

b.     From January 2027 onwards (should the course not be concluded):50% of the said overseas expenses monthly.

18.    In addition, the Husband shall pay his share of PTK’s major and ad hoc expenses for the entire duration of her tertiary education, including but not limited to school fees, clothing in excess of A$100, school-related expenses in excess of A$100, airfare (returning back to Singapore and to Australia), furniture, furnishings, one-off purchases such as a laptop, mobile phone, costs of opening bank account in Australia, medical, and dental expenses. Payment shall be made directly to PTK’s designated bank account as follows:

a.     From January 2025 to December 2026 (or when the course concludes, whichever is earlier): 55% of such expenses within seven (7) days of the Wife providing supporting documents or invoices.

b.     From January 2027 onwards (should the course not be concluded): 50% of such expenses within seven (7) days of the Wife providing supporting documents or invoices.

19.    For the avoidance of doubt, parties shall continue to pay for PTK’s maintenance when she is back to Singapore for holidays and pay in the proportion as ordered for her monthly mobile phone subscription, medical and dental expenses in Singapore.

Costs

20.    The Defendant is to pay the Plaintiff costs fixed at $10,000 (all-in).

html:
VEV v VEW

VEV v VEW
[2025] SGFC 26

Case Number:Divorce No 3162 of 2018, Summons No 3216 of 2024 & 3397 of 2024
Decision Date:12 March 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Jen Koh
Counsel Name(s): Plaintiff/Husband (In Person).Defendant/Wife (In Person).
Parties: VEV — VEW

Co-parenting issues; Sharing of time with children, Make-up access

12 March 2025

District Judge Jen Koh:

Introduction

1       The Plaintiff shall be referred to as the “father” and the Defendant shall be referred to as the “mother”.

2       The mother filed an appeal against orders made on 4 December 2024 with regard to 3 prayers of 2 different summonses:

(i)     She appeals the dismissal of her prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3216/2024. In this prayer, the mother sought a one-off school holiday with the children at her sole election during 2025 in lieu of her entitlement to the children for a one-off school holiday on 4 October 2024.

(ii)     She appeals the orders made in favour of the father in prayers 6 and 7 of FC/SUM 3397/2024. Prayer 6 of the father’s summons deals with the same subject matter as the mother’s prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3216/2024. The father sought an order that in consideration of the mother having the children for a school holiday on 4 October 2024 and in accordance with the parties' agreement of 1 October 2024, the father would be entitled to an additional single-day school holiday at a time of his choosing (including in 2025) on giving reasonable notice to the wife. I granted an order in terms of the father’s prayer, leading to a dismissal of the mother’s prayer 6 in FC/SUM 3216/2024.

(iii)     In prayer 7 of FC/SUM 3397/2024, the father sought make up access in consideration of the fact that the children were with the mother on 31 August and 1 September 2024. He sought make up access on an additional public holiday at a time of his choosing and an additional Sunday at a time of his choosing on giving (including in 2025) reasonable notice to the mother. I granted an order in terms of this prayer.

Brief background

3       The parties were married on xx July 2011, and they have 2 children, a daughter who will be turning 10 years old in 2025 and a son who will turn 8 years old this year (‘the children’).

4       The father is about 52 and is a Barrister/Mediator/Arbitrator. The mother is about 42 years of age, and she also has a law degree as well as a master’s in law. She is currently a teacher in an international school. The parties are citizens of the United Kingdom (“UK”) with the father holding dual citizenship with Australia and the mother holding dual citizenship in Ireland.

5       The parties relocated to Singapore in February 2012, some 6 months after their marriage. The parties have lived in Singapore since February 2012. The parties are permanent residents of Singapore. Both children are attending local schools.

6       The husband filed a writ for divorce in July 2018. Interim judgment was granted on 5 March 2019. The contested ancillary matters (AM) were heard on 16 and 19 September 2019. I reserved decision and delivered the AM orders on 8 October 2019 with clarifications on 9 and 14 October 2019. Final judgement was extracted on 23 December 2019.

7       The father appealed the AM orders in their entirety and the appeal was heard before the High Court Family Division. The High Court also dealt with related summonses in HCF/DCA 127/2019, HCF/SUM 289/2019, HCF/SUM 324/2019, HCF/SUM 55/2020, HCF/RAS 10/2020, HCF/SUM 163/2020, HCF/SUM 244/2020, HCF/RAS 27/2020, HCF/SUM 340/2020.

8       The High Court made orders on 11 March 2021. In rendering his decision, the learned Judicial Commissioner Tan Puay Boon (as he then was) made the following remarks which I set out:

“141  Before concluding, I add the following remarks. Once the division of matrimonial assets and maintenance in the divorce issues are resolved, the parties should give serious consideration to becoming more accommodating towards each other in dealing with the matters concerning the Children, rather than continuously utilising their forensic skills to seek resolution in court all the time. This is especially so when the matters in dispute are administrative and not legal in nature. Moreover, as the Children grow up day by day, and enter different stages of their lives, such as beginning formal education, adjustments would necessarily have to be made to the current orders. Handling such adjustments in a more amicable way cannot be but in the best interests of the Children.

142    When last counted, there were 26 summonses filed in D 3162, the divorce suit. There were four appeals to the High Court Family Division from decisions in the Family Court, in which a total of four summonses have been filed. There was also an originating summons filed in the Family Court concerning the permanent relocation of the Children, and an originating summons filed in the Court of Appeal for leave to appeal the decision in RAS 10. All these were filed since July 2018, less than three years ago. The Children were aged three and one then, and are now six and four years old, respectively. They will reach majority at 18 in 12 to 14 years. It is a very heavy burden for parties to bear if they continue to choose to resolve disputes for the remaining of those years in the manner and at the rate they have chosen so far. I accept that the Children are still very young and may not now understand the conflicts taking place between the parties. But they will grow up and soon discover what is taking place between their parents. The conflicts will affect them, and it is not fair to them to be made to bear the same heavy burden as well.”

9       Notwithstanding this advice, after the conclusion of the appeal in March 2021, the parties filed 41 applications and 505 affidavits between April 2021 and December 2024.

10     The children were aged 3 and 1 when the divorce proceedings started. They are now turning 10 and 8 respectively. The marriage was contracted in July 2011 and ended in Interim Judgment in March 2019 subsisting some 8 years. But at the rate of the litigation parties decide to embroil in, the years they spend in litigation will soon outstrip the length of the marriage in no time. Indeed, these children have spent much of their childhood thus far with parents mired in litigation.

11     This latest appeal by the mother is a case in point. I have set out the crux of the appeal which is the mother’s dissatisfaction over what she perceived as her entitled time with the children over 3 dates: 4 October 2024, 31 August 2024 and 1 September 2024.

12     Before setting out the reasons for my decision, I also refer parties to DDN v DDO [2024] SGHC(A) 2 in which the Appellate Division (the AD) gave guidance to parties that parents should, in considering their children’s changing needs, exercise grace and flexibility in co-parenting and make arrangements in the best interests of their children: [18]. The AD also referred to VVB v VVA [2022] 4 SLR 1181 (at [24]): Instead of litigating in the courts for the variation of orders, parents should endeavour to make adjustments by agreement to the care and access orders where necessary.

13     It is unfortunate that 7 years after their divorce was granted, these parties continue to be locked in acrimonious litigation over issues pertaining to the children.

Dismissal of Prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3216/2024

Order in terms of prayer 6 of FC/SUM 3397/2024

4 October 2024

14     The issue pertained to with whom the children were to be with on 4 October 2024.

15     The mother sought an order that she should be entitled to make up access on 4 October 2024 whilst the father sought an order giving effect to an express agreement between the parties with regard to an equal split of school holiday for the period 30 August to 7 September 2024. Resulting from this agreement, the children were to be with the mother on 4 October 2024.

16     As set out, according to the mother, the parties agreed to a split of the children’s school holiday for the period 30 August to 7 September 2024. On 26 August 2024, the mother said that she spotted an alleged erroneous calculation of that school holiday period but as parties had made their respective plans with the children for their share of that period, she proceeded with the agreement. However, because of the erroneous split, she said that the alternating entitlements of the parties shifted with the result that the school holiday after the term break fell to the father and the next one (4 October 2024) to the mother.

17     The make-up time with the children she sought therefore pertained to what the mother said stemmed from the erroneous calculation of that school holiday period. As a result of this alleged erroneous calculation by the father, the mother took the view that she had been disadvantaged. She offered to keep the arrangements the parties had agreed to but sought another 1.5 days with the children.

18     The husband’s position was straightforward. There was no reason to grant the order sought by the wife as the children were in fact with her on that day. This was pursuant to an express written agreement detailing how the parties were to share the time with the children. The husband said that the agreement was set out in an exchange of emails on 1 October 2024 exhibited in the husband’s affidavit filed on 25 October 2024 at pages 32 to 33.

19     My decision was likewise straightforward – it was predicated on the parties’ written agreement. Notwithstanding calculations and division of days, parties are always at liberty to agree between themselves on the sharing of time with the children. I refer to paragraph 11 above. In line with co-parenting and considering the children’s needs and welfare, the parties reached an agreement. The agreement was not disputed. The mother herself said she would comply with the agreement as arrangements had been made for the children. She proceeded with her share of that school holiday period in accordance with the agreement. The time sharing of the children for that school holiday period was spent.

20     Having reached such an agreement and acting in accordance with the agreement, the mother then raised an issue with an alleged erroneous calculation. She sought to impose “penalties” on the father by claiming an extra 1.5 days with the children. When she filed the summons, it became a replacement of one day.

21     Although she did have the children with her on 4 October 2024, the mother sought a replacement one day “in lieu of her entitlement to the children for a one-off school holiday on 4 October 2024”.

22     From what I can surmise, the mother’s disgruntlement stemmed from the definition of school holidays and the application to that particular school holiday period. For completeness, this definition (of school holidays) was dealt with by the High Court in its decision of 11 March 2021 in which the Court defined school holidays for the parties as follows:

“[83] The Husband has asked that school holidays be defined, and the Wife has agreed to the draft definition in the AC. This draft was revised by the Husband in the Appellant's Speaking Notes ... to cover multi-day school holidays. I substitute para 16 of [the AM Orders] with the following, based on the revised draft:

School holidays are to be equally shared between the parties. A school holiday shall, for the purposes of these Orders, be a non-teaching day as stated in the children’s school calendar (“the calendar”). In the case of a multi-day school holiday, the school holiday commences on the first non-teaching day of the holiday break as stated in the calendar and shall continue until the day before the first teaching day as stated in the calendar. In all cases, a school holiday shall run from 5:30pm on the eve of the day until 7:30pm on the day itself. ..."

23     However, the point to be noted is not the definition of school holidays or whether there was an erroneous calculation but that parties had an agreement. They both acted on the said agreement; the school holiday period in question had lapsed and the mother had the children with her on 4 October 2024 in reliance on that agreement. Indeed, in the spirit of co-parenting, the parties have been enjoined repeatedly to agree on time sharing with their children as they are best placed to determine this. Having done so, the mother should not press on to claim a disadvantage of a loss of one day with the children with whom she has care and control.

24     The mother is also not a naïve litigant in person. She is legally trained and has fired many salvos herself in the litigation arena with applications for time sharing, clarification of time sharing and the filing of many affidavits. Having agreed with the father on the holiday period in question, she should not now be permitted to backtrack and claim an additional day. There was no basis for this Court to grant the relief sought in prayer 6 of the mother's Summons and this prayer was accordingly dismissed.

Order in terms of prayer 7 of FC/SUM 3397/2024 – make up access to the father

31 August and 1 September 2024

25     The children had a mid-term break in the week of 2 to 6 September 2024. On Friday 30 August, the children did not have to attend school because it was Children's Day. 31 August was a Saturday, and this was the father’s time with the children pursuant to the AM Orders. 1 September was a Sunday and Father’s Day and meant for the father to spend time with the children.

26     The parties had agreed that 30 August 2024 was a single-day school holiday and that this day was meant for the father. Father’s Day was also meant for the father. This then led to the multi-day school holiday in the week of 2 to 6 September which would include the weekend of 7 and 8 September. The parties agreed to the calculation of 7 days (2 to 8 September 2024) and the mother agreed to take the first half as this was again, an equal split. This was set out in emails in pages 35 to 36 of the father’s affidavit filed on 25 October 2024.

27     However, 3 days before handover to the father, the mother claimed that Children’s Day on 30 August 2024 also formed part of the multi-day school holiday starting on 2 September 2024. This led to emails being sent as referred to in pages 23 to 32 of the mother’s affidavit of 8 October 2024. The mother was only prepared to let the father have the children from Tuesday 3 September 2024. This was notwithstanding that parties had reached an agreement on time sharing as set out in paragraph 26 above.

28     Because of the mother’s change in position, again departing from an agreement at the 11th hour, the father did not see the children on 30 August 2024 (his entitlement pursuant to the definition of a single-day school holiday), Saturday which was part of his weekend access order pursuant to the AM orders and more pertinently, on Father’s Day.

29     The parties had agreed to the arrangement with the school holidays to be divided between them from 2 to 8 September 2024. Because the mother resiled on the agreement and retained the children with her depriving the father of his single-day school holiday, his Saturday access and Father’s Day, the father was therefore entitled to the make-up access.

30     The parties subsequently agreed to a replacement and swapped single-day school holiday which resolved the issue of replacement time for the father on 30 August 2024. The father was therefore entitled to the make-up access for his loss of access on 31 August 2024 and 1 September 2024 and I so ordered.

Concluding remarks

31     Whilst the High Court had defined single-day school holidays and multi-school holidays (see paragraph 11 above), the parties have managed to agree and rework time sharing of their children considering the children’s needs and welfare as well as the parties’ own schedules. It is important for the parties to agree and resolve this time sharing of their children without the Court’s intervention; they are, after all, the children’s parents. It is also not right to agree on an arrangement and then throw it out on the 11th hour then insisting on “rights” and “claims”.

32     The parties would do well to move away from their perceived entitled positions and think in terms of what would work best for the children with the least movement for handovers. At the crux of this matter, the issues are not legal issues. These are parenting matters, and it is unfortunate that their inability to co-parent spawned an appeal for 3 dates of access/make-up time.

33     I have said before that these parties would benefit from the assistance of a parenting coordinator or a mediator as they are wasting precious time in drafting affidavits and filing applications ironically about time sharing with the children; time which would have been better spent with their children. I hope for the children’s sake that the parties would heed the advice of the Court as set out in paragraph 8.
