html:
XJB v XJC

XJB v XJC
[2025] SGFC 21

Case Number:Summons No 217 and 218 of 2024
Decision Date:19 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Cha Yong Sing, Ignatious and Pearlyn Yeo (Yeo & Associates LLC) for the Husband; Leong Zhen Yang (I.R.B Law LLP) for the Wife.
Parties: XJB — XJC

Family Law – Family Violence – Personal Protection Order

19 February 2025

Judgment reserved

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       This was a dispute between Husband and Wife. Each had brought an application for a personal protection order (“PPO”) against each other. SS 217 of 2024 (“SS 217”) is the Wife’s application against the Husband for a PPO. In addition, the Wife also seeks a domestic exclusion order (“DEO”) to exclude the Husband from her bedroom.

2       SS 218 of 2024 (“SS 218”) is the Husband’s application against the Wife for a PPO. In addition, the Husband also seeks a DEO against the Wife to exclude her from his bedroom.

3       The Husband was represented by Mr Ignatious Cha (“Mr Cha”) and Ms Pearlyn Yeo (“Ms Yeo”). The Wife was represented by Mr Leong Zhen Yang (“Mr Leong”).

4       I heard the trial and reserved judgment. This is my decision.

The Law on Family Violence

5       It is hornbook law that to obtain a PPO, an applicant must establish the following two requirements on a balance of probabilities (XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 (“XFL”) at [13] – [14]; XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [5] – [7]; XDV v XDW [2024] SGFC 87 at [12]):

(a)     That the respondent had either committed family violence, or was likely to commit family violence; and that

(b)     It is necessary for the court to grant the PPO.

6       As to what constitutes family violence, the starting point is found in the definition set out in s 64 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (the “Charter”). That provision states:

“family violence” means the commission of any of the following acts:

(a)    wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;

(b)    causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;

(c)    wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will;

(d)    causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member,

but does not include any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age;

7       In addition to ordering a PPO, a DEO may also be ordered if it is necessary for the “protection or personal safety of the applicant”. That is made clear by s 65(5)(a) of the Charter:

(5)    A protection order may, where the court is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that it is necessary for the protection or personal safety of the applicant, provide for such orders as the court thinks fit having regard to all the circumstances of the case, including any one or more of the following orders:

(a)    the granting of the right of exclusive occupation to any protected person of the shared residence or a specified part of the shared residence by excluding the person against whom the order is made from the shared residence or specified part thereof, regardless of whether the shared residence is solely owned or leased by the person against whom the order is made or jointly owned or leased by the parties;

Whether the Wife’s application in SS 217 should be granted

8       I deal first, with the Wife’s application in SS 217.

Incidents complained of in SS 217

9       These are the incidents which the Wife relies on in support of her application for a PPO and a DEO.

The incident on 11 December 2023

10     According to the Wife, this incident took place at around 10 pm.[note: 1] The Husband had warned her to not show their son any YouTube videos on the projector and threatened to switch off the projector if his demands were not met.

11     An argument ensued. The Husband allegedly swung his left hand towards the Wife’s face. He stopped mid-blow such that his hand brushed past her right ear forcefully. The Wife says that the Husband did want to slap her, but stopped himself because he knew that there was a CCTV installed in her bedroom. She says that Husband would have been more brazen in his use of force had there not been a CCTV installed in her room.[note: 2]

12     This incident was captured on the CCTV installed in the Wife’s room. The footage was played in court. It clearly shows that the Husband had tried to slap the Wife. He had, all of a sudden, swung his hand very quickly towards the Wife’s face. The Wife recoiled and tried to shield herself. Her earbud was dislodged and fell to the ground. The Wife retaliated by slapping the Husband twice.

13     The Husband had, in the course of his re-examination, given an explanation for having acted in this manner:

Q:    Right. Now, earlier in relation to the 11th December 2023 incident, Mr. Leong said that you did not just move your hand, but swung forcefully such that Ms. XJB’s earpiece dropped on the floor and you said you could explain. What do you wish to explain?

A:    Mmm. Mmm. Okay, uh, on the 11th December, uh, twenty twen---uh, 2023, um, I noticed that, uh---uh, Ms. XJB is showing the, uh, projector to the kids in their rooms. And usually, when they show the projector, then the light is off, uh, turn off and---and they just show that, uh---uh, projector on the---on the---on the wall. And this one could, uh, strain the---the child eyes and does---and then---and [inaudible] uh, screen times. And, uh, because I want to, uh, discuss this with, uh, Ms. XJB’s, um, in a manner way. And, uh, during the---during discussion I found out that she didn’t, uh, listen carefully and didn’t pay attention to it. And I found out that, um, she have ear---earbud on her---on her ear. So, um, my intention just to take out the earbud, uh, from the ear and so we can have, um---um, so she can listen and have a conversation in a manner way. Uh, this is just to take out the, uh, earbud from---from her ear. And while I---while I take out the earbud, she quickly, uh, grab my hands and that’s caused the earbud to fall on the floor. And not just that, she also, um---uh, pulled my hands and pulled my body until I, uh, until my body is pulling---pull in front. Then not---not enough with that, she also hit me twice on my body. And I have to use my hands to, um, to defend it.

14     The Husband had also argued, in written submissions, that he had no intention of placing the Wife in fear of hurt, or that he had intended to cause hurt to the Wife.[note: 3] He submitted that he “had simply wanted to stop the Wife from closing the door as parties h[ad] not addressed” the issue of the Wife letting their son watch YouTube videos on the projector in her room.

15     I do not accept the explanations which the Husband had offered for his actions on that day. He had indeed swung his hand very quickly. It was aimed at the Wife’s face. Up till that juncture, it was apparent that both parties were engaging in conversation that was not particularly heated in any way.

16     The circumstances as well as the Husband’s act of swinging his hand therefore do not support his stated intention of wanting to remove the earbud from the Wife’s ear so that they could have an uninterrupted conversation. It is thus clear to me that the Husband had committed family violence in that he had, to use the language of limb (a) (see above at [6]), wilfully, knowingly, or had attempted to place the Wife in fear of hurt.

17     Finally, I add that insofar as the Husband alleges that the Wife had, by slapping him twice in retaliation, committed family violence, I do not find that to be the case. It is clear from the video that the Wife had been provoked by the Husband’s actions. Her two slaps appeared to have been done out of anger and frustration at how the Husband had behaved. She had also subsequently taken steps to disengage and de-escalate the conflict by closing her room door.

The incident on 27 December 2023

18     Both the Wife and the Husband rely on this incident in support of their respective applications.

19     This is the Wife’s account of events. She stated that she had planned to take their son to Johor Bahru.[note: 4] The Husband had given approval to do so. Their son, however, kicked up a fuss. The Husband construed this as their son being reluctant to go on the trip. He refused to hand over their son’s passport.

20     The Wife describes the events which followed that took place at the void deck. She says that there was an argument. She said she wanted to call the police.[note: 5] This was when the Husband took their son’s passport and slammed it hard onto her left shoulder and the “motion came into contact” with her cheek, “causing a bruise”.[note: 6]

21     The Wife called the police immediately. She also exhibits, in her affidavit, a copy of a discharge summary dated 28 December 2023 showing the “diagnosis of the injury as contusion on” her cheek. In the course of her testimony, the Wife also said that the Husband’s younger sister had scratched her on the cheek during this incident. When she saw the doctor, she had told him that she suffered injuries on her left shoulder and cheek. According to her, the doctor could see that “there were red marks” on her cheek, and that the doctor also examined her shoulder and told her to monitor it for a few days.[note: 7]

22     The Wife’s case is that the Husband had, by slamming the passport into her shoulder which resulted in a bruise, committed family violence within the definition of either limbs (a) or (b) (see above at [6]) of s 64 of the Charter.

23     The Husband, on the other hand, presented a different version of events in his affidavit. According to him, that incident had taken place at 11.30 pm. He had returned to the matrimonial home with his family members in tow. They had just come back from a trip to Kuala Lumpur.

24     The Husband states that he had argued with the Wife. He wanted to let their son sleep as he was exhausted. The Wife, on the other hand, refused.

25     Both the Husband and the Wife took their quarrel to the ground floor. The Wife continued to insist that she be allowed to bring their son to Malaysia. She asked for his passport. The Husband says that because it was raining at the time, and for their son’s sake, he used his son’s passport to “tap” the Wife on her shoulder and asked that she let their son return to the matrimonial home.

26     The Wife became aggressive. She accused the Husband of punching her. She screamed loudly and told both her parents, as well as her boyfriend, that the Husband had punched her.

27     The Husband attempted to disengage by retreating into the lift. The Wife, however, managed to trigger the lift alarm button. The police were called and officers eventually arrived on the scene.[note: 8]

28     Having considered the evidence, I find that the Wife has established, on a balance of probabilities, that the Husband had hit her forcefully on her shoulder with the passport which resulted in a bruise.

29     For one, it is not disputed that the photo, marked “W2”, was indeed of the Wife’s shoulder.[note: 9] The time stamp indicates that the photograph was taken 2 days after this incident. The photograph does show what appears to be a faint bruise on the Wife’s shoulder.

30     Aside from the photographic evidence, there is also the Husband’s testimony. His account of events was that he had used the passport to “tap” the Wife on her shoulder. He does not dispute having made contact with the Wife’s left shoulder. This was what he had said in cross-examination:[note: 10]

Q:

Mr. XJC, would you therefore agree that Ms. XJB’s evidence that you slammed the passport is consistent with what you said about---in---at paragraph 8 of your affidavit?

Witness:

Your Honour, if I may---uh, if I may---uh, the word, the---what the lawyer I mean, say is “slam” which is I don’t agree with the “slam” word, it’s a tap. So, if we, uh---he keep mentioned about the “slam”---

Q:

You can---

Witness:

I will always disagree, Your Honour.

Q:

Thank---thank you, Mr. XJC. You can disagree.



31     In my judgment, the Husband’s use of the word “tap” was an attempt to downplay the force he had actually used during the incident. I find that he had slammed the passport into the Wife’s shoulder which resulted in a bruise. The Husband’s account of merely tapping the Wife on her shoulder is not consistent with the context in which the incident took place, which was amidst a quarrel. Having been showed evidence in the form of videos of other quarrels between the parties, I consider it likely that this quarrel on 27 December 2023 was also a heated one. The Husband’s account as to the amount of force he had used is therefore less plausible than the Wife’s account.

32     Having found that the Husband had “slammed” the passport into the Wife’s left shoulder and caused a bruise, I also find that such an act falls squarely within limb (b) of the definition of family violence set out in s 64 of the Charter (see above at [6]).

The incident on 3 February 2024 (the “Air Tag Incident”)

33     On this date, the Wife discovered that the Husband had planted an Apple Air Tag tracker in their son’s necklace.[note: 11] The Wife claims that this would allow the Husband to track their whereabouts when she takes the son out. She further claims that the Husband is doing this as a means of “conducting surveillance” on her. Consequently, she feels worn out mentally, extremely vulnerable and worried.

34     She made a police report about this incident. That report is also exhibited in her affidavit. The Wife’s case is that the Husband had, by planting an Apple Air Tag in their son’s bag to track her movements, committed an act of family violence within the meaning of limb (d) of s 64 of the Charter (see above at [6]).[note: 12]

35     The Husband, in the course of his testimony, did not deny placing an Apple Air tag tracker in his son’s necklace, as well as his bag.[note: 13] The Husband claims that he had done so to ensure his son’s safety and that he had seen the need for this after December 2023. This was because he had noticed that whenever the Wife sent their son to school, and picked him up, the Wife’s close male friend would be present.[note: 14] This led the Husband to be concerned about his son’s safety. As he explained:

[A]fter the fetching the school---from the---from the school, she frequently, uh, bring the child’s together with the this---third party, and, uh---they put---they do things, uh, together like, uh, dinner together, even watch movie together, evens, uh, go to shopping malls together. Yah. So, uh, this has been repeatings and when the kids go home and---and told me that, uh, there is this, uh, that’s the---there’s another guy that involved in this. And I repeatings mention to Ms. XJB, which is my wife to say I---do not do this---uh, do not do in front of the kids. Want to do is, uh, do your own, don’t involve the kids. Yah. And she---uh, she’s just ignoring me and just keep continue doing that. Yah. So, for me, uh, there’s a third party involved and some time they reach home it’s quite late sometimes. I can see from the time here is, uh, 11:00 or some time it reach homes, uh, past midnight as well. Uh, until the kids already sleeping and when---when they reach home, the kids already sleeping. So, uh, and she didn’t tell me where they go and---and what---what they do and did they go. So, I found it as a signs of me to---to me---need to know, uh, whether or not my son is in the safety. So, I need to like at least to know, uh, where I can find my son, if need---if needed.

36     It appears that the Husband may have had one other reason for placing an Apple Air Tag on the son’s belongings – that was, to find out if his Wife was having an affair, and if so, who she was having an affair with. The Husband had told me that he had first learnt about the Wife’s close male friend from their son. When he confronted the Wife about this, she mentioned that he was merely a Grab driver.[note: 15] Her story soon changed – she subsequently gave other conflicting accounts as to who this man was.

37     The Husband’s decision to place an Apple Air tag in his son’s bag was likely motivated by an incident which took place on 28th November 2023. He was looking at his Wife’s phone and when he tried to make a video call on her phone, he noticed that there was already an active video call in progress. This was what he saw:

Witness:

Yes. There’s active video call and I saw the guy then he saw me, and he tried to look, uh, clearly what he saw, then he quickly end out the call.

Court:

Okay. And so, that led you to suspect that Ms. XJB---

Witness:

That they---

Court:

was actually having an affair with that man.

Witness:

That’s right. That’s right, uh, Your Honour.

Court:

Okay. So, how did you feel when you found out?

Witness:

Uh, I feel betray, uh, Your Honour. I mean, I never been---I never really expect can betrayed in such a way. I never, um hurt the families, or---or---or do other things, um, I’m---I’m---I’m present myself as a good role model for my sons, and uh, as a hand-on father. So, I don’t have times for---for have, uh, um, look for other [inaudible] but I didn’t expect that I’ve been treated like this---this way.



38     That being said, I do believe the Husband’s explanation for placing the Apple air tag on his son’s belongings – that it was to ensure that he could find his son, especially given the presence of this unknown and unidentified man. I do not find that the Husband had planted the air tags with the purpose or intention of stalking the Wife. Had he intended to do so, the air tags would have either been planted on her belongings, or cleverly concealed. This was not the case. As the Wife herself had testified:[note: 16]

Q:    Now, Ms. XJB, was the Apple AirTag stitched to some secret compartment of the child’s bag?

A:    Yes, inside the compartment.

Q:    Ms. XJB, the---the question was yes or no. Was it stitched to some secret compartment of the child’s bag? That’s not my question.

A:    I don’t know whether you call that a secret compartment bag, it’s inside the compartment of the bag.

Q:    Was the Apple AirTag sewn in the bag?

A:    What do you mean by that?

Q:    Did you have to cut the Apple AirTag out of the bag?

A:    No, I don’t have to.

Q:    And which compartment of the child’s bag did you find the Apple AirTag?

A:    The compartment inside the schoolbag.

Q:    Okay, Ms. XJB. Now, for that Apple AirTag hidden in your son’s bag, you said that you disposed of it, correct?

A:    Yes.

39     As a matter of law, to establish that there has been family violence as defined in limb (b) of s 64 of the Charter, it must be shown that the respondent had: a) committed harassment, b) that such harassment is continual, and c) that this had been done with the intention to, or with the knowledge that such action would, cause the applicant to suffer “anguish”: XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [6(d)]; XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [37] – [38]; VAW v VAX [2019] SGFC 104 at [8] (see also XEN v XEO [2024] SGFC 94). I do not find that the Husband’s actions of planting the Apple Air Tag in the son’s belongings constitute harassment towards the Wife, nor do I find that he had done so with the intention of causing her “anguish”.

The incident on 28 November 2023

40     This incident, according to the Wife, took place at around 9.35pm.[note: 17] She had returned home from work. The son had not bathed. The Wife took their son to the toilet for a bath.

41     During this time, the Husband entered the Wife’s room without her permission. He rummaged through her bag and checked her handphone. The Wife did not consent to this. She says at that time, the both of them were contemplating divorce. It was thus likely that the Husband was looking for evidence to “build his case for ancillary matters in the divorce”. The Wife says the Husband had, by going through her phone, violated her privacy. She also says that the Husband’s actions fall within limb (d) of the definition of family violence (see above at [6]).[note: 18]

42     The Husband’s explanation was that he had done this for the sake of their son. He explained that when he tried to text the Wife, she did not pick up. He had therefore gone into her room, picked up her phone, and used his phone to send her a message on WhatsApp to see if she could receive it.[note: 19] He admitted that he had done this despite knowing that relations between himself and the Wife were not good, and that if the Wife discovered that he had been rummaging through her belongings, it would only serve to worsen matters.[note: 20] The Husband, however, denied that he had gone into the Wife’s room on previous occasions and rummaged through her belongings, and checked her phone.[note: 21]

43     I do not find this incident which the Wife complained of falls within the definition of family violence under limb (d) of s 64 of the Charter. It has not been established that the Husband had indeed, on other previous occasions, snuck into the Wife’s room, rummaged through her belongings, and checked the contents of her phone.

The incident on 28 January 2024

44     In this incident, the Wife was spending time with their son on the sofa in the living room.[note: 22] The Husband had come and sat next to her despite knowing that she was uncomfortable being in close proximity with him. The Wife alleges that the Husband continued to harass her by moving close to their son. She believes that the Husband wanted to exploit her fear of being near him to deny her the space and freedom of being in her own home. She claims that she could no longer “enjoy or feel safe in the flat”.

45     The Wife also exhibits footage of the Husband allegedly harassing her by “coming so close” to her personal boundaries.[note: 23] Again, the Wife says that the Husband’s actions constituted continual harassment as defined in limb (d) of s 64 of the Charter.

46     The video was played in court. It clearly shows the Husband seated next to the Wife on the couch. The Wife then stands up and moves to sit away from the Husband, putting their son in between them. In the process, a cushion was flung, presumably by the Wife, onto the seat that she had just vacated. The clip ends with the Husband kissing the son on the head.

47     While the Wife may feel annoyed, frustrated, or angry at being in close physical proximity to the Husband, in my judgment, his actions do not constitute harassment. As the Husband had explained, he had joined the Wife and the son on the couch because it was their routine to watch television with their son.[note: 24] I find that the Husband’s actions were not calculated at “causing anguish” to the Wife, but rather, intended to give their son a sense of normalcy as far as possible by keeping up with their Sunday routine.

The incident on 2 February 2024

48     This incident occurred at 11.35pm.[note: 25] The Husband had tried to enter the Wife’s room multiple times on the pretext that he wanted to remove the remote control to the air conditioner. What he really wanted was to remove the CCTV that the Wife had installed in her room.

49     When the Wife saw the Husband heading towards the CCTV, she quickly pushed him out of the room. She tried to close the door. The Husband resisted and prevented her from doing so.

50     An argument ensued over the Wife’s use of the air conditioner in her room. In the course of this argument, the Husband suddenly came “very close” to the Wife and shouted in her face. The Wife says this was an act of aggression to intimidate her. She retaliated to demonstrate that she would not cower in the face of such behaviour.

51     During this time, the scuffle continued, with the Wife using her body to push against her bedroom door to prevent the Husband from entering her room. The Husband, however, forcefully pushed against the door, causing the Wife to fall “backwards on[to] [her] back”. The Wife’s head hit the floor.

52     The Wife subsequently obtained a medical report from the Accident and Emergency Department. It was exhibited in her affidavit. The primary diagnosis was a “sprain of shoulder”. The secondary diagnosis was a head injury.[note: 26]

53     The Wife also claims that prior to this incident, both the Husband and his family had been very aggressive and had made several threats against her. Her case was that the Husband had, in this incident on 2 February 2024, caused hurt to her, and this was an act falling within limb (b) of s 64 of the Charter.[note: 27]

54     Having watched the video footage, which was also played several times in court, it is clear to me that the Husband did not commit family violence within the definition of limb (b) of s 64 of the Charter in this incident.

55     The video shows both the Husband and the Wife tussling at the door. The Husband is trying to gain entry into the Wife’s room. The Wife, on the other hand, is barring his way and trying to push him back out into the corridor. As the Husband tries, once more, to force his way in, he does not appear to be using much force. The Wife tries to stop him. In the process, she loses her balance. Her knees buckle. She reaches out to grab onto something to arrest her fall. Her hand finds the Husband’s neck and arm. The Husband is also dragged down. He falls on top of her.

56     That the Wife fell down, and suffered an injury to her shoulder and head, was not, in my judgment, a result of the Husband shoving her forcefully.

The incident on 20 April 2024

57     The Wife cites this incident as an example of how the Husband had escalated his “harassment and aggression” towards herself as well as her mother.[note: 28] The Wife alleges that that the Husband had placed his hand very close to her face, as well as that of her mother, under the “guise of making a video recording” of the both of them. She says that the Husband did so “in order to apply physical force” on the both of them.

58     In written submissions, the Wife clarifies that her reference to this incident was merely to “show that there was an escalation of tensions between the parties”.[note: 29] In any event, having reviewed the footage, I do not find that the Husband had intentionally placed his hand very close to the Wife’s face under the guise of making a video recording when his true intention was to apply physical force. Parties were, at the time, both filming each other, presumably so that they would both have evidence to present in court.

Other allegations of family violence

59     In addition to the aforementioned incidents of alleged family violence, the Wife also raises a host of other acts of family violence which she says the Husband had committed on her.

60     First, the Wife says that the Husband had harassed her by unlocking her room with the master key and entering without her permission or giving advance notice. This was in spite of her informing him that he needed to seek her permission before doing so given that the both of them were already living in separate rooms by that point. The Wife also says that she was, on several occasions, improperly attired when the Husband barged in.[note: 30]

61     The second instance of such harassment the Wife cites was in relation to the Husband installing CCTV cameras around the flat. She says that this has led to her living in “fear and surveillance”.[note: 31] Apart from this, the Wife says that the Husband had intruded into her personal boundaries, planted an Apple Air Tag tracker on their son (see above at [x]), and threatened to ransack her room. Taken together, these were, according to the Wife, acts that constituted continuous harassment meant to cause her anguish.[note: 32]

62     Finally, the Wife accuses the Husband of abusing her mentally, and cites the following examples.[note: 33]

63     For one, the Husband had taken away the remote control to the air conditioner, forcing her to endure “the heat with just a fan”.

64     The Wife also says the Husband had cut off her Wi-Fi. In addition to this, the Husband would, on or around July 2022, slam or bang on her door early in the morning simply because he was unhappy. When she opened the door, he would just stare at her and walk away. This apparently happened for a few months.

65     The Wife also accuses the Husband of threatening her in mandarin – he would tell her: “I will want to see how you eventually die without me”.[note: 34]

66     Having already addressed the specific incidences of family violence which the Wife has raised, and found that the Husband’s actions in two of those incidents did constitute family violence (above at [16] and [32]), I do not think it necessary to deal with these other allegations the Wife has levelled against the Husband. Doing so would only run the risk of increasing the acrimony between the parties who are currently in the midst of divorce proceedings. I echo the views of the court in XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95:

(b)    Apart from s 65(1), there are also good reasons why, in principle, a court should not be obliged to make findings as to whether family violence has been committed for every allegation raised by the parties.

(i)     The purpose of a PPO is not to punish a party for past acts of such violence: Lai Kwok Kin at [38]; Yue Tock Him at [10]; GFS v GFT [2023] SGFC 21 (“GFS”) at [31]; WSD v WSE [2024] SGFC 1 at [1]; UMI v UMK [2018] SGFC 53 at [37] to [39].

(ii)   Instead, a PPO is “pre-emptive” in purpose – i.e., it protects an applicant from future family violence. If there are reasonable grounds to believe that an applicant is in danger of family violence, then a PPO should be issued even if such violence has not been committed on the applicant previously.

(iii)   Additionally, in the case of cross-complaints involving parties in a highly acrimonious relationship, there is a real risk of the parties expecting the court to adjudicate on who was “right” or “wrong” regarding their past differences. A PPO trial is not a forum to settle personal scores. There is little utility in expending court resources to scrutinise each allegation of family violence when it is already clear from the evidence or from a party’s conduct in court that he/she is ready to engage in escalatory “tit-for-tat” for the most minor slight perceived from the other party.

[emphasis added]

67     For completeness, however, I deal with the Wife’s argument that based on the incidents which took place on 28 November 2023 (above at [40]), 28 January 2024 (above at [44]), February 2024, 3 February 2024 (above at [33]), and the CCTVs installed in the home since 16 December 2024, it is clear that the Husband had committed family violence within the definition of limb (b) of s 64 of the Charter.[note: 35]

68     I do not find that these incidents, when considered together, demonstrate that Husband had embarked on a campaign of harassment against the Wife. As I had explained above (at [38] – [39]), the Husband did have reasons for putting an air tag in the son’s bag, as well as going to sit next to the Wife on the couch. In any event, these alleged incidents took place during a time when parties’ relations were strained to the breaking point. The suspicion and mistrust that arose likely coloured the Wife’s view of these events, giving her the impression that the Husband was trying to harass her.

Whether it is necessary to order a PPO and a DEO

69     Having found that the Husband had committed family violence (above at [16] – [32]), I turn now to consider the necessity of a PPO as well as a DEO.

70     The inquiry into whether a PPO is necessary involves a risk assessment as to the likelihood of a respondent committing family violence against an applicant in the future: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [19]. This involves an examination of, inter alia, the reasons and circumstances for family violence and whether the family violence was a recent occurrence. Red flags that point to the necessity of a PPO include: a) likelihood of interactions between the parties; b) that the underlying cause for family violence remains unresolved; c) respondent specific factors (ie, where the respondent is deeply antagonistic towards the applicant or where the respondent has a propensity for violence): XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [21].

71     In addition, the necessity requirement also encapsulates an assessment of whether a PPO is necessary to deter family violence – as the court in XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 had observed (at [23]), this is because a PPO essentially converts acts which are typically non-arrestable offences, into an arrestable offence. This is because the commission of such acts would be considered a breach of a PPO, and such a breach is an arrestable offence under s 65(11) of the Charter.

72     I would add that the PPO regime recognises that there will be, in any relationship, some degree of conflict, and that the actions of parties could conceivably fall within the definitions of family violence as set out in the Charter. However, it is only where this conflict rises to a point where intervention is warranted that a PPO will be granted to protect the applicant from harm and/or abuse. This finds expression in the “necessity” requirement.

73     In the circumstances, I find that it is necessary to grant a PPO, as well as a DEO to exclude the Husband from the Wife’s bedroom.

74     It is clear to me that there was no love lost between the Husband and the Wife. The videos produced in court showed the intensity of their quarrels. There are also unresolved issues that provide the kindling for further conflict – for instance, the Husband’s suspicion that the Wife had been cheating on him.

75     It is also not the case that both the Husband and the Wife are able to completely break off ties and go their own separate ways. They are still staying in the same house. Their close physical proximity to each other has, and can only continue to, create further opportunities for conflict.

76     As to the necessity of a DEO, that stems from the fact that a number of the incidents here have arisen from the Husband’s attempt to enter the Wife’s room despite her having told him, on no uncertain terms, not to do so. The DEO is necessary to ensure that the Wife has her own undisturbed space within the house and to minimise the possibility of further conflict between the parties.

77     Finally, I will also order that the PPO and DEO shall only be effective for a period of 2 years from the date of this judgment (ie, until the 19th of February 2027). This is because the divorce proceedings between parties would, in all likelihood, have concluded by then. After the ancillary matters have been resolved, parties would have embarked on their own separate paths. Contact may well be minimal, and limited to matters concerning their son. This would greatly reduce the opportunities and avenues for conflict that necessitate my granting of the PPO and the DEO.

78     In addition to the PPO and DEO, I am also ordering that both the Husband and Wife go for counselling to equip themselves with the necessary tools to better deal with and manage their conflict.

Whether the Husband’s application in SS 218 should be granted

79     I turn now to consider the Husband’s application for a PPO and DEO in SS 218.

Incidents complained of in SS 218

80     The Husband relies on the following incidents in support of his application for a PPO and a DEO against the Wife.

The Incident on 13 September 2023

81     The first relates to an incident on 13 September 2023 at 11.55pm. This was what the Husband had said in his affidavit:

11.    The Respondent and I have quarrelled over her claim that my parents entered her room without her consent. She has also accused my parents of bringing “black magic”-related paraphernalia into her room. Her claims are obviously trivial, frivolous, and false.

12.    She has clear anger management issues and has screamed at me and physically assaulted me by scratching my upper body which left visible scratch marks. After doing so, she called the police. When the police arrived and saw my scratches, he asked whether I would like to report abuse/violence. I had no intention of pursuing the matter back then.

82     In essence, the Husband’s complaint is that in this incident, the Wife had physically assaulted him by “scratching [his] upper body which left visible scratch marks”.

83     In written submissions, the Husband had argued that because counsel for the Wife did not cross-examine the Husband on this point, it leads to the conclusion that she had accepted the Husband’s account of events.[note: 36]

84     The Wife, on the other hand, argued in written submissions that the Husband’s account should not be accepted. This was because the Husband had not adduced any supporting documents. There was also an “abject lack of details” in the Husband’s AEIC.[note: 37] And even taking the Husband’s case at its highest, the Wife’s actions could not constitute family violence.[note: 38]

85     The Husband’s argument, though it does not explicitly say so, urges me to apply the rule laid down in Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67 (“Browne”). As was noted in Britestone Pte Ltd v Smith & Associates Far East, Ltd [2007] 4 SLR(R) 855 at [17]:

[T]the rule in Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67 prima facie applied. This rule stands for the well-settled proposition that (per Colin Tapper, Cross and Tapper on Evidence (Butterworths, 8th Ed, 1995) at p 319, which was cited in Arts Niche Cyber Distribution Pte Ltd v PP [1999] 2 SLR(R) 936 at [48]; see also M N Howard et al, Phipson on Evidence (Sweet & Maxwell, 14th Ed, 1990) at para 12-13):

Any matter upon which it is proposed to contradict the evidence-in-chief given by the witness must normally be put to him so that he may have an opportunity of explaining the contradiction, and failure to do this may be held to imply acceptance of the evidence-in-chief ...

86     The rule in Browne, however, is not a “rigid, technical rule”. In the words of the court in Hong Leong Singapore Finance Ltd v United Overseas Bank Ltd [2007] 1 SLR(R) 292 (cited with approval in Asnah bte Ab Rahman v Li Jianlin [2016] 2 SLR 944 at [115]):

42    Before leaving the issue of oral evidence, I should comment briefly on the effect and relevance of what is referred to as the rule in Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67. Browne v Dunn is a case of some vintage and it lays down a rule of fairness. The effect of that rule is that where a submission is going to be made about a witness or the evidence given by the witness which is of such a nature and of such importance that it ought fairly to have been put to the witness to give him the opportunity to meet that submission, to counter it or to explain himself, then if it has not been so put, the party concerned will not be allowed to make that submission. It is not a rigid, technical rule. Nor is it necessarily satisfied by a formulaic recitation of a party’s case to a witness, with an invitation merely to agree or disagree. In Chan Emily v Kang Hock Chai Joachim [2005] 2 SLR 236 at [15], Choo Han Teck J noted that the rule which is derived from a case more than a century old must be applied with due regard to the realities of modern litigation and in evaluating any given objection, consideration should be given to the totality of the evidence in the case. I think that is correct. In Lo Sook Ling Adela v Au Mei Yin Christina [2002] 1 SLR 408 the Court of Appeal noted (at [40]) that the rule is not rigid and does not require every point to be put to the witness but this would generally be required where the submission was “at the very heart of the matter”. This was approved by the Court of Appeal in Ong Jane Rebecca v Lim Lie Hoa [2005] SGCA 4 at [49]–[50]. I approached the evidence and the submissions in this case in that light.

87     That the Wife had not been cross-examined on this point does not necessarily mean that I am bound to accept the Husband’s version of events. Indeed, I do not. While the Husband has recounted this incident in his affidavit, he has not exhibited any documents to support his claim. For example, there are no pictures of the scratches which the Wife had allegedly inflicted. Further, given that the police had been called, one might expect that a police report or some other documentary evidence be exhibited, notwithstanding the fact that the Husband had stated he had “no intention of pursuing the matter back then”.

88     I add that even accepting the Husband’s account, that the Wife had indeed scratched him, he has not established whether her actions amounted to family violence. That is because his account of events (above at [81]), does not set out fully the circumstances in which the Wife had scratched him. It also does not describe the extent and severity of the scratches allegedly inflicted upon him.

89     The Husband has therefore not established, on a balance of probabilities, that the Wife had indeed committed family violence in this incident.

The Incident on 2nd February 2024

90     The second is an incident which took place on 2 February 2024 at 11.30 pm.[note: 39] The Wife had also relied on this incident in support of her application for a PPO in SS 217.

91     The Husband’s account is that the Wife had returned to the matrimonial home and turned off the doorbell camera. When confronted by the Husband, the Wife admitted to doing so.

92     The Husband says that the Wife had turned off the doorbell camera out of spite and with the intention of provoking him. He says that she had done so several times previously.

93     On this occasion, the Husband responded by informing the Wife that he would be turning off the CCTV she had installed in her room, as well as the air conditioner. He further informed her that she would have to bear part of the utilities expenses if she wanted to enjoy the comforts of air conditioning.

94     This sparked a quarrel. The Husband says that when the quarrel took place, he was standing outside her room and holding the door. The Wife insisted on pushing him out of the room, and in doing so, scratched him all over his body. The Husband was left with visible scratch marks. He exhibited photographs at Tab C of his affidavit.

95     Amidst this scuffle, the Wife tried to retreat into her room. She lost her balance and fell to the ground. The Husband denies pushing her. He says that she had lost her balance.

96     Having fallen down, the Wife began to “scream and cry loudly”. The Husband retreated from her room. He says that she was able to stand and walk around normally. The Husband went to the living room to wait for the police officers who arrived a few moments later.

97     The Husband’s case is that the Wife had caused hurt to him when she scratched him, and hit him on his neck.[note: 40]

98     Having watched the video, it was clear to me that there was a scuffle between the Wife and the Husband at the entrance to the Wife’s bedroom. The Husband was trying to force his way into the Wife’s bedroom, and she was trying to resist. The video shows the Husband feinting to his left, as though he was about to disengage from the scuffle, before suddenly twisting around and trying to barge past the Wife. The Wife managed to hold her ground, and it was in this context that she had struck his neck. In my judgment, the Wife’s actions do not constitute family violence within the definition of either limb (a) or (b) of s 64 of the Charter.

99     As to the scratches which the Husband had allegedly sustained, he was cross-examined at length on whether the video showed that the Wife had indeed inflicted these scratches on him.[note: 41] He was also cross-examined on the manner in which he had described these scratches in the police he had filed a day after the incident.[note: 42]

100    In my judgment, the Wife had indeed scratched the Husband during this scuffle. The Husband had produced pictures of scratch marks on his body, namely his shoulder and arm. It is also clear from the video that the Wife had indeed grabbed the Husband. Taken together, it is likely that the scratches the Husband sustained were indeed caused by the Wife during the scuffle. I also note that the Husband’s evidence, in his affidavit, that the pictures of the scratch marks on his body were indeed the injuries he had suffered in the altercation with the Wife, was never challenged in cross-examination.

101    That being said, I do not find that this falls within the definition of family violence as set out in limb (b). These were minor scratches. It cannot be said, from the pictures of these scratches the Husband had exhibited, that the Wife had indeed caused hurt to him.

102    Finally, I add that even if the Wife’s acts of hitting the Husband on the neck, and scratching him, were considered acts of family violence, the Wife is entitled to rely on the Self-Defence exception (see XBC v XBD [2024] SGFC 63 at [10] – [13]). The video makes it clear the context in which the Wife had used such force on the Husband. She was trying to stop him from intruding into her personal space. She did not use excessive force in doing so.

The incident on 27 December 2023

103    I come now to the incident on 27 December 2023. The Wife had also relied on this same incident to support her application in SS 217.

104    The Husband’s case is that in this incident, the Wife had committed family violence because she had wrongfully confined or restrained him, together with their son, as well as his elderly parents against their will in the lift.

105    The Husband appears to suggest that because he was never cross-examined on his account of events[note: 43] – that the Wife had, by asking “her boyfriend and mother to hold the lift at the ground floor” and even pressed the alarm button – his account of events should be accepted and so he has proven that the Wife had wrongfully confined or restrained him in the lift.

106    Even accepting the Husband’s account, I do not think that the Wife’s actions fall within the definition of family violence as set out in limb (c) of s 64 of the Charter. As the court in UEJ v UEK [2017] SGFC 90[note: 44] had noted (at [40]), the threshold for wrongful confinement or restraint is higher than a situation where a complainant’s movements were “somewhat restricted” by a respondent for a “certain duration”, and especially where such incidents had occurred in a public place and not in a private or restricted area.

107    Based on the Husband’s account, the Wife had merely tried to prevent him from taking the son back up to their flat. This had occurred in a public area amidst a quarrel between both the Husband and the Wife. Given the Wife’s actions and the circumstances in which she had so acted, I do not find that her actions had crossed into the realm of family violence in that it could be said that she had “wrongfully confined” or “restrained” the Husband.

The Incident on 20 April 2024

108    The Wife had also cited this incident in support of her application for a PPO (above at [57]). In written submissions, the Husband further submitted that this incident would “better support his application for a [PPO] against the Wife”.[note: 45] The Husband cites the fact that the Wife had “intentionally provoked him” in this incident by “video recording him”, “knocking multiple times on his room door” and “knocking on his mother’s room door” although she had already gone to bed.[note: 46]

109    The Wife raises a preliminary objection. She says that the Husband should not be allowed to make a claim based on this incident. That is because this incident was never part of the Husband’s case, and so the Wife never had an opportunity to respond to the allegation which the Husband is now levelling at her.[note: 47]

110    It is well-established that incidents which arise after an application for a PPO has been filed may be taken into account provided that the respondent: a) had not been taken by surprise, and b) had been given sufficient opportunity to respond to the evidence at the trial: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [21(g)] citing Teng Cheng Sin v Law Fay Yuen [2003] 3 SLR(R) 356 at [19] and [20]; Lai Kwok Kin v Teo Zien Jackson [2020] 5 SLR 389 at [57] – [60]; VFM v VFN [2021] SGFC 91 at [44]-[47]; VAW v VAX [2021] SGFC 50 at [52] and [55]; VYW v VYV [2022] SGFC 2 at [32] – [39]; BCY v BCZ [2012] SGDC 360 at [6] – [9].

111    In the present case, the Husband had not included this incident in his complaint form. There is also no account of it given in his affidavit. There was therefore nothing to which the Wife could respond. Given this, I will not take this incident into account in considering the Husband’s application in SS 218.

Whether the Wife is likely to commit family violence

112    As was noted in XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [16], there is no need for an applicant to prove that family violence had been committed. It suffices to establish, on a balance of probabilities, that family violence is likely to be committed against the applicant.

113    An example of when the court has found that family violence is likely to be committed is the recent decision in XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95. In that case, a video tendered to court showed that both the husband and wife in that case had knowingly harassed each other. The video showed both the husband and wife recording each other during their altercation whilst accusing each other of provocation. The court also found that there was “deep and long-standing animosity” between the both of them which was evident from the numerous police reports the both of them had filed, each accusing the other of having committed family violence (XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [12] and [14]).

114    In the present case, I find that the Wife is likely to commit family violence against the Husband. On the evidence put before me, it was clear that the quarrels between both the Wife and the Husband were becoming increasingly heated. That was clear to me from the videos which showed how the Wife had responded in the incident on 11 December 2023, as opposed to how she had responded in the incident on 2 February and 20 April 2024. These videos show the Wife acting in an increasingly confrontational manner towards the Husband.

115    I would add that the additional video which the Husband tendered, which showed a different angle of the incident on 20 April 2024, also showed that the Wife did provoke the Husband. The Wife did not object to this video being produced.[note: 48]

116    That video shows the entirety of the quarrel between the Husband and the Wife on that day. The Husband had gone to the Wife’s room. He knocked on the door. When there was no response, he walked away and took off his shirt. He returned soon after and tried knocking on the Wife’s bedroom door again. After a few attempts, the door opened. The son ran out and into the Husband’s bedroom.

117    The Wife, as well as her mother, came out of their bedroom. They went to knock on the Husband’s bedroom door. The Wife’s mother pulled out her handphone in an attempt to record the Husband’s actions.

118    Frustrated at being filmed, the Husband attempted to grab the handphone from the Wife’s mother. Witnessing this, the Wife goes and knocks on the Husband’s mother’s bedroom door. The argument escalates and the Husband’s mother is dragged into the ensuing argument. The Wife enters the room where the Husband’s mother had been sleeping in and begins shifting various objects out. I must add that unlike the Wife’s mother, who played an active role in the argument, the Husband’s mother can be seen attempting to restrain the Husband and to calm him down.

119    The video clearly shows that the actions of both the Wife, as well as her mother, had only served to provoke the Husband and to escalate matters in that incident. The Wife also agreed, when it was put to her in cross-examination, that she had, by her actions in this incident, intentionally provoked the Husband.[note: 49]

120    When considered in totality, the various video clips which parties had played in court showed an escalation in tensions and aggressions between the parties. The Wife clearly had a role to play in this escalating conflict. She chose to react in a manner that was not only confrontational, but also rather aggressive at times. The manner in which she reacted in all these incidents which were captured on video spoke to the likelihood of her committing family violence against the Husband.

Whether it is necessary to order a PPO and a DEO

121    Having found that the Wife is likely to commit family violence against the Husband, it logically follows that a PPO is presumptively necessary to protect the Husband: XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [21(a)] citing Lai Kwok Kin v Teo Zien Jackson [2020] 5 SLR 389 at [39].

122    Leaving aside the presumption, on the evidence before me, I am satisfied that it is indeed necessary to order a PPO. Parties are still living together in the same flat. They are currently undergoing divorce proceedings. It is also apparent to me that there is a great deal of animosity between them. Given that the both of them still continue to share the same space, it is likely that they will continue to interact and come into contact with each other. This will only provide ample fuel for further conflict (see also my findings above at [75]).

123    In the circumstances, the Husband’s application for a PPO is allowed. This PPO shall be valid for a period of 2 years (ie, until the 19th of February 2027). For the same reasons which I had set out above (at [77]), I find it appropriate, in this case, to limit the PPO to a period of 2 years.

124    However, I do not find it necessary to allow the Husband’s application for a DEO to exclude the Wife from his bedroom. The evidence before me does not show that the Wife had attempted to set foot into the Husband’s bedroom. The Husband’s application for a DEO is dismissed.

Conclusion

125    To summarise, the Wife’s application for a PPO and DEO is allowed. I am also granting the Husband’s application for a PPO, but not for a DEO.

126    Unless parties are able to agree, I shall hear parties on costs.

127    Finally, I conclude with some brief remarks to both the Husband and the Wife:

(a)     I have made the relevant orders against the both of you. There are consequences if it is found that you have wilfully breached those orders: s 65(10) of the Women’s Charter 1961.

(b)     Stop fighting. You have a young son. These are his formative years. Do not let his childhood be sullied by the bitterness of your quarrels. Focus on how the both of you can work together to give your son the best possible start in life.

(c)     Treat the counselling sessions seriously. They are meant to help you.

128    It remains for me to thank Mr Cha, Ms Yeo and Mr Leong for their able assistance.

counsel: Ho Shiao Hong and Yap Tong Hitomi (M/s Quahe Woo & Palmer LLC) for the Complainant
