html:
XHW v XHX

XHW v XHX
[2025] SGFC 12

Case Number:Divorce No 4355 of 2023 (Summons No 3472 of 2024)
Decision Date:27 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Chan Xian Yi, Jonathan (Zeng Xianyi) (Chia Wong Chambers LLC) for the plaintiff; Lim Fang-Yu Mathea (PKWA Law Practice LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XHW — XHX

Family Law – Procedure – Discovery

Family Law – Procedure – Interrogatories

27 January 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       Parties were married in the United Kingdom sometime in July 2009. They lived in various countries until 2019, when they decided to settle down in Singapore. It was also in 2019 that parties welcomed the one and only child to their marriage.

2       In this case, it was the Wife who had filed for divorce on 8 September 2023, citing the Husband’s unreasonable behaviour as the reason behind the irretrievable breakdown of their marriage.

3       The Statement of Particulars (Amendment No 1) sets out details of how their marriage had broken down, as well as details of their habitual residence in Singapore, which forms the basis for this court’s jurisdiction over their divorce.

4       Interim judgment was obtained on 25 January 2024. Thereafter, parties plotted a course for the hearing of the ancillary matters. It is in this context that the Wife has taken out an application for discovery and interrogatories vide SUM 3472/2024 (“SUM 3472”).

5       I heard the application on the bulk list and reserved judgment. This is my decision.

Wife’s Application for Interrogatories

6       It is well established that the court will only order interrogatories if those interrogatories are both relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters: WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC at [22]. It is also well established that the court, at the interlocutory stage, is not concerned with the truth of any answers given to an interrogatory, but rather, whether that answer is sufficient: WXG v WXH [2024] SGFC 32 at [9] – [11]; WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [28] – [30].

7       At the hearing before me, counsel for the Wife, Mr Jonathan Chan (“Mr Chan”) confirmed that, where the interrogatories were concerned, the Wife was only proceeding in respect of four out of the five items which she had originally sought in SUM 3472. I shall deal with them in turn.

8       I first deal with the Wife’s request in Items 1 and 3:

(a)     Item 1 was a request for the Husband to state and explain the whereabouts and purpose of several recurring withdrawals/payments from his HSBC account ending -21. These transactions ranged in value from £500 – £990.

(b)     Item 3 was a request for the Husband to state and explain the current whereabouts and purpose(s) of the several recurring monthly withdrawals from his HSBC premier account ending -1.

9       Counsel for the Husband, Ms Mathea Lim (“Ms Lim”), argued that the Husband should not have to answer these interrogatories on the basis that the transactions involved are insubstantial. In support of this argument, they cite my earlier decisions in XDD v XEE [2024] SGFC 79 and WXE v WXF [2024] SGFC 29 for the proposition that the process of discovery and interrogatories should not be used as an exercise in forensic accounting. Ms Lim had also highlighted in written submissions that the Husband had explained that these transactions made in the UK were for the payment of bills, and that they have been made on a regular basis since the family had relocated to Singapore.[note: 1]

10     I do not find that the Wife’s request in Items 1 and 3 was an attempt to engage in a forensic accounting exercise. I agree with the point Mr Chan had made – that these expenses, which were not insignificant, were rather odd given that the parties had relocated from the UK to Singapore. In this vein, it is clear to me that this interrogatory is indeed relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – it would show why the Husband had continued to incur and pay for expenses in the UK although parties were no longer living there, and how he had managed to do so especially given that he had stated that he had been unemployed for the past 3 years.[note: 2] This would have a bearing on issues such as whether there had been dissipation of matrimonial assets, the Husband’s financial capacity to pay for child maintenance, and whether there were any other undisclosed bank accounts or credit cards in the Husband’s name.

11     For the reasons set out above, the Wife’s request in Items 1 and 3 is allowed.

12     Item 2 was a request for the Husband to “state and explain the sum(s) of monies” which he had allegedly loaned to his helper, and to provide details of when such loans had been disbursed and what was the outstanding sum loaned to date.

13     The basis for the Husband’s objection is that a voluntary request had not first been served. Mr Chan does not dispute that no voluntary request had been served. He explained that the Wife had taken such a course of action in a bid to avoid protracting proceedings.

14     Notwithstanding the fact that a voluntary request for Item 2 had not first been served, I am still minded to deal with the Wife’s request on its merits, though I would add that the failure to comply with the applicable rules of procedure may be a relevant consideration when it comes to costs.

15     I find that Item 2 is indeed relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. The quantum of the loan which the Husband had extended to their helper certainly goes towards the determination of the matrimonial pool of assets.

16     As a final point, I note that the Wife did, in fact, ask the Husband in her voluntary request for discovery, to disclose documents showing payments made to their helper. The Husband had provided a rather detailed explanation as to why such payments were made and why such payments were no longer reflected on the relevant bank statements. The Husband’s explanation, however, does not state the sums which he had loaned to the helper, and the outstanding sums that are still owed to him.[note: 3] These are all pertinent points that would have a bearing on the issues at the hearing of the ancillary matters.

17     The Wife’s request in Item 2 is allowed.

18     I come now to the final request in Item 4. This was the request as framed:

The Defendant is to state and confirm whether the flat in Seoul, South Korea at [XXX] is the only South Korean property he and his parents own and have ever owned, and if not, the address and particulars of ownership of any other property owned by the Defendant or his parents.

19     Although it is undisputed that a voluntary request in respect of this item had not been served, as I had stated above (at [14]), I am not minded to dismiss the Wife’s request on that basis. In my judgment, this interrogatory is certainly relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – any properties in the Husband’s name, or that are being held on the Husband’s behalf are certainly a relevant consideration when it comes to determining the matrimonial pool of assets as well as the division of such assets.

20     The Wife’s request in Item 4 is allowed.

Wife’s Application for Discovery

21     I come now to the items which the Wife had sought in discovery. In considering the Wife’s application, I bear in mind the principles that govern the discovery process, namely, that the court will only order discovery if the documents sought are relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters: WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [22].

22     During the hearing, Mr Chan confirmed that the Wife was not pursuing her request in respect of Items 4, 9, and 11. I shall deal with the rest of the items in turn. I will also make brief mention of Item 9 given the points that were raised by both Mr Chan and Ms Lim at the hearing before me.

23     Item 1 was a request for the Husband to produce documents showing the disbursements, transactions and purpose of loans taken from January 2023 to date.

24     The Husband does not dispute the relevance or the necessity of these documents. Rather, his position is that he has no such documents in his possession, custody or power.

25     As I had noted in WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [75], parties cannot “tiptoe around” their obligation to give discovery with the mere assertion that they do not have the documents which are requested for. The Husband cannot sidestep his obligation to provide disclosure with the bare assertion that he has no such documents in his possession, custody or power.

26     I will allow the Wife’s request in Item 1. If the Husband says that he does not have these documents, he must provide an explanation on affidavit, and exhibit any supporting documents.

27     Item 2 was a request for documents showing the current whereabouts and purpose of various recurring withdrawals from the Husband’s HSBC account ending -21. This mirrored Item 1 of the Wife’s request for interrogatories (see above at [8(a)]).

28     I will allow the Wife’s request in Item 2 for the same reasons which I had set out above (at [10]). Although Ms Lim urged me to disallow the Wife’s request in respect of this item on the account that the sums in question were insubstantial, and that the process of discovery and interrogatories should not be used as a tool to aid in a forensic accounting exercise, as I have explained, the documents sought would cast light on why the Husband had continued to incur these expenses in the UK although parties were no longer living there.

29     Item 3 was a request for documents showing that the Husband had temporarily borrowed a sum of $2000 from one [K] on 26 June 2023, the whereabouts of this sum, and the purpose of the alleged loan.[note: 4]

30     The Husband’s basis for objecting to this request was that he had already provided all the documents in his possession, custody and power. He states that there was no written documentation in relation to these loans which were extended to him by friends.[note: 5]

31     The Wife, on the other hand, argues that disclosure should be ordered because the Husband has repeatedly made claims that various deposits and withdrawals from his bank accounts are loans/repayment of loans, but did not provide any supporting documents to back up his assertions.[note: 6] During the hearing, Mr Chan emphasised the point in his oral submissions that if these were indeed loans made from the Husband’s friends, there would be some messages to evidence such an arrangement. In this connection, these messages would go towards establishing the liabilities which the Husband now claims to have.

32     I note that the Husband’s explanation, that this transaction was repayment of a loan given to him by [K], was his response to the Wife’s voluntary request for discovery. It is a bare explanation. The Husband simply stated that it was a temporary loan from [K] made on 26 June 2023. He did not state any reasons as to why he could not produce the requested documents, neither did he state that he did not have any documents in his possession, custody or power given the nature of the loan.

33     In the circumstances, I will allow the request in respect of Item 3. The documents are, in my judgment, certainly relevant and necessary. It would go towards assessing whether this transaction was indeed for the repayment of the loan as the Husband alleges.

34     I come now to Items 5 and 6. I shall deal with them together as they both concern various deposits which had been made to the Husband’s UOB account ending -8. These were the specific requests as framed:

(a)     Item 5 was a request for documents to show that various deposits into the Husband’s UOB account ending -8 was for alleged “loans” extended to him for his living expenses and legal fees.

(b)     Item 6 was a request for documents showing the source as well as the purpose of various deposits made by certain individuals into the Husband’s UOB account ending -8.

35     The Husband objects to both Items 5 and 6 on the same basis as Item 3 – that he had already disclosed all the documents in his possession, custody and power, and that because these were loans which had been extended to him by family and friends, there was no documentation of any such loan agreements.

36     The Wife’s argument in respect of Items 5 and 6 was that that these were rather substantial deposits to the Husband’s UOB account. Accordingly, these documents would establish whether they were indeed loans extended to the Husband, or proceeds from any other sources of income or funds that the Husband had yet to disclose. This would have a bearing on issues such as determining the matrimonial pool of assets, the division of matrimonial assets and the Husband’s ability to pay maintenance.[note: 7]

37     Again, I note that in the Husband’s response to the Wife’s voluntary request for the same documents as set out in Items 5 and 6,[note: 8] he explained that these were “monies loaned” to allow him to pay for his living expenses and legal fees in Singapore and that there were “no documents for the said loans” “save for those already previously provided”. The Husband merely asserts that there are no documents, but does not go on to explain why that is the case.

38     In my judgment, both Items 5 and 6 are certainly relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. It would allow the court to assess the source of these deposits into the Husband’s account and the reasons for these deposits. This would, as Mr Chan had rightly pointed out in written submissions (see above at [36]), have a bearing on issues such as ascertaining the matrimonial pool of assets and maintenance.

39     The Wife’s request in both Items 5 and 6 are allowed.

40     I turn now to Item 7. This was a request for the Husband to produce documents showing the source of funds and the purpose for various deposits from company [T] to the Husband’s UOB account ending -8.

41     Again, the Husband objects to this request on the basis that he had already provided all the documents in his possession, custody and power.[note: 9] He says that these were loans extended to him by his family which had been transferred to him via a wire transfer service provider which was reflected as company [T] on his bank statements.

42     The Wife, on the other hand, argues that these documents are relevant to showing the source of such funds which are relevant to issues such as ascertaining the pool of matrimonial assets, whether there had been dissipation of any matrimonial assets and maintenance.[note: 10]

43     I agree with the arguments advanced by the Wife – these documents would show the source of the funds, and would, accordingly, shed light on the Husband’s true financial capacity and whether these were indeed, as he says, loans extended to him by his family. This would go towards issues such as ascertaining the matrimonial pool of assets as well as maintenance.

44     The Wife’s request in Item 7 is allowed.

45     Item 8 was a request for documents showing the current whereabouts and purpose of several recurring transactions from the Husband’s HSBC premier account ending -1. This request mirrored the Wife’s request for interrogatories at Item 3 (see above at [8(b)]).

46     Given that I had allowed the Wife’s request for interrogatories, I will also allow this request for discovery. The Husband shall answer the Wife’s interrogatory as framed in Item 3 and provide the relevant documents requested. In my judgment, these documents sought are indeed relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters – they would cast light on why the Husband had, by his account,[note: 11] continued to pay for bills incurred in the UK although the family had since relocated to Singapore.

47     Item 9 was a request for documents showing the source of funds and purpose of some 21 deposits into the Husband’s HSBC premier account ending -1.

48     During the hearing, Mr Chan explained that the Wife was no longer pursuing Item 9 given the Husband’s response in his reply affidavit to SUM 3472. That being said, the Husband had also disclosed the existence of two other credit cards which he had not previously disclosed. Given this, the Wife now wanted the statements of these credit cards.

49     Ms Lim, naturally, objected to this. She said that the Wife was now shifting the goalposts of her application.

50     I did not think that this was necessarily the case. As I had explained to Ms Lim during the hearing, my understanding was that the Wife was merely seeking further discovery of the statements of these two credit cards which had now surfaced.

51     In any event, even if Mr Chan was asking that I order the disclosure of these two credit card statements, I was not minded to consider the request given that it was not included in SUM 3472, and the Husband did not appear to have had the opportunity to consider the request. In the circumstances, I directed that any further voluntary request for interrogatories and discovery be filed and served by 27 January 2025. The Husband was to give his response by 17 February 2025. I also further directed parties to attend at a Case Conference after 17 February 2025 to update the court on the status of the voluntary request and whether a formal application would be required.

52     I come now to the final request in Item 10. This was a request for documents showing that the Husband had received retrenchment benefits as well as 3 months’ worth of salary in lieu of notice. These sums of money had allegedly been paid to the Husband’s HSBC Singapore account in May 2022.

53     The Husband argues that the Wife’s request should be disallowed. He says that he had already obtained the relevant bank statement, and sought the Wife’s consent to file a further affidavit to SUM 3472 to exhibit this statement. However, the Wife did not reply. As such, this bank statement was annexed to his written submissions.[note: 12]

54     During the course of the hearing, Mr Chan argued that the sums which the Husband alleges had been paid to him as part of his retrenchment package does not match that in the bank statement which the Husband had belatedly disclosed. The Wife was therefore maintaining her request in Item 10, and sought a court order for the Husband to produce these documents.

55     It appears that the Wife is continuing the maintain her request in Item 10 because of the discrepancy between the bank statement the Husband had produced, and what he had previously declared. However, the discovery and interrogatory process is not an avenue for parties to ventilate arguments on where the truth may lie in relation to matters which are in dispute. Given that the Husband has produced a bank statement that appears to reflect the deposit of his retrenchment benefits, I make no order in relation to Item 10. I will, however, order the Husband to exhibit this bank statement in his compliance affidavit.

56     In summary, I make the following orders:

(a)     The Husband shall answer the interrogatories as set out in Items 1 – 4 of the Request for Interrogatories (as indicated at para 2b of SUM 3472) on affidavit, to the best of his knowledge, information and belief, pursuant to Rule 69 of the Family Justice Rules 2014.

(b)     The Husband shall state on affidavit, pursuant to Rule 63 of the Family Justice Rules 2014, in respect of each of the following documents listed in Items 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, and 8 of the Request for Discovery (as indicated at para 1b of SUM 3472), whether the same is in his possession, custody or power, and if not then in his possession, custody or power, when he parted with it and what has become of it;

(c)     The Husband shall exhibit, in the affidavit, a copy of each of the documents that are in his possession, custody or power. If any of the documents are not in his custody, power or possession, he is to state the reasons why, together with supporting documentation for his explanation (if any).

(d)     The Husband shall also exhibit, in his compliance affidavit, the bank statement contained in Annex A of his Written Submissions dated 10 January 2025.

(e)     In addition, the Husband’s compliance affidavit is to be filed by 24 February 2025.

57     Unless parties are able to agree on costs of SUM 3472, they are to write in, by way of letter, with their respective submissions on costs. This is to be done no later than 14 February 2025 and the length of these submissions shall not exceed 3 pages.

58     For the avoidance of doubt, nothing I have said here shall bind the judge hearing the ancillary matters. The time limited for filing an appeal shall also begin to run from the date of this judgment.

59     Finally, it remains for me to thank Mr Chan and Ms Lim for their able assistance.

XHY v XHZ

XHY v XHZ
[2025] SGFC 13

Case Number:Divorce No 4534 of 2023
Decision Date:05 February 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Nicole Loh
Counsel Name(s): Mr Thirumurthy Ayernaar Pambayan (Murthy & Co) for the plaintiff; Mr Patrick Fernandez (Fernandez LLC) for the defendant
Parties: XHY — XHZ

Family Law – custody – access, care and control

Family Law – maintenance – child

Family Law – matrimonial assets – division

5 February 2025

District Judge Nicole Loh:

Introduction

1       The Wife filed for divorce on 20 September 2023, leading to an Interim Judgment for divorce being granted on 21 May 2024 on both the Wife’s claim and the Husband’s amended Counterclaim. The ancillary issues relating to custody, care and control, access of the children, division of matrimonial assets, wife maintenance and cost were adjourned to chambers.

2       The ancillary matters proceeded for hearing on 7 January 2025 and my decision was delivered through Registrar’s Notice on 8 January 2025. The Wife has since appealed all of my orders.

Facts

The parties

3       Both parties are about 37 years of age and gainfully employed. The Wife was a senior Office Administrator and the Husband a freelance driver. At the time of the divorce, parties had been married for almost 9.5 years. There are 2 children born of their marriage, a son (turning 9 years in 2025) and a daughter (turning 7 years old in 2025). The Wife and children left the matrimonial home in March 2023. She applied for maintenance under section 69 of the Women’s Charter and a by consent order for the Husband to pay $350 per month for each child’s maintenance was recorded without prejudice to her rights and claims for child maintenance in the divorce proceedings. There is also a Personal Protection Order against the Husband in favour of the Wife.

Background to the dispute

4       At the hearing of the Ancillary Matters, I was informed by both counsel that parties are in agreement with the following:

(a)     Parties shall have joint custody of the children;

(b)     Wife is not making a claim for her maintenance;

(c)     Husband shall pay the outstanding SP Services/utilities bills for the matrimonial flat incurred after March 2023; and

(d)     Husband shall pay the outstanding Town Council Service and Conservancy charges for the matrimonial flat from March 2023 until the sale of the flat;

(e)     Husband shall pay 50% of the year end school books and uniform expenses.

5       I accordingly ordered the above by consent as part of my eventual order.

Issues to be determined

6       The issues before me for determination were:

(a)     Care and control of the children and if shared care was not granted, access;

(b)     Division of matrimonial assets; and

(c)     Maintenance for the children.

Issue 1: Care and control and access

7       The Wife asked for care and control of the children to be granted to her and the Husband asked for shared care and control of the children.

8       The Wife, in support of her claim, detailed her involvement in the care of the children since birth and in particular, how she became a homemaker for about 5 years before returning to employment.

9       The Husband, in support of his case for shared care and control, points to the current arrangement since March 2023, wherein he has the children from Friday 6pm to Sunday 6pm. He therefore submitted this should continue since it is workable.

10     I do not find the current arrangements of timing that the Husband has with the children equates to a shared care and control order. It only provides for time the children spend with him. A shared care and control arrangement works in the interest of children if both parents are highly co-operative and willing to mutually discuss effective and reach agreements with regard to the daily activities of the children, e.g. which day the children go for what classes (without overly being calculative about how much care time that parent loses for example) so that the children’s daily life is seamless even when they switch homes. I do not believe the parties in this case have such a relationship. I find that the Wife has been the main caregiver of the children, therefore I grant her care and control in view of her involvement with the children since birth, their current young age and that they live primarily with her.

Access

11     Having granted care and control to the Wife, the issue of access to the Husband arises. The following access was agreed:

(a)     Deepavali from 2pm to 8pm; and

(b)     Alternate public holidays (except Deepavali) from 10am to 9pm.

12     As submitted by the Husband[note: 1], he has had time with the children from Fridays 6pm to Sundays 6pm since March 2023. There were no allegations of violence from him towards the children. No issues have been raised by the Wife with regard to the time the children were with him since so he should have the same timing for access. He also sought half of the March, June, September and year end school holidays with liberty to travel and midweek dinner access.

13     Although the Wife had raised issues with overnight access in her affidavits and concerns over the children’s safety in view of the Husband’s violent behaviour, there was no response from the Wife about the current arrangements described by the Husband that have been in place for more than 1.5 years. The Wife submitted that weekend time should be carved out for her as well and that March and September school holidays were a short one week so there was no need to grant half to the Husband. There was also a concern raised as to whether the Husband would exercise access faithfully in view of the uncertainty of the Husband’s hours of work.

14     I accept that the Wife should also have some time on the weekends to spend with the children as she would have little opportunity to plan any leisure activities if she only has the weekdays when the children are in school and she is at work. I also accept that there is evidence to support her allegations of family violence by the Husband towards her but there is no evidence of any such behaviour towards the children. The fact that the Husband has been having overnight weekend access without incidents for more than 1.5 years also allay any concerns. As for his working hours, I accept the Husband’s submission that he can arrange for his work to be scheduled around access time given that it is flexible. There were no instances raised to show that he has not shown up for access. I am also wary of reducing access periods only on a speculative problem. Furthermore, plans can change even within an intact family. It is for parties to communicate and make alternative arrangements to deal with the change in plans.

15     Access time is to enable the children to continue to have a bond with a parent whom they do not live with primarily. I therefore granted half of the school holidays (including the March and September school holidays) and a midweek access bearing in mind the children’s routine given the following day would be a weekday. For completeness, even though the March and September school holidays are relatively shorter school holidays compared to the June and year-end school holidays, there is no reason not to give the Husband and children the opportunity for access. After all, public holidays (usually a brief one-day holiday) are also commonly shared between parents. I also allowed both parties the liberty to bring the children overseas during their time with the children.

16     I therefore made the following orders for access (including those by consent as set out in paragraph 11 above):

(a)     During school term,

(i)       Weekly from Friday 6pm to Saturday 8pm;

(ii)       Wednesdays from 5:40pm to 7:30pm;

(b)     Half of the March, June, September and year end school holidays;

(c)     Either party is at liberty to take the children overseas during their time with the children upon at least 14 days advance notice to the other party with the travel itinerary and contact details.

Issue 2: Division of Assets

18     The Wife’s submissions listed certain liabilities such as legal costs ($6,000), diner’s card ($8,000) and a trust loan ($5,884.02) but it was not clear if she sought the same to be deducted from the pool of matrimonial assets. With regard to legal fees of parties, following UZN v UZM [2020] SGCA 109, they should not be deducted from the pool of matrimonial assets but each party should settle their own legal costs from their respective share of the assets. There was no supporting document for the diner’s card whilst statements for the loan were provided from April 2024. There was no evidence of the liabilities as at the date of the Interim Judgment or that they were incurred for the benefit of the family. Therefore I did not deduct the Wife’s liabilities from the pool of matrimonial assets.

19     Parties’ direct financial contribution was also not disputed:

Although both parties asserted in affidavits they were responsible for the renovation costs of the matrimonial flat, no proof was provided by either party and at the hearing, it was agreed that this would be disregarded.

20     The Wife claimed that 80% of indirect contributions during the marriage should be attributed to her whereas the Husband claimed 60% in his favour.

21     I took into account the fact that this marriage lasted 9.5 years and it was undisputed that the Wife stopped work soon after the marriage to care for the children until she resumed work about 5 years later. It was conceded the Husband provided the financial support for the family although the exact amount he provided was disputed. He claimed to have provided his entire salary which was between $2,000 to $7,000 previously. When the Wife started work, he stopped providing his entire salary but still provided $3,000 to $4,000. The Wife disputed the amounts he claimed to have provided but asserted that he gave her $2,000 monthly, which he at times took back from her when he ran out of money. There was no evidence to support either party’s claim.

22     Using a broad brush approach, I considered that generally the Wife was the main caregiver whilst the Husband was the breadwinner for about half their marriage. In addition, in the later half of the marriage, the Wife also contributed financially towards the family when she started work. I therefore attribute 60% of the indirect contributions to her and 40% to the Husband.

23     Both parties applied equal weightage between direct and indirect contributions and the final share of the matrimonial assets would be 50.6% to the Wife and 49.4% to the Husband.

24     Out of the pool of matrimonial assets, each party would retain their own assets. The Wife’s 50.6% of $519,720.26 amounts to $262,750.75. After deducting $34,569.41 which is already retained by her, she is entitled to $228,181.34 from the matrimonial flat. This amounts to 51% of the net value of the matrimonial flat.

25     I therefore ordered:

(a)     The matrimonial assets shall be divided 50.6% to the Wife and 49.4% to the Husband. In this regard, the matrimonial flat shall be sold in the open market within 6 months from the Final Judgment. The net sale proceeds (after repayment of the outstanding mortgage loan and cost and expenses of sale) shall be divided 51% to the Wife and 49% to the Husband. Each party to refund their CPF accounts for monies utilised in the acquisition of the matrimonial flat including accrued interest from their respective share of the net sale proceeds. Parties to have joint conduct of sale.

Issue 3: Children Maintenance

26     The children’s monthly expenses were determined as follows:

27     The Husband challenged items 8, 9 and 10 of the expense list. For item 8, both children are Singapore citizens enrolled in a local primary school. The school fees is listed as $13 per child and there is no explanation or evidence to prove the Wife’s claim that their school fee is $32.50 per child. I determined the school fees as $13/child.

28     In WBU v WBT [2023] SGHCF 3, it was held that

“It follows that in seeking to quantify the child’s reasonable expenses, parties should avoid an overly mathematical approach where receipts are adduced to prove every single item of expenditure. This is not to say that no evidence is ever required to support proposals for what is sought as reasonable maintenance; it depends on the type of expenses sought, and of course, on the facts of each case……It may be helpful for parties to apply their minds to drafting up what can be described as a “budget”, whereby broad categories of the child’s estimated needs are identified, and a corresponding reasonable sum is proposed for each category..”

29     For enrichment/tuition, the Wife claimed a monthly expense per child of $340. This accounted for a substantive 1/3 of her expense claim for the children but there was no evidence on this expenditure or what it entailed. Not every child requires enrichment/tuition. Different types of enrichment and/or tuition will affect the reasonable amount to be budgeted for a child. Without any evidence as to any enrichment/tuition that the children are enrolled in and their costs, I excluded this claim. With regard to hobbies/sports claim of $135 per child, similarly there was a lack of evidence on this expense. However, I accept that it is reasonable for all children to have some form of hobbies and sports. Without any other evidence to assist me in in determining the reasonable sum based on the hobby or sports the child engages in, I allocated $60 per child per month for this expense on a broad budgeting basis.

30     The Wife’s take home income is $2,913 and submits the Husband should have a higher income than what is declared because:

(a)     Previously in the marriage when they were together, his income was $7,000 and this is proven by his self-declaration of providing $3,000 to the Wife monthly previously; and

(b)     He continues to be in the same field of work so his income should remain the same.

31     The Husband disputes earning $7,000 or $5,000, a figure was used by the Wife’s Counsel to submit he should pay more maintenance. He declared he earned an average of about $3,600 from his jobs. He exhibited his Notice of Assessment which shows he earned $48,000 in one year, i.e. $4,000 per month.

32     I had difficulty accepting the Wife’s argument regarding the Husband’s past income because it is based on the Husband’s assertion which she has expressly disputed. If she wants the Court to disbelieve that he didn’t provide as much financial support as he claimed for the purposes of dividing matrimonial assets, she cannot then flip her entire position to now claim it is true for the purposes of child maintenance.

33     The Husband has provided supporting evidence of his current income and there is no evidence to find that he has a higher income currently. Nonetheless, the Husband offered to bear 64% of the children’s expenses, which I find is a fair proposal given that he earns about 58% of their combined income. I therefore ordered him to pay 64% of $1,306 which amounts to $835.84. I rounded this up to $840 in total (i.e. $420 per child).

Conclusion

34     In view of both parties’ practical and reasonable approaches during the hearing before me and also in view that neither party really succeeded fully on any particular point, I made no order as to cost.

[note: 1]Paragraph 22 of Husband’s 2nd affidavit

XHQ v XHR

XHQ v XHR
[2025] SGFC 10

Case Number:MSS 1648 of 2024
Decision Date:27 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The complainant in person and unrepresented; The respondent in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XHQ — XHR

Family Law – Maintenance – Enforcement

27 January 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       Parties were divorced in 2016. Pursuant to an order of court (“FC/ORC xx/2016”), the Father was ordered to pay $500 as monthly maintenance for the two children of the marriage. This sum was to be deposited into the Mother’s bank account on the last day of every month.

2       On 19 July 2024, the Mother applied for an enforcement of maintenance arrears vide MSS 1648/2024 (“MSS 1648”). The matter was fixed for hearing, and I heard the trial on 1 November 2024.

3       Towards the end of the trial, it was discovered that the Father had been recording the proceedings.[note: 1] A check done by the court officer showed two audio recordings of the trial on his phone. By recording the proceedings, the Father was in contempt of court: s 5 of the Administration of Justice (Protection) Act 2016. The Father was given an opportunity to purge his contempt: You Xin v Public Prosecutor and another appeal [2007] 4 SLR(R) 17 at [54]. He did so by deleting those recordings and confirmed that he had not disseminated any recordings made. He also apologised for his conduct. Assured that there would be no repeat of this behaviour, I decided it was appropriate to not take cognisance of the contempt and proceeded with the remainder of the trial.

4       After the trial, I reserved my judgment. On the 15th of November 2024, I handed down my decision where I allowed the Mother’s application and made the relevant orders.

5       These are the reasons for my decision.

6       When it comes to the enforcement of maintenance orders, s 71 of the Women’s Charter 1961 sets out what the court may do in the event that an order to pay maintenance has not been complied with. This, of course, assumes that the maintenance order should be enforced, and in that vein, it has been held that “the quintessential characteristic of enforcement proceedings is for a respondent to be given a chance to “show cause” (ie, provide reasons which are satisfactory to the Court) why an enforcement order should not be made against him or her”: VUJ v VUK [2021] SGFC 87 (“VUJ”)[note: 2] at [20] citing Lai Ching Kin v Ng Chin Chye [2001] SGDC 228; WUG v WUH [2024] SGFC 11 at [9][note: 3].

7       As to when a respondent to an enforcement application has shown cause, that is an assessment which must, naturally, turn on the facts. At the end of the day, what is important to bear in mind is whether the making of an enforcement order would “lead to injustice and/or where it would be inequitable to do so given the circumstances and facts of a given case”: VUJ at [22].

8       To give a flavour of the sort of circumstances in which a respondent had been found by the Family Courts to have shown cause, I reproduce the succinct summary in VUJ at [21]:

(a)    where the parties had mutually agreed to a reduction of the amount payable pursuant to maintenance order or where there was an understanding (whether implicit or explicit) between the parties not to require strict compliance with the terms of the said order (see for eg., Lai Ching Kin v Ng Chin Chye [2001] SGDC 228 at [15], UAE v UAF [2017] SGFC 46 at [24] – [28] and VAM v VAN [2019] SGFC 96)

(b)    where the respondent had went over and beyond what was required under the maintenance order and/or had provided additional support to the complainant even though the payment modality may not have been exactly in accordance with the terms of the maintenance order (see TDR v TDS [2014] SGDC 183 at [22] – [27]);

(c)    where a complainant had used monies belonging to the respondent to pay for expenses which were within the scope of the maintenance order such that the respondent should be treated as having paid for those expenses (see for eg. TXY v TXZ [2017] SGFC 21); and

(d)    where a respondent had a good track record of payment but is facing genuine financial difficulties in keeping up with the payments (see for eg. VSP v VSQ [2021] SGFC 71, a case involving financial difficulties brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic).

9       At the trial, there was no dispute between the parties as to the arrears owed which came in at $3000 as of 1st November 2024. The real contention between the parties was whether the Father had given good reasons as to why these arrears should not be enforced against him, specifically, whether the Father’s medical condition was a good reason for his non-payment.

10     The Father gave evidence that he used to work as an IT engineer.[note: 4] However, he had not been working this year owing to his medical condition. He testified that he had been admitted to hospital for treatment, and that he had a heart attack on 11 June 2024. Later, on 12 August 2024, he underwent cardiac surgery. The doctors had told him that a complete recovery would take approximately 6 months.

11     The Father also told me that he intended to look for work once he had fully recovered.[note: 5] In his estimation, he figured that he would be able to resume his obligation to pay child maintenance once he managed to find a job that was not too physically taxing.[note: 6]

12     I did not doubt that the Father had a serious heart condition, or that he had had surgery. Signs that he had undergone surgery were plainly evident from the medical tubes protruding from beneath his shirt. In addition, the Father had also produced a bundle of medical certificates from the hospital which showed that he had been in and out of hospital since March 2024. There was also a letter from the doctor stating that the Father was receiving inpatient medical care, including cardiac surgery.

13     The Father explained that notwithstanding his medical condition which had put him out of work since January 2024, he had tried his best to continue paying maintenance. He had drawn down on his savings to do so, and his current wife had also chipped in.[note: 7] He told me that his savings were down to $100, and that his current wife was shouldering the financial burden during this time. When quizzed about his current medical expenses, the Father said that he was paying roughly $200 each month.[note: 8]

14     The Father, however, had not put any documents (ie, bank statements) in evidence to support his assertion that he was cash-strapped as a result of his medical condition and therefore could not afford the $500 monthly maintenance.

15     That being said, I add that there are also two pieces of evidence which, to my mind, pointed to the real reason behind the Father’s failure to keep up with the maintenance payments.

16     The first was his response to the Mother’s question. She had asked why he could not simply have responded to her repeated text messages chasing him for payment to say that he could not pay.[note: 9]

17     The Father’s response was that the Mother was only concerned with getting the money.[note: 10] When he was hospitalised, she did not enquire as to how he was doing, but rather, kept hounding him for the monthly payments. The Father went on to add that he was not spending time with the children despite having gone through supervised visitation.[note: 11] He told me that he wanted to spend time with the children, but the Mother did not allow that.

18     The second was a text message dated 12 June 2024. The Father’s current wife had texted the Mother, using his phone, to inform her that the Father was unwell and that the money would be transferred. The money owed, however, was never transferred and the Mother continued to hound the Father for payment. I would also note from the screenshots which the Father produced, that it is clear that the Mother did send rather nasty text messages to him in demanding for payment owed under the maintenance order.

19     It appears to me that the Father may well have ceased payment because of his frustration with the Mother’s attitude and her continued refusal to let him see the children. I would add that if it were indeed the case that the Father had intended to keep up with his maintenance obligations, but could not afford to do so, he could have sent the Mother a text, providing her with details about his health condition and asked for more time to make payment. Instead, there was radio silence. And while the Father chalks this up to his hospitalisation after surgery, he had more than 3 months to at least send a simple response to the Mother’s repeated text messages. He did not do so.

20     I therefore did not find that the Father had shown cause as to why the arrears should not be enforced. Although the Father was still recovering from a heart operation, he had not managed to show that his medical condition put him in such dire financial straits such that he simply could not afford to pay the $500 monthly maintenance for the children.

21     I thus allowed the Mother’s application in MSS 1648 to enforce the arrears of $3000 and made the following orders:

(a)     The Father shall pay off these arrears in monthly instalments of $100, starting from April 2025;

(b)     This sum of $100 shall be paid on the last day of every month; directly to the Mother’s stipulated bank account;

(c)     For the avoidance of doubt, maintenance that is owed under the current order remains payable.

[note: 3]The appeal against the DJ’s decision vide HCF/DCA 108/2023 was dismissed on 24 April 2024.

html:
XHA v XHB

XHA v XHB
[2025] SGFC 9

Case Number:Divorce No 2865 of 2023 (Summons No 3376 and 3318 of 2024)
Decision Date:20 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The plaintiff in person and unrepresented; Luke Anton Netto (Netto & Magin LLC) for the defendant.
Parties: XHA — XHB

Family Law – Costs

20 January 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       This is my decision on the costs of SUMs 3376 and 3318 of 2024. Both applications had been taken out by the Wife who sought orders in relation to discovery and interrogatories.

2       These were the parties’ submissions in respect of costs.

3       Counsel for the Husband, Mr Netto, argued in written submissions, that it was the Wife who should be, pursuant to Rule 857(1)(b) of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (the “FJR 2014”), liable for costs to the tune of $500.[note: 1] This was because the Wife had failed to, prior to taking out SUMs 3376 and 3318, serve a voluntary request for discovery and interrogatories on the Husband. This meant that the Husband had no opportunity to respond to the voluntary request.

4       Mr Netto further pointed out that while the Wife was self-represented, the learned Assistant Registrar had, in a case conference on 14 November 2024, highlighted that an “application for discovery and/or interrogatories ought to be in relation to existing request(s) where one party did not receive a satisfactory response to”, and that there could be cost consequences if one were to proceed with their application without first taking out a voluntary request.[note: 2]

5       Finally, Mr Netto argued that the Wife should be ordered to pay costs to signal, to parties, the importance and necessity of complying with the rules of procedure which are meant to ensure “fairness and equity in the proceedings”.[note: 3]

6       The Wife, on the other hand, took the position that she was entitled to costs in respect of both SUMs 3376 and 3318. She gave the following reasons. First, that apart from incurring $221.80 in the filing of both summonses, she had also spent a great deal of time and effort in learning how to navigate the “complex legal processes without the benefit of formal legal training”. Second, the Wife highlighted the Husband’s conduct, namely, that he would alternate between verbal threats and passive indifference which “created unnecessary delays and heightened emotional distress”.[note: 4] The Husband’s behaviour took a toll on her which necessitated sessions with a psychologist.

7       Where costs are concerned, it is well-established that costs shall follow the event. The court, however, can depart from this starting point if the circumstances of the case justify doing so: WXE v WXF [2024] SGFC 40 at [7] citing Rules 852 and 854 of the FJR 2014.

8       Mr Netto relies on Rule 857(1)(b) of the FJR 2014 to argue that it is the Wife who should have to pay costs to the Husband, even though she had succeeded in both her applications. That provision states:

Costs arising from misconduct or neglect

857.—(1)    Where it appears to the Court in any proceedings that anything has been done, or that any omission has been made, unreasonably or improperly by or on behalf of any party, the Court may order —

(a)    that the costs of that party in respect of the act or omission, as the case may be, shall not be allowed; and

(b)    that any costs occasioned by that party to any other party shall be paid by him to that other party.

(2)    Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (1), the Court must for the purpose of that paragraph have regard to the following matters:

(a)    the omission to do anything the doing of which would have been calculated to save costs;

(b)    the doing of anything calculated to occasion, or in a manner or at a time calculated to occasion unnecessary costs;

(c)    any unnecessary delay in the proceedings.

(3)    The Court may, instead of giving an order under paragraph (1), direct the Registrar to inquire into the act or omission and, if it appears to the Registrar that such an order should have been given in relation to it, to act as if the appropriate order had been given.

(4)    The Registrar shall, in relation to anything done or omission made in the Court of taxation and in relation to any failure to procure taxation, have the same power to disallow or to award costs as the Court has under paragraph (1) to order that costs shall be disallowed to or paid by any party.

(5)    Where a party entitled to costs fails to procure or fails to proceed with taxation, the Registrar may, in order to prevent any other parties being prejudiced by that failure —

(a)    allow the party so entitled a nominal or other sum for costs; or

(b)    certify the failure and the costs of the other parties.

9       Rule 857 is derived from Order 59 Rule 7 of the Rules of Court 2014 and forms one of the “well-established exceptions to the general rule that costs follow the event”: Chen Siyuan, Eunice Chua, Lionel Leo, Family Procedure in Singapore (LexisNexis, 2018) (“Family Procedure in Singapore”) at [857.01]. For example, it is noted that in cases where a plaintiff has adopted an “entirely wrong procedure”, that plaintiff may have to pay his opponent’s costs even though he has prevailed: Singapore Civil Procedure 2021 vol 1 (Cavinder Bull gen ed) (Sweet & Maxwell, 2021) (“White Book”) at 59/7/7 citing Re Nichols & Von Joel’s Contract [1910] 1 Ch. 43.

10     In the present case, the Wife did not first serve a voluntary request for discovery and interrogatories, prior to taking out both applications. As I had noted in my judgment, the Wife could not, despite being self-represented, be said to be wholly ignorant of the applicable procedural rules: XHA v XHB [2025] SGFC 6 at [7]. I also note that in the case conference on 14th November 2024, the learned Assistant Registrar told the Wife that costs may be ordered if she did not first take out a voluntary request for discovery and interrogatories before putting in a formal application to court – the Wife was also told to seek legal advice on the implications of pursuing her applications if she was unsure.

11     The Wife’s course of action naturally meant that there was no voluntary request for the Husband to respond to. As Mr Netto points out, this means that the Husband did not have the opportunity to “negotiate on the time period and/or type of documents to be provided”.

12     I add that although the Husband had resisted the Wife’s application in both SUMs 3376 and 3318, this does not necessarily mean that he would have responded in the same way to a voluntary request for discovery and interrogatories. The point remains that because a voluntary request for the items sought in SUMs 3376 and 3318 was never made, the Husband never had an opportunity to consider and respond to those requests, or make proposals in respect of these requests for the Wife to consider.

13     In the circumstances, I deem it fit to depart from the general rule that costs shall follow the event. I order that the Wife pay costs for both SUMs 3376 and 3318, which are fixed at $350 (all-in), to the Husband. This is to be done by 24th February 2025.

[note: 1]Husband’s Written Submissions on Costs at para 10.

[note: 2]Husband’s Written Submissions on Costs at para 4.

[note: 3]Husband’s Written Submissions on Costs at para 11.

[note: 4]Wife’s Written Submissions on Costs at para 5.

html:
XHM v XHN

XHM v XHN
[2025] SGFC 8

Case Number:MSS 1060/2023
Decision Date:06 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Applicant-in-person and unrepresented; The Respondent-in-person and unrepresented.
Parties: XHM — XHN

Family Law – Child Maintenance

6 January 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       MSS 1060/2023 (“MSS 1060”) was the Mother’s application for maintenance for her 18-year-old son. The Mother sought, from the Father, $400 per month as maintenance for their son. Both the Father and the Mother had been divorced in October 2015.[note: 1]

2       I heard the trial on 4 September 2024 and allowed the Mother’s application. I ordered that the Father pay monthly maintenance of $150 per month, at the end of every month, with effect from 1 June 2026.

3       These are the reasons for my decision.

4       When it comes to such applications for maintenance, s 69 of the Women’s Charter 1961 is the first port of call. In particular, s 69(2) provides that the court may, “on due proof that a parent has neglected or refused to provide reasonable maintenance for his child who is unable to maintain himself, order that parent to pay a monthly allowance or a lump sum for the maintenance of that child” (see also XFP v XFQ [2024] SGFC 97 at [8(a)]).

5       I found that the Father had indeed neglected to provide maintenance for his son. During the trial, I heard evidence from the Mother that she was the one who had supported the child, even throughout their marriage. The Father’s own testimony corroborated the Mother’s account. He told me that he had only contributed some money when his son was born. However, as his son was growing up, he could not afford to support him. This was because he was homeless and sleeping in the streets. The Father explained that he worked odd-jobs as a mover on a part-time basis and only made $70 a day. At times, he was only able to find a 2-day job in a single week.

6       In my judgment, the Father should therefore be ordered to pay maintenance for his son – the next issue I had to consider was the quantum of such maintenance the Father should be ordered to pay.

7       In making such an order for child maintenance, s 69(4) of the Women’s Charter 1961 stipulates that the court is to have regard to all the circumstances of the case including factors such as the financial needs of the child (s 69(4)(a)), the income and earning capacity (if any) of the child (s 69(4)(b)), and the contributions made by each of the parties to the marriage (s 69(4)(d)) (see also WIM v WIL [2022] SGFC 80 at [4] – [9][note: 2]). The court does not adopt a mathematical approach to calibrating the quantum of child maintenance. As was recently noted in WBU v WBT [2023] SGHCF 3:

Applicable legal principles for quantifying maintenance

9     Maintenance is ordered to provide for the reasonable needs of the child, having regard to all the relevant circumstances of the case: see s 69(4) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed) (the “Charter”). The mere fact that the parties have been paying for certain items during the marriage does not automatically render such expenses reasonable expenses for the purposes of determining maintenance. Instead, parties should show how their projected expenditure for the child’s expenses is reasonable having regard to all relevant circumstances, including the child’s standard of living and the parents’ financial means and resources. Further, the changed circumstances following the marital breakdown of the parents’ relationship are relevant as the breakdown of a household invariably has an impact on the family’s financial needs and resources.

10     It follows that in seeking to quantify the child’s reasonable expenses, parties should avoid an overly mathematical approach where receipts are adduced to prove every single item of expenditure. This is not to say that no evidence is ever required to support proposals for what is sought as reasonable maintenance; it depends on the type of expenses sought, and of course, on the facts of each case. While receipts are useful as an indication of the child’s accustomed standard of living, they are not necessarily conclusive of what the child’s reasonable expenses are. It may be helpful for parties to apply their minds to drawing up what can be described as a ‘budget’, whereby broad categories of the child’s estimated needs are identified, and a corresponding reasonable sum is proposed for each category (see, for example, the table set out below at [13]). It was observed in UEB v UEC [2018] SGHCF 5 (at [13]):

While it is a very useful practice to determine whether each item in the list of expenses submitted by the Wife is a reasonable one, one should not be overly mesmerised by the approach of reaching a maintenance sum only by totalling up every item of expense as if it were a legal requirement. The law provides that the court shall take into account various factors in deciding the maintenance award. The law does not require that every specific item of expense be proved by receipts or assessed on specific values, as if on a reimbursement exercise. More exceptional expenses though, such as certain medical needs and costs, ought to be supported by evidence. A child’s needs and expenses may also fluctuate from month to month; similarly, household expenses may fluctuate over time. Setting out regular specific expenses nevertheless enables the other party and the court to assess broadly whether the expenses are reasonable.

[emphasis added]

8       The Mother explained that she had taken out her application in MSS 1060 as she was facing difficulty in supporting her son given the state of her health and her son’s growing expenses. She was unable to work as she was battling a host of medical conditions which included: a nerve issue which required surgery, as well as diabetes and cholesterol. In addition, the Mother also explained that she had been seeing a psychiatrist from the Institute for Mental Health for depression and anxiety.

9       I also heard evidence that the son was working part time and was earning an hourly wage of $10. The Mother would give him some money amounting to $350 – $400 a month for school fees and food. I was also told, by the Mother, that the son, who is currently a student at the Institute of Technical Education, intends to further his education by enrolling in polytechnic. The Mother shared that the son would like to focus on his studies.

10     Given the Mother’s circumstances, it was clear to me that the Father must do his part to provide financially for the son. That is his responsibility as a parent. In that connection, the Father told me that in his estimation, he would be able to afford $100 a month in child maintenance, but only upon his release from prison in 2026. He had begun serving a two-year sentence earlier in March this year.

11     I thus ordered that the Father pay maintenance of $150 per month to his son starting from 1 June 2026, and that this sum be paid on the last day of every month. This means that the first payment will be made on the last day of June 2026.

12     In drawing up this order for maintenance, I placed weight on the Father’s financial circumstances and his capacity to make payment (see VLO v VLP [2021] SGFC 68 at [135]; XFP v XFQ [2024] SGFC 97 at [14] – [15]). I accepted that the Father currently had no means of paying monthly child maintenance given his testimony that he had no savings, and the fact that he was currently in jail. It was also likely, in my judgment, that the monthly sum of $400 which the Mother had sought, while a reasonable sum to ask for in respect of child maintenance, would be beyond the Father’s means. There was, in my judgment, little point in making an order that the Father had no means of being able to comply with.

13     As to what the Father could reasonably afford, I took into account his evidence that he had previously been able to find part-time work at a rate of $70 per day. Even accepting that the Father may not be able to find part-time work at the same daily rate for every day of the month, the monthly sum of $100 which the Husband thinks he can afford is, in my judgment, on the conservative side.

14     This order gives the Father a little time to get back on his feet upon his release from prison sometime at the end of March 2026. The Father will have about 3 months to find a job and to get his finances in order so that he can begin to do his part to support his son. While he has not done so for the better part of his son’s life, it is not too late for him to start doing so.

15     Given that the Mother did not ask for costs of her application, I made no order as to costs.

[note: 1]Pursuant to an Order of the Syariah Court.

[note: 2]The appeal filed against the decision of the District Judge was deemed withdrawn on 22 December 2022.

html:
XHI v XHJ

XHI v XHJ
[2025] SGFC 7

Case Number:Divorce No 5149 of 2023 (Summons No 3306 of 2024)
Decision Date:13 January 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Ong Ying Ting, Eunice (Netto & Magin LLC) for the plaintiff; Seetha Lkshmi P.S. Krrishnan (East Asia Law Corporation) for the defendant.
Parties: XHI — XHJ

Family Law – Procedure – Discovery

13 January 2025

Judgment reserved

Assistant Registrar Soh Kian Peng:

1       Parties were married on 12 February 2020. They had two daughters. After more than two decades of marriage, the Husband filed for divorce on the 25th of October 2023, citing the Wife’s unreasonable behaviour as the reason for irretrievable breakdown of their marriage.

2       Interim judgment was granted on the 25th of April 2024. Thereafter, parties charted a course for a hearing of the ancillary matters.

3       It is in this context that the Wife has taken out an application for discovery vide SUM 3306/2024 (“SUM 3306”). During the hearing before me, counsel for the Wife, Ms Seetha Lkshmi (“Ms Seetha”) confirmed that the Wife was only proceeding on the following two items:

(a)      Item 1: Bank account statements for the following bank accounts for the period (January 2020 to May 2020 and January 2023 to December 2023):

(i)       OCBC account ending -57;

(ii)       POSB account ending -44;

(iii)       DBS account ending -46;

(iv)       DBS account ending -23.

(b)      Item 2: Bank account statements for a Standard Chartered Wealth Saver account ending -35 from the time the account was opened, till the time the account was closed.

4       It is hornbook law that a party seeking discovery must demonstrate the relevance and necessity of the documents sought to the hearing of the substantive matters: WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [22].

5       With regard to Item 1, the Wife explained that the bank statements are needed for two reasons. First, to ascertain why the Husband had received the sum of $45,000 from a third party, [X]. The Wife says that the Husband had told her, in a conversation, that he had lent this sum of money to [X]. The Husband’s account, however, is that [X] had transferred this sum to him to make investments on his behalf.

6       The second reason the Wife gives is that these statements are needed to ascertain if the Husband had been dissipating assets. She points out that the Husband had, in April 2021, some $390,000 in his DBS account ending -6. However, in his first Affidavit of Assets and Means (“AOM”) filed on 3 June 2024, the Husband discloses that he only has $8,903.73 in that account.

7       In my judgment, the documents which the Wife seeks disclosure of in Item 1 are certainly relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. It would go towards the issue of whether the sum of $45,000 which [X] had sent to the Husband, was for an investment to be made on [X]’s behalf, or whether it was repayment for a loan which the Husband had made to [X]. It would also shed light on whether there had been any dissipation of matrimonial assets.

8       I note that the Husband has given his account of events relating to the sum of $45,000.[note: 1] He has also explained the reason for the reduction in the balance in his DBS account ending -6.[note: 2] I must emphasise that, at the interlocutory stage, it is not for me to decide where the truth lies in relation to the various transactions which the Wife is disputing. The purpose of the discovery process is to ensure that all the relevant evidence is placed before the hearing judge, and also to allow parties the opportunity to evaluate their case: XGY v XGZ [2025] SGFC 3 at [14] citing The Lao People’s Democratic Republic v Sanum Investments Ltd and another and another matter [2013] 4 SLR 947 at [24] citing Teo Wai Cheong v Crédit Industriel et Commercial [2013] 3 SLR 573 at [41]. In that connection, a party only needs to demonstrate the relevance and necessity of the documents sought.

9       As for the Husband’s objection to providing disclosure on the basis that it would be too costly for him to do so, I too, could not accept this argument. For one, the costs of complying with an order for discovery is generally borne by the party giving discovery. Although the court can depart from this starting point, and order that the party entitled to discovery “bear a whole or a portion of the costs of compliance with such an order for the giving of discovery” (WZR v WZS [2024] SGFC 51 at [21] citing Family Justice Courts Practice Directions para 81(35) and (36); Chen Siyuan, Eunice Chua, Lionel Leo, Family Procedure in Singapore (LexisNexis, 2018) at p 945), I saw no reason to depart from this general position. After all, the Husband had, in his reply affidavit to SUM 3306, stated:[note: 3]

… I also maintain that I have always provided a full and frank disclosure of my assets and finances as I have always kept good records of my finances.

10     Given the Husband’s evidence, one would expect him to have kept copies of these bank statements. In any event, insofar as the Husband has stated that he would need to fork out, at the very least, $9,600 to obtain the statements which the Wife seeks,[note: 4] he did not put forward any documentary evidence from the banks to support his claim. As I had noted in my earlier judgment in WZR v WZS [2024] SGFC 51:

25    I would, however, observe that in a future case, it may well be open to the party giving discovery to seek liberty to apply for an order that the party entitled to discovery is to bear the entirety, or a portion of the costs that may be incurred in complying with the order for discovery. In doing so, that party must articulate their legal and factual basis for seeking such an order. Naturally, in deciding whether it is appropriate to make such an order, the court will consider all the relevant circumstances. This could include factors such as the quantum of such costs that had been incurred or were likely to be incurred, and whether there was any reasonable way to avoid incurring such costs.

11     Finally, as to the Husband’s objection that the statements sought related to a period where divorce was not contemplated at all, the law is clear that it is indeed useful for the court to have an insight into parties’ finances during the breakdown of the marriage and prior to the filing of divorce. This is because, during the breakdown of the marriage, there is often a decrease in the knowledge and involvement of each party about the other’s finances: XGY v XGZ [2025] SGFC 3 at [9] citing WWS v WWT [2024] SGFC 24 at [79] citing Tan Bin Yong Christopher v Ng Lay Mui (m.w.) and other cases [2003] SGDC 306 (“Tan Bin Yong Christopher”) at [19].

12     In this connection, although the divorce was only filed in October 2023, I note from the Husband’s Statement of Particulars as well as parties’ 1st AOMs, that their marriage of some two decades, did not appear to have been an entirely happy one, and that their relationship had gone down the path of no return long before the divorce was filed. For instance, the Husband states, in his 1st AOM, that their marital relations had begun to break down over the years.[note: 5] The Wife also states, in her 1st AOM, that she had suffered “25 years of [p]hysical and [e]motional abuse” by the Husband.[note: 6]

13     Apart from the various details which demonstrate that the parties’ relationship was strained years before the divorce, the Husband did also state, in his reply affidavit to SUM 3306, that the both of them always had “independence over [their] own bank accounts and finances” and that they would not “question each other on how” they chose to spend their own money.[note: 7] Given this state of affairs, it appears that the Wife may not have had much knowledge, or involvement in the Husband’s finances. In that vein, the Wife’s request for the documents in Item 1 cannot be said to be a wholly unreasonable one.

14     I will therefore allow the request in Item 1.

15     As for the request in Item 2, the documents which the Wife seeks are, in my judgment, also relevant and necessary to the hearing of the ancillary matters. These bank statements would go towards verifying the Husband’s claim in his 1st AOM that he used to hold the sum of $501,849 on behalf of his mother, and [X], for investment purposes.[note: 8]

16     The Husband’s main objection to giving disclosure in relation to Item 2 is that he no longer has the documents given that he has “disposed of all documents relating to this account”. I cannot accept this for two reasons. First, I find it rather strange that the Husband would dispose of these statements, especially given his claim that the money in this account belonged to other people. During the hearing, counsel for the Husband, Ms Eunice Ong (“Ms Ong”) had told me that the Husband was careful with money and that he would keep the relevant statements where he had dealt with other people’s money. If this was indeed the case – then the Husband should have no difficulty in producing these bank statements. In any event, I note that the Husband has not provided proof that it would be impossible to obtain these statements by writing to the bank to request for the same.

17     The Wife’s request in Item 2 is also allowed.

18     In summary, I therefore order that:

(a)     The Husband shall state on affidavit, pursuant to Rule 63 of the Family Justice Rules 2014, in respect of each of the following documents sought in discovery, as listed in Schedule A of SUM 3306, whether the same is in his possession, custody or power, and if not then in his possession, custody or power, when he parted with it and what has become of it;

(b)     The Husband shall exhibit, in his affidavit, a copy of each of the documents that are in his possession, custody or power. If any of the documents are not in his custody, power or possession, he is to state the reasons why, together with supporting documentation for his explanation (if any);

(c)     The Husband is to file his compliance affidavit by the 10th of February 2025.

19     As to the issue of costs, Ms Ong argued that parties should bear their own costs. Counsel for the Wife, Ms Seetha Lkshmi (“Ms Seetha”), on the other hand, argued that the Wife should be entitled to costs.

20     Given that the Wife had succeeded in her application, she is entitled to costs, which are fixed at $950 (all-in). In determining the quantum of costs, I took into account the fact that the Wife’s application was not a lengthy one and did not involve any novel points of law. The Husband is to pay this sum of $950 to the Wife by the 10th of February 2025.

21     For the avoidance of doubt, nothing I have said here shall bind the hands of the judge hearing the ancillary matters.

22     Finally, it remains for me to thank Ms Ong and Ms Seetha for their able assistance.
